sloka: cinmayasyādvitīyasya niṣkalasyāśarīriṇaḥ | upāsakānāṃ kāryārthe brahmaṇo rūpakalpanā ||
translation: For the worshippers, in determining the form of the undivided, bodiless, and unique consciousness, what is to be contemplated?

sloka: devebhyaḥ svāhākāra ā kāṣṭhāt
translation: From the sacrificial post to the gods , the exclamation "svāhā!" is offered.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Therefore, it nourishes the waters, therefore it enriches the sky and the earth with its essence, therefore it strengthens herbs with moisture, therefore it fills the spaces in-between with vitality.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: During the full moon of Rohini, Mrigashirsha, Phalguna, and the upper limbs of Vishakha.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: In the constellation of Kritika, a Brahmin who has thoroughly studied the Vedas becomes the primary source of spiritual illumination; he becomes like a domestic fire.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are spring, summer, and the rains; those deities are autumn and late winter, and these [two] are the fatherly ones in the cold season.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: During the entire night, (one) should engage in remaining awake for vigil.

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: From the seed of a śamī tree, fire is churned. This is indeed the sacrificial form of fire itself.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: With these three syllables "bhūr, bhuvaḥ, iti," [the priest] establishes the sacrificial fire, protecting it from going out too soon or too late.

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: I will now offer with fire, along with oblations and sacrificial rituals (yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saha), the ashvattha tree that arises from śamī's womb, as I am capable of doing so with my brahmanical powers (brahmaṇā āharāmi) before the fully accomplished agnyādheya sacrifice (pūrṇāhutyantam).

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: Having abandoned the fire three nights and a day after kindling it, or at once during a rain shower, one should establish anew the ripened piles of rice, barley, and darbha grass in the midday sun in the gārhapatya fire; this is my command for the worthy as long as it is possible.

sloka: nānāhitāgnirnāyajvā vipro nāpyasahasradaḥ |
translation: A priest is not a multidirectional benefactor of fire altars nor one who has a thousand senses.

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: This indeed is an un sacrificial one, who is a womanizer.

sloka: etadvai jarāmaryaṃ satraṃ yadagnihotraṃ jarayā vā hyevāsmānmucyate mṛtyunā vā payasā nityahomaḥ
translation: This is indeed the ritual, oh deathly one, that conquers aging - the agnihotra; it frees us either from aging or through the constant offering of an oblation with milk.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: Of yava broth, tears, and curd, what is the desire of those who are devoted to satisfying the various senses' desires and cravings?

sloka: dhūmāyantyām grāma kāmasya juhuyāt | jvalantyām brahma varcasa kāmasya | aṅgāreṣu paśu kāmasya |
translation: During the village fire's outbreak, one should offer obligations (to the fire). For it is ablaze with divine effulgence, and at this time also, it is in the cattle and other body parts of the sacrificial ritual.

sloka: jātaṃ vātsapreṇābhimṛśyottareṇa yajuṣopastha ādhāyottarābhyāmābhimantraṇaṃ mūrdhanyavaghrāṇaṃ dakṣiṇe karṇe jāpaḥ sarṣapānphalīkaraṇamiśrānañjalinottaraistristripratisvāhākāraṃ hutvā saṃśāsti praviṣṭe praviṣṭa eva tūṣṇīmagnāvāvapateti
translation: Born, having been anointed on the head with clarified butter by the elder sister of the cowherd after the recitation of the Yajus formulas, and having offered oblations mixed with sesame seeds while keeping the hands joined in prayer, remains silent, having entered the fire.

sloka: athaināmuttarayā dakṣiṇe haste gṛhītvāgnimabhyānīyāpareṇāgnimudagagraṃ kaṭamāstīrya tasminnupaviśata uttaro varaḥ agnerupasamādhānādyājyabhāgānte'thaināmādito dvābhyāmabhimantrayeta
translation: Having taken the fire deity with his right hand and brought it to the southern side, having kindled it by placing it on a suitable support, he should make the oblations in the end of the first portion of the offering. Then, having made an exception for the final oblation, he should invoke the fire deity twice with mantras.

sloka: sāyaṃsāyaṃ gṛhapatirno agniḥ prātaḥprātaḥ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhi vayaṃ tvendhānāstanvaṃ puṣema || prātaḥprātargṛhapatirno agniḥ sāyaṃsāyaṃ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhīndhānāstvā śataṃhimā ṛdhema ||
translation: At dawn, the householder is not without the fire; in the evening, the giver of comfort is. We should nourish our bodies with food and fuel at both times. In the morning, the householder is not without the fire; in the evening, the giver of comfort is. May we sustain ourselves with a hundred measures of vigor and strength at all times.

sloka: sa yatsāyamastamite dve'āhutī juhoti | tadetābhyāṃ pūrvābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhattyatha yatprātaranudite dve'āhutī juhoti tadetābhyāmaparābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhati sa'enameṣa'udyannevā''dāyodeti tadetaṃ mṛtyumatimucyate
translation: The one who offers, at sandhyakaal (dusk and dawn), two oblations while reciting that sāyaṃ mantra, is established in this and the next death. Similarly, the one who offers, at sandhyakaal, two oblations while reciting the prātaḥ mantra, is established in this and the following death. This practice, named udandani, liberates one from an early death.

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: Performing the agnihotra ritual, the wise person rejects this worthless fuel that splutters at the very lighting; indeed, all sinful people despise this alone.

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: Where dwell living beings.

sloka: karṇaśrave'nile rātrau divā pāṃsusamūhane | etau varṣāsvanadhyāyāvadhyāyajñāḥ pracakṣate
translation: During nighttime under the name "Karna-shravani" and during daytime at the time of dust storms, these two are known as the rains' recitation and study, respectively.

sloka: vidyutstanitavarṣeṣu maholkānāṃ ca saṃplave | ākālikam anadhyām eteṣu manurabravīt etāṃstvabhyuditānvidyādyadā prāduṣkṛtāgniṣu | tadā vidyādanadhyāyam anṛtau cābhradarśane
translation: Manu spoke of this knowledge that becomes manifest when lightning illuminates the sky during the rainfall of great meteors: study it thoroughly at both dawn and dusk, especially after fire sacrifices have been performed and clouds are present.

sloka: nirghāte bhūmicalane jyotiṣāṃ copasarjane | etānākālikānvidyādanadhyāyānṛtāvapi prāduṣkṛteṣvagniṣu tu vidyutstanitaniḥsvane | sajyotiḥ syādanadhyāyaḥ śeṣe rātrau yathā divā
translation: Even in the absence of daytime and during the night, when stars appear, when fires ignited for various purposes start to dwindle, and despite the cessation of lessons, the meteors, like flashes of light, continue to shine; similarly, knowledge should be constantly cultivated.

sloka: nīhāre bāṇaśabde ca saṃdhyayoreva cobhayoḥ | amāvāsyācaturdaśyoḥ paurṇamāsyaṣṭakāsu ca amāvāsyā guruṃ hanti śiṣyaṃ hanti caturdaśī | brahmāṣṭakapaurṇamāsyau tasmāttāḥ parivarjayet
translation: During the sandhyas, specifically during new moon and full moon phases, one should avoid using arrows (or any weapon) named bana, for it can harm both the guru and the shishya on the 14th day of each lunar phase; similarly, one should stay away from Brahma's octet during the full moon.

sloka: pāṃsuvarṣe diśāṃ dāhe gomāyuvirute tathā | śvakharoṣṭre ca ruvati paṅktau ca na paṭheddvijaḥ
translation: In a shower of sand particles, just as in a fire in all directions, on a dog, a donkey, and in the rows (of the Vedas), a twice-born person should not stumble.

sloka: pratigṛhya dvijo vidvānekoddiṣṭasya ketanam | tryahaṃ na kīrtayedbrahma rājño rāhośca sūtake yāvadekānudiṣṭasya gandho lepaśca tiṣṭhati | viprasya viduṣo dehe tāvadbrahma na kīrtayet prāṇi vā yadi vāprāṇi yatkiṃ cicchrāddhikaṃ bhavet | tadālabhyāpyanadhyāyaḥ pāṇyāsyo hi dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ
translation: A twice-born scholar should not publicize the king's designated insignia; its fragrance and mark remain as long as it is meant for that scholar. The Brahman should not be proclaimed in a virtuous man's body until his specific rite of passage, whether involving living beings or not, is completed. Only when the appropriate study is undertaken is the twice-born one remembered by their hands.

sloka: dvāveva varjayennityaṃ anadhyāyau prayatnataḥ | svādhyāyabhūmiṃ cāśuddhaṃ ātmānaṃ cāśuciṃ dvijaḥ
translation: A twice-born should diligently avoid two things: consistently neglecting one's own study and maintaining an impure mind/self , as well as an unclean study material .

sloka: nādhīyītāśvaṃ ārūḍho na vṛkṣaṃ na ca hastinam | na nāvaṃ na kharaṃ noṣṭraṃ neriṇastho na yānagaḥ śayānaḥ prauḍhapādaśca kṛtvā caivāvasakthikām | nādhīyītāmiṣaṃ jagdhvā sūtakānnādyaṃ eva ca
translation: Should not one mount an untrained horse, nor a tree, nor an elephant, nor a boat, nor a cart, nor lie down in the midst of a highway or on a pile of hay, nor should one eat meat, drink wine, or indulge in garlic and onions?

sloka: corairupadrute grāme saṃbhrame cāgnikārite | ākālikaṃ anadhyāyaṃ vidyātsarvādbhuteṣu ca
translation: In the nearby village, due to carelessness or during a fire, studying is not to be neglected, especially in the face of unexpected calamities.

sloka: upākarmaṇi cotsarge trirātraṃ kṣepaṇaṃ smṛtam | aṣṭakāsu tvahorātraṃ ṛtvantāsu ca rātriṣu
translation: In the case of the upākarma ritual, it is remembered that one should perform kṣepaṇa for three nights; in contrast, for the eight days of the ṛtu and the intervening nights, only a single-night performance is recommended.

sloka: na vivāde na kalahe na senāyāṃ na saṃgare | na bhuktamātre nājīrṇe na vamitvā na śuktake atithiṃ cānanujñāpya mārute vāti vā bhṛśam | rudhire ca srute gātrācchastreṇa ca parikṣate
translation: Without causing controversy or strife, without in a battle or combat, not even for a well-cooked meal or remnants, nor for the sake of avoiding unpleasant tasks, nor out of fear of reproof or to gain praise; only when the guest has been received with respect, when the wind is blowing hard, and when one's injuries have been inspected and treated - then one should speak.

sloka: sāmadhvanāvṛgyajuṣī nādhīyīta kadā cana | vedasyādhītya vāpyantaṃ āraṇyakaṃ adhītya ca
translation: One should never neglect the study of both samhitas and yajus recitations; only after thoroughly studying the Vedas and also the Aranyakas can one do so.

sloka: vibhāvasubharadrājau parjanyairāvatau tathā | viśvācīsenajitsaṃjñau kārttike cādhikāriṇāḥ ||
translation: The rulers of the Vasus and Bharatas, like Indra (Parjanya) and Varuna (Airavata), known as Senajit and Vacaspati, are respectively dominant in the rainy season and in the month of Karttika.

sloka: śeṣaḥ prathamato jāto vāsukistadanantaram| airāvatastakṣakaśca karkoṭakadhanañjayau||
translation: The first-born was Shesha, followed by Vasuki, then Airaavata, Takshaka, Karkotaka, and Dhanañjaya.

sloka: daśa krodhavaśā rāma vijajñe api ātmasaṃbhavāḥ | mṛgīm ca mṛgamaṃdām ca harīm bhadramadām api ||
translation: Even Rama, who is under the control of ten emotions, was born. Both the doe-like deer and the magnificent elephant were also born.

sloka: tato jajñe mahākāyaścaturdanto mahāgajaḥ| kapilā kāmavṛkṣaśca kaustubhaścāpsarogaṇaḥ|
translation: Then arose Mahakaya, the elephant with four tusks, along with Kapila, the desire-fulfilling tree and Kaustubha, the celestial gems, as well as the group of Apsaras.

sloka: pitṛṇāṃ dharmarājaṃ taṃ yamaṃ rājye'bhyaṣecayat | airāvataṃ gajendrāṇām aśeṣāṇāṃ patiṃ dadau ||
translation: The righteous king of the ancestors , he appointed as the ruler of Yama. To all elephant lords , he gave Airavata as their leader.

sloka: śeṣantu nāgarājānaṃ mṛgāṇāṃ siṃhamīśvaram | vanaspatīnāṃ rājānaṃ plakṣamevābhyaṣecayat ||
translation: Let the king of snakes (Ananta/Shesha) be anointed as the king of cities, and let him be respectfully invoked as the lord of animals (lion) among the herds of animals. Similarly, let the plaksa tree be reverentially enthroned as the king of trees.

sloka: yo māmajamanādiṃ ca vetti lokamaheśvaram | asaṃmūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate ||
translation: The one who truly understands me, the unborn and beginningless, along with the Lord of the universe, becomes free from all sins in this world and is not deluded.

sloka: maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavastathā | madbhāvā mānasā jātā yeṣāṃ loka imāḥ prajāḥ ||
translation: The seven great sages of yore and the four subsequent ones were born mentally, as were their progeny who populate these worlds.

sloka: etāṃ vibhūtiṃ yogaṃ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ | so'vikampena yogena yujyate nātra saṃśayaḥ ||
translation: One who truly understands my divine manifestation and yoga experiences union without doubt.

sloka: arjuna uvāca
translation: Arjuna spoke (the following words).

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: I myself created the four-varnas (castes) based on attributes and actions; know me to be the imperishable creator of it.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: When the Lord in his cosmic form brought about creation, then from his body emerged the four varnas (social classes) in sequence: first the brahmins from his mouth, then the kshatriyas in great numbers from his arms, next the vaihysas from his thighs, and finally the shudras from his feet.

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī |
translation: Just as all living beings exist depending on the wind, similarly all ashrams (stages of life) function relying on the householder. Indeed, the knowledge of the three ashramas is upheld by the householder alone on a daily basis. Therefore, the householder stage of life is considered the highest.

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I meditate on the Rigveda, the Bhagavan; Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana, the other three; the fifth Veda, the itihasa-purana; the treasury of pitrya and daiva rituals; the one eloquent Vedic statement; the knowledge of devas, brahma, beings, kshatra, stars, and serpent deities. This, Bhagavan, I meditate upon.

sloka: ahaṃ tṛtīya ityatristasmādatriḥ sa kīrtyate ||
translation: I am referred to as "the third" and known as Atri; thus, Atri is glorified.

sloka: atrivaṃśasamutpanno brahmayoniḥ sanātanaḥ| prācīnabahirbhagavāṃstasmātprācetaso daśa||
translation: Born from the eternal and ancient Brahma-yoni of the lineage of Atri, he is the outer revered being, known as Pracetas; indeed, he is the tenth one.

sloka: daśānāṃ tanayastveko dakṣo nāma prajāpatiḥ| tasya dve nāmanī loke dakṣaḥ ka iti cocyate||
translation: Of the ten's offspring, there is one called Daksha, named Prajapati. In this world, he has two names – Daksha and who is that?

sloka: vāgevātrirvācā hyannamadyate'ttirha vai nāmaitadyadatririti | sarvasyāttā bhavati sarvamasyānnambhavati | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: Speech, life air, and food indeed sustain each other; all of these become the individual's inner self. Knowing this one becomes everything, and all things become their sustenance.

sloka: svāminaḥ sevanaṃ dṛṣṭvā śivasya ca parātmanaḥ || sādhvi dharmaṃ ca te dṛṣṭvā sthitāsmi tava sannidhau ||
translation: Having seen the service of my lord Shiva and his supreme self, and having witnessed your adherence to righteousness, I have taken my stand in your presence.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā nātiprabhaṃ somaṃ tathā sūryaṃ ca pārthiva| prakāśamakarodatristapasā svena saṃyuge| jagadvitimiraṃ cāpi pradīptamakarottadā||
translation: Having seen the extremely radiant Moon and Sun, in that very battle, the sage Atri, through his own spiritual power, made daylight and also dispelled the cosmic darkness that had covered the world.

sloka: sarvaṃ hīdaṃ prāṇenā''vṛtam iti | so'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhastadyathā'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdha | evaṃ sarvāṇi bhūtāni āpipīlikābhyaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhānītyevaṃ vidyāt iti ||
translation: All this is indeed pervaded by the life-force . This sky/space is filled with that same life-force , as it were. Similarly, all beings , from elephants to the smallest atoms , are pervaded by that life-force . This is the wisdom to be known .

sloka: āyuḥ prāṇaḥ prāṇo vā āyuḥ prāṇa evācāmṛtam | yāvaddhyasmiñcharīre prāṇo vasati tāvadāyuḥ |
translation: Life (ayuh) and vital breath (prana) are the same; they are indeed immortal (amaratma) so long as they reside in this body (asmin sharire).

sloka: prāṇena sṛṣṭāvantarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca | antarikṣaṃ vā anucaranti antarikṣamanuśṛṇvanti | vāyurasmai puṇyaṃ gandhamāvahati | evametau prāṇaṃ pitaraṃ paricarato'ntarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca |
translation: Inhaling and exhaling, the air and the sky serve and listen to the sky; the pure scent is borne by the wind to the sky. Thus, these two (elements), while serving the breath, the father, also move in and perceive the sky.

sloka: taṃ devāḥ prāṇayanta sa praṇītaḥ prātāyata prātāyītī~ tatprātarabhavatsamāgāditī~ tatsāyamabhavadahareva prāṇo rātrirapānaḥ iti |
translation: The gods breathed out that (object) which was then taken in by the Prahitas. At dawn, it was gathered there. That very breath became day and night in this form.

sloka: vāgagniścakṣurasāvādityaścandramā mano diśaḥ śrotraṃ sa eṣa prahitāṃ saṃyogo'dhyātmamimā devatā ada u āviradhidaivatamityetattaduktaṃ bhavati iti |
translation: This is the established connection of speech as fire, the sun as seer, the moon as provider of sap, the mind as controller, the directions as hearing, and this self consisting of these divine powers: it is spoken that it is so.

sloka: pūrvajanma kṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhi rūpeṇa bādhate | tata śāṃtiroṣadhedāneṃ mantra japa homa surāracaneṃ ||
translation: The past life's accumulated sins manifest as diseases. To alleviate this disturbance of peace and vitality, one should engage in mantra recitation, fire rituals, and offerings to the divine.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: By truth and immortality should one live, whether it be with falsehood or without. The true must never be mixed with the false. Immortality is rightfully earned, while falsehood is merely asked for as alms. Gain is remembered as earned through hard work, falsehood as a profession. One should live by service and reject the false life.

sloka: ato'nyatamayā vṛttyā jīvaṃstu snātako dvijaḥ | svargāyuṣyayaśasyāni vratāṇīmāni dhārayet
translation: Hence, a twice-born (dvija) bath-purified snātaka, should observe these vows that yield heavenly long life and fame, not engaging in any other occupation but this.

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: One should practice the Vedas continuously and without fatigue, as he desires; for they call this his supreme duty, and any other is called an inferior duty.

sloka: klptakeśanakhaśmaśrurdāntaḥ śuklāmbaraḥ śuciḥ | svādhyāye caiva yuktaḥ syānnityaṃ ātmahiteṣu ca
translation: With well-combed hair and nails, wearing white and pure garments, always engaged in self-study and using them for the benefit of oneself and others.

sloka: sarvānparityajedarthānsvādhyāyasya virodhinaḥ | yathā tathādhyāpayaṃstu sā hyasya kṛtakṛtyatā
translation: Give up all activities that hinder study, whether they be few or many, and in this way fulfill your duty.

sloka: buddhivṛddhikarāṇyāśu dhanyāni ca hitāni ca | nityaṃ śāstrāṇyavekṣeta nigamāṃścaiva vaidikān | yathā yathā hi puruṣaḥ śāstraṃ samadhigacchati | tathā tathā vijānāti vijñānaṃ cāsya rocate
translation: One should regularly examine the scriptures and the ancient Vedic lore, for as a person acquires knowledge of the scriptures, so does their understanding grow and become illuminated.

sloka: vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: By constantly practicing the Vedas, purity, and austerities, as well as by being impartial towards all beings, one recalls their original, natural form. Through unceasing practice of Brahman, immense and eternal bliss is experienced.

sloka: ṛṣiyajñaṃ devayajñaṃ bhūtayajñaṃ ca sarvadā | nṛyajñaṃ pitṛyajñaṃ ca yathāśakti na hāpayet
translation: One should always perform the ṛṣi-yajña, deva-yajña, bhūta-yajña, and according to one's ability, human-yajña and pitr-yajña.

sloka: etāneke mahāyajñānyajñaśāstravido janāḥ | anīhamānāḥ satataṃ indriyeṣveva juhvati vācyeke juhvati prāṇaṃ prāṇe vācaṃ ca sarvadā | vāci prāṇe ca paśyanto yajñanirvṛttiṃ akṣayām
translation: These scholars of sacrificial rituals' scriptures, some offer sacrifices through their senses, constantly and abstemiously; others offer speech and breath, always; perceiving the unending fulfillment in sacrifice through speech and breath.

sloka: jñānenaivāpare viprā yajantyetairmakhaiḥ sadā | jñānamūlāṃ kriyāṃ eṣāṃ paśyanto jñānacakṣuṣā
translation: Scholars indeed always worship with the single means of knowledge, through constant ritual offerings that are false. They see this action as having its origin in knowledge, through the vision of insight.

sloka: agnihotraṃ ca juhuyādādyante dyuniśoḥ sadā | darśena cārdhamāsānte paurṇāmāsena caiva hi
translation: One should perform the agnihotra sacrifice continuously at both the beginning and end of daylight hours, as well as at half-monthly intervals during the full and new moon.

sloka: sāvitrāñ śāntihomāṃśca kuryātparvasu nityaśaḥ | pitṝṃścaivāṣṭakāsvarcennityaṃ anvaṣṭakāsu ca
translation: One should perform the Savitra chant and the peace chant daily in the prescribed rites, as well as regularly offer respects to the ancestors during the eight-day observances.

sloka: rājato dhanam anvicchetsaṃsīdansnātakaḥ kṣudhā | yājyāntevāsinorvāpi na tvanyata iti sthitiḥ
translation: Seeking wealth should be pursued only after renunciation and bathing, not due to hunger; this is the view of those who dwell near the sacrificial altar, as well as others.

sloka: na sīdetsnātako vipraḥ kṣudhā śaktaḥ kathaṃ cana | na jīrṇamalavadvāsā bhavecca vibhave sati
translation: A brahmin cannot be unsteady, how could he ever, who is not a recent initiate, capable of being overwhelmed by hunger, and dressed in dirty, tattered clothes, even if he has the means.

sloka: daśa sūṇāsahasrāṇi yo vāhayati saunikaḥ | tena tulyaḥ smṛto rājā ghorastasya pratigrahaḥ yo rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇāti lubdhasyocchāstravartinaḥ | sa paryāyeṇa yātīmānnarakānekaviṃśatim etadvidanto vidvāṃso brāhmaṇā brahmavādinaḥ | na rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇanti pretya śreyo'bhikāṅkṣiṇaḥ
translation: The king who can carry a burden of ten thousand chariots is considered equal to Saunika. One who desires to receive such a tribute from the king must not be greedy or unversed in scriptures. Such a person, entering

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: In this world, one should diligently practice the conduct that is associated with learning, lineage, actions' purpose, and words. The conduct, when bound to scriptures and traditions, becomes the foundation of dharma. Such a conduct leads to long life, desired progeny, and infinite wealth. Indeed, proper conduct destroys inauspiciousness.

sloka: sarvalakṣaṇahīno'pi yaḥ sadācāravānnaraḥ | śraddadhāno'nasūyaśca śataṃ varṣāṇi jīvati durācāro hi puruṣo loke bhavati ninditaḥ | duḥkhabhāgī ca satataṃ vyādhito'lpāyureva ca
translation: Even one who is devoid of all qualities, if they are consistently righteous and free from envy, they can live for a hundred years. However, a wicked person in this world becomes an object of censure and is constantly afflicted with suffering and a short lifespan.

sloka: na pāṇipādacapalo na netracapalo'nṛjuḥ | na syādvākcapalaścaiva na paradrohakarmadhīḥ yenāsya pitaro yātā yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ | tena yāyātsatāṃ mārgaṃ tena gacchanna riṣyati vairiṇaṃ nopaseveta sahāyaṃ caiva vairiṇaḥ | adhārmikaṃ taskaraṃ ca parasyaiva ca yoṣitam | na hīdṛśaṃ anāyuṣyaṃ loke kiṃ cana vidyate | yādṛśaṃ puruṣasyeha paradāropasevanam |
translation: One who is not unsteady in hand or foot, not a wanderer of the eyes, nor untruthful in speech, nor fickle in intent; through whom his ancestors have attained their abodes, as well as his great-grandfathers; such a one should tread the path of the virtuous. He should not be approached by an enemy, nor should he associate with such a companion. Unrighteous thieves and another's wife - nothing like this is found in the world for such a person. This is the kind of association that exists for a man in the world; indeed, there is nothing else comparable to it.

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktānāṃ nityaṃ ca prayatātmanām | japatāṃ juhvatāṃ caiva vinipāto na vidyate
translation: For those who are always engaged in conduct joined with auspiciousness and whose souls are dedicated to constant practice, there is never a downfall for those who recite and make offerings.

sloka: dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: One who is firm in their resolve, gentle in nature, avoids cruel company, is harmless, self-controlled, and charitable can attain heavenly bliss according to this vow.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: By following this conduct as a scholar, always observing the Vedic scriptures and free from defects, one becomes exalted in the abode of Brahman.

sloka: sākṣāt mokṣasādhanāni imāni ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyāsitavyaḥ | bṛhadāraṇyakopaniṣat
translation: These means of liberation should be directly observed, heard, contemplated, and meditated upon; they are the self. (Brihadaranyaka Upanishad)

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: Informed by Kaṇāda, the authoritative treatise of Vaiśeṣika and by Gautama, Nyāya, and Kapila, the Sāṃkhya.

sloka: prajāvatā vacasā vahnirāsā ca huve ni ca satsīha devaiḥ | veṣi hotramuta potraṃ yajatra bodhi prayantarjanitarvasūnām ||
translation: As a father, the fire, with its flames and smoke, adorns itself as the priest for the birth, nourishment, and development of living beings.

sloka: yo adhvareṣu śaṃtama ṛtāvā hotā tamū namobhirā kṛṇudhvam | agniryadvermartāya devānsa cā bodhāti manasā yajāti ||
translation: The one who is peaceful at religious rituals and the best among those who recites the truth during such events, him you should honor with obeisance. Agni (the fire god) awakens the understanding of the divine in the mind of the one who performs the ritual with attention and focus.

sloka: abhi tvā gotamā girā jātavedo vicarṣaṇe dayumnairabhi para ṇonumaḥ jātavedase sunavā masomamarātīyato ni dahāti vedaḥ sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ agnirasmi janmanā jātavedā ghartaṃ me cakṣuramṛtaṃ ma āsana arkastridhātū rajaso vimānoajasro gharmo havirasmi nāma
translation: Approaching you, oh Gautama, with kind words, we (pl.) address the all-knowing one. May he, who is our protector and destroyer of evil, hear us. The Veda has not revealed to us the means of overcoming great difficulties, like a river unable to cross over its shores. I am born as Agni named Jātavedas, the bearer of oblations, the eye that is immortal and the warm rays of sun. I am the eternal essence that pervades all, existing in the three states of matter, devoid of qualities and full of heat. I am the offering to the fire.

sloka: hotāraṃ viśvavedasaṃ saṃ hi tvā viśa indhate | sa ā vaha puruhūta pracetaso 'gne devā~ iha dravat ||
translation: The Hotar, Vishvavedasa, invites you to perform the sacrifice; come, O Purohita Pracetas, bring Agni here; the Gods will indeed come to this spot.

sloka: jarābodha tadviviḍḍhi viśeviśe yajñiyāya stomaṃ rudrāya dṛśikam
translation: Perceive the destruction of aging (jarā) and make an offering, in the form of a hymn (stoma), to the all-seeing Rudra.

sloka: tvamagnerudro asuro maho divastvaṃ śardho mārutaṃ pṛkṣa īśiṣe
translation: You, Agni, are the mighty adversary of Asuras in the heavenly realm, and you are the sharer of sacrifices with Maruts and the ruler over the winds.

sloka: sa eva puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat sa yaḥ sa puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat ayameva saḥ yo'yamagniścīyate kāṇḍikā
translation: This very Purusha became Prajapati, the one who became Prajapati in the past is indeed this. And this very one is identified as Agni Kandika.

sloka: tataḥ yaḥ jātagarbhaḥ saḥ agniḥ asṛjyata tasmāt sarvasya sthūlaprapañcasya agram ādau sṛṣṭatvāt agnirityucyate tam agrim idānīntanā agnināmnā vyavahāraṃ kurvanti kāṇḍikā
translation: The one who was born from that [cosmic egg] is called Agni, as he was the first to be created from the dense physical world. Now, people refer to Agni by this name in their dealings. This is the explanation given by Kandika.

sloka: vāyuranilamamṛtamathedaṃ bhasmāntam śarīram | oṃ krato smara kṛtam smara krato smara kṛtam smara ||
translation: Inhale the imperishable air, O breath, and reduce this body to ashes. Om, remember the actions performed, remember, remember the actions performed, O Krato.

sloka: agne naya supathā rāye asmānviśvāni deva vayunāni vidvān | yuyodhyasmajjuhurāṇameno bhūyiṣṭhāṃ te nama uktiṃ vidhema ||
translation: O Agni, guide us on the right path for our benefit, you who know all the ways of the devas. We strive to win your favor and offer you our choicest oblations. We respectfully pay homage to you.

sloka: te'gnimabruvan jātaveda etadvijānīhi kimetadyakṣamiti tatheti ||
translation: They, having approached Agni, asked: "O seer of all creatures, discern for us what this is and who it (the creature) might be." He assented.

sloka: tadabhyadravattamabhyavadat ko'sītyagnirvā ahamasmītyabravījjātavedā vā ahamasmīti ||
translation: Upon being approached by that fire, who was asking "Who are you?" , it said "I am Agni" , and only then did the Vedas emerge .

sloka: tasmiṃstvayi kiṃ vīryamityapīdaṃ sarvaṃ daheyaṃ yadidaṃ pṛthivyāmiti ||
translation: In you, what excellence is there to discuss? Everything here on earth is burnable, indeed.

sloka: tasmai tṛṇaṃ nidadhāvetaddaheti tadupapreyāya sarvajavena tanna śaśāka dagdhum | sa tata evanivavṛte naitadaśakaṃ vijñātuṃ yadetadyakṣamiti ||
translation: To him, he should offer a blade of grass, for that is appropriate in his presence; even the fire cannot burn it. He enveloped it there (in his power) and no one could understand its size, thinking "What kind of magical being is this?"

sloka: pra te bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: I indeed tell you about that which leads to heaven and is the agni named nachiketa; understand it. Know that as my eternal abode, which grants unlimited worlds, and is established in the hidden cave.

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ ||
translation: The first created being, to whom he spoke, asked him in return, "As many desires as you have expressed, in that manner I have granted them all to you." Thus, satisfied, death approached him again.

sloka: sa etaṃ devayānaṃ panthānamāpadyāgnilokamāgacchatisa vāyulokaṃ sa ādityalokaṃ
translation: He approaches the world of fire through this celestial path, and similarly the realms of air and the sun.

sloka: yasyāgnihotramadarśamapaurṇamāsamacāturmāsyamanāgrayaṇamatithivarjitaṃ ca ahutamavaiśvadevamavidhinā hutamāsasaptamāṃ stasya lokānhinasti
translation: Of whom the new and full moon Agnihotra, the four months' Chandramas ceremony, the additional offerings to the forefathers, and the sacrifices performed with no flaw according to the rites, not omitting any of the Vasuvat offerings during the seventh part of the month, his worlds do not perish.

sloka: agnimīl̤e purohitaṃ yajñasya devamṛtvijam | hotāraṃ ratnadhātamam ||
translation:
To the fire-altar, as priest of the sacrifice, devoted,
The divine one, most revered among reward-givers, is assigned.

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: The five disciples of Shākalyaseya are a perpetual brahmachari, a householder firmly established in domestic duties, one who endures extreme weather conditions, a follower of Sāṃkhya philosophy, and a follower of the Vātsya school. These five disciples contribute to the propagation of the Shākala shakha.

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: These bright hymns, referred to as the Yajurveda's "Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā" and recognized by Yājñavalkya, are dedicated to the Ādityas.

sloka: tallakṣaṇamāha jaiminiḥ gīteṣusāmākhyā iti gīyamāneṣu mantreṣu sāmasaṃjñetyarthaḥ iti
translation: Jaimini defines the characteristics of "sāma" as it is being sung in hymns of the "gīta" genre.

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She indeed, along with āma, constitutes that which is known as sāma-tva; such is the nature of equality.

sloka: sahastravartmā sāmavedaḥ
translation: The path of the Sama Veda is a thousandfold (varied and vast).

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The duties that prompt [one to] action are the brahmana's.

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: Those who have taken up the vow in the wilderness.

sloka: kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti || mṛtyave tvā dadāmīti ||
translation: To whom should I give myself, or who should I make deathless?

sloka: svāntaḥprāṇākṣivāṇīprabhṛti ca viṣayābhāsakaṃ yasya yogād yanna prāpnoti caitadviditaṃ yadbhavennātmarūpam| indrādyā devamukhyā api kila na viduryasya śaktiṃ nigūḍhāṃ tadbuddhaṃ yena so'sau bhavati naravaro'nantasaukhyapratiṣṭhaḥ ||
translation: The one who has not attained, through yoga, the power to manifest external objects from the inner life-force and consciousness, is considered ignorant of their own self. Even the chief gods like Indra cannot comprehend this hidden potential of such a person, who becomes the ultimate source of infinite joy and bliss.

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam ||
translation: The all-pervading fire (Vaisvanara) enters the abode of a Brahmin as a revered guest. They appease it with these calming rituals and the oblation of Vaivasvata's water.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati ||
translation: What needs to be done immediately by me, what is that excellent activity?

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: The revered one, filled with delight, said to him: "I give you a special boon today, and from now on this fire will bear your name and take on many forms."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ ||
translation: The doubt that exists in people about whether this soul (preta) still exists or not after death, you must be instructed in this knowledge - among all the valuable things, this knowledge is the third best.

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte ||
translation: In which (yasmin) is this (idam) doubted (vicikitsanti) by people (mṛtyaḥ) at the time of great crisis (yatsāmparāye mahati), tell us (brūhi) that (tat); what (yaḥ) is this (ayam) hidden (gūḍham) treasure (varaḥ) that has entered (anupraviṣṭaḥ)? Therefore (tasmāt), Naciketā (naciketāḥ) chooses (vṛṇīte) not anyone else (na anyam).

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate ||
translation: It cannot be obtained either through speech or mind, nor can it be seen by the eyes. But how can it be perceived when one denies its very existence?

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti ||
translation:
Having mastered the three-fold knowledge of the fire-sacrifice, Trinačeta transcends the cycle of birth and death through the performance of the triple karma. By recognizing the divinity of Brahmajajña, one should take shelter (of this knowledge), and thus attain eternal peace.

(Note: The word sandhi in the verse refers to the grammatical fusion of words into compounds in Sanskrit. I have translated it as 'through' to convey the continuity and connection between mastering the three-fold knowledge and transcending the cycle of birth and death.)

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke ||
translation: Having understood the three-fire ritual and realizing it in practice, one who knows thus, is able to liberate themselves from death's proximity and rejoice in the celestial world, free from sorrow.

sloka: nehetārthānprasaṅgena na viruddhena karmaṇā | na vidyamāneṣvartheṣu nārtyāṃ api yatastataḥ indriyārtheṣu sarveṣu na prasajyeta kāmataḥ | atiprasaktiṃ caiteṣāṃ manasā saṃnivartayet
translation: One should not deviate to sensual pleasures in any of the senses, neither through attachment to nor rejection of actions; and one should also restrain with the mind any excessive attachment that arises towards objects.

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Even if one is capable of accepting gifts, they should avoid that situation. Indeed, a person's brahmanical power quickly subsides if they accept gifts. Such behavior is not the highest duty for people who seek to follow righteousness; the proper placement of physical, verbal, and mental discipline, along with the use of punishment, is in beings.

sloka: parasya daṇḍaṃ nodyacchetkruddho nainaṃ nipātayet | anyatra putrācchiṣyādvā śiṣṭyarthaṃ tāḍayettu tau brāhmaṇāyāvaguryaiva dvijātirvadhakāmyayā | śataṃ varṣāṇi tāmisre narake parivartate tāḍayitvā tṛṇenāpi saṃrambhānmatipūrvakam | ekaviṃśatīṃ ājātīḥ pāpayoniṣu jāyate
translation: The brahmin, getting angry at one who doesn't follow another's commands, shouldn't threaten or harm him. Instead, he should correct him for the sake of discipline, but not out of anger. If he does harm, he will be born in a foul hell for 100 years, striking even a blade of grass without just cause. A twice-born who kills with an intent to kill will be born in a sinful womb for 20 births.

sloka: ayudhyamānasyotpādya brāhmaṇasyāsṛgaṅgataḥ | duḥkhaṃ sumahadāpnoti pretyāprājñatayā naraḥ śoṇitaṃ yāvataḥ pāṃsūnsaṃgṛhṇāti mahītalāt | tāvato'bdānamutrānyaiḥ śoṇitotpādako'dyate na kadā ciddvije tasmādvidvānavaguredapi | na tāḍayettṛṇenāpi na gātrātsrāvayedasṛk
translation: While serving a brahmin, if one fails to properly initiate the service and instead carelessly picks up even a small amount of his spilled blood with earth, they will suffer immense suffering in the next life, proportionate to the amount of blood collected. Therefore, neither should one strike them with grass or anything else, nor cause their body to bleed in any way.

sloka: satyadharmāryavṛtteṣu śauce caivārametsadā | śiṣyāṃśca śiṣyāddharmeṇa vāgbāhūdarasaṃyataḥ parityajedarthakāmau yau syātāṃ dharmavarjitau | dharmaṃ cāpyasukhodarkaṃ lokasaṃkruṣṭaṃ eva ca
translation: One who is truthful, righteous, and civil in conduct, always with cleanliness, should abandon, in the pursuit of wealth and desire, worldly students along with their worldly duties, as well as those who have forsaken dharma. And one should also adopt a kind and pleasing form of dharma that is even capable of causing distress to the world.

sloka: na sīdannapi dharmeṇa mano'dharme niveśayet | adhārmikānāṃ pāpānāṃ āśu paśyanviparyayam
translation: The mind should not be settled in its own whims even for a moment, in the sphere of dharma; for one can quickly perceive the reversal of righteousness into unrighteousness.

sloka: bhadraṃ bhadraṃ iti brūyādbhadraṃ ityeva vā vadet | śuṣkavairaṃ vivādaṃ ca na kuryātkena citsaha
translation: Speak auspiciousness, saying "bhadram, bhadram" is also acceptable; but never engage in a heated argument with a dry-hearted person, even if you are capable.

sloka: yadyatparavaśaṃ karma tattadyatnena varjayet | yadyadātmavaśaṃ tu syāttattatseveta yatnataḥ yatkarma kurvato'sya syātparitoṣo'ntarātmanaḥ | tatprayatnena kurvīta viparītaṃ tu varjayet
translation: Perform that action which is under the control of others with great effort to abandon it; engage in with diligence the action that is under your own control; from doing actions, satisfaction of the inner self arises for the one who acts; do with extra effort what needs to be done, but avoid the opposite.

sloka: śraddhayeṣṭaṃ ca pūrtaṃ ca nityaṃ kuryādatandritaḥ | śraddhākṛte hyakṣaye te bhavataḥ svāgatairdhanaiḥ dānadharmaṃ niṣeveta nityaṃ aiṣṭikapaurtikam | parituṣṭena bhāvena pātraṃ āsādya śaktitaḥ
translation: With unwavering devotion, one should regularly perform this revered and fulfilling act of charity. Indeed, with a content heart, upon encountering a deserving recipient, one should carry out the duty of giving, daily practicing a form of charity that is both virtuous and saintly.

sloka: yatkiṃ cidapi dātavyaṃ yācitenānasūyayā | utpatsyate hi tatpātraṃ yattārayati sarvataḥ sarveṣāṃ eva dānānāṃ brahmadānaṃ viśiṣyate | vāryannagomahīvāsas tilakāñcanasarpiṣām
translation: Whatever is given, even in small quantities, out of compassion and without reluctance, to one who asks for it; such a gift is truly worthy of being offered to all, and above all, the gift of knowledge surpasses all others; the virtuous, as well as those who take care of cows, the land, and adorn themselves with marks on the forehead made of sacred powders or sandalwood paste, are especially deserving of such gifts.

sloka: yena yena tu bhāvena yadyaddānaṃ prayacchati | tattattenaiva bhāvena prāpnoti pratipūjitaḥ yo'rcitaṃ pratigṛhṇāti dadātyarcitaṃ eva vā | tāvubhau gacchataḥ svargaṃ narakaṃ tu viparyaye
translation: By whichever mental state one gives charity, it is through that same state of mind that they will attain worship; whether they accept, give, or even just fulfill a promise, both of them go to heaven or hell depending on the opposite.

sloka: yajño'nṛtena kṣarati tapaḥ kṣarati vismayāt | āyurviprāpavādena dānaṃ ca parikīrtanāt
translation: Sacrifice is eroded by falsehood, austerity by astonishment, lifespan by disrespecting the learned, and fame by not praising charity.

sloka: dharmarājaḥ pitṛpatiḥ samavartī paretarāṭ kṛtānto yamunābhrātā śamano yamarāḍ yamaḥ kālo daṇḍadharaḥ śrādhdadevo vaivasvatontakaḥ
translation: The upholder of righteousness, the lord of ancestors, associated with the Yamuna river, the suppressor of evildoers, the end of all things, identified as Yama, the wielder of the rod of justice, known as Vaivasvata, is also the revered deity who grants blissful rewards.

sloka: yacchati upa ramayati jivitam sarvam bhuta graman iti yamaha
translation: The one who grants life and delight to all creatures in the world, that Yama are we.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation: Like the moon that glows among the stars in the sky , at the place where the sun rises and sets , there you, Indra , should cause the nectar to flow for me.

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The timeless tale of Naciketa. [It is] spoken of as Death.

sloka: ati drava sārameyau śvānau caturakṣau śabalau sādhunā pathā athā pitṝntsuvidatrānupehi yamena ye sadhamādaṃ madanti
translation: Even the two strong and steadfast dogs of Indra, with thirst unquenchable, partake, along with other virtuous beings, of the offering presented to pitrs in the ancestral rites conducted righteously.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: The earth supports (sustains) the worlds and is itself self-controlled and virtuous.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ |
translation: The supreme duty is to set a proper example.

sloka: maitraṃ prasādhanaṃ snānaṃ dantadhāvanaṃ añjanam | pūrvāhṇa eva kurvīta devatānāṃ ca pūjanam dūrādāvasathānmūtraṃ dūrātpādāvasecanam | ucchiṣṭānnaniṣekaṃ ca dūrādeva samācaret udvartanaṃ apasnānaṃ viṇmūtre raktaṃ eva ca | śleśmaniṣṭhyūtavāntāni nādhitiṣṭhettu kāmataḥ
translation: Begin the day with friendliness, tranquility maintenance, bathing, dental hygiene, and applying collyrium. Perform worship of deities at a distance, keep urine and feces far, avoid contact during eating. Conduct oneself in such a way that leftovers, anointing, and blood are kept distant from the divine. Massage the body, cleanse again, and apply red sandalwood only if necessary for health reasons.

sloka: nānnaṃ adyādekavāsā na nagnaḥ snānaṃ ācaret | na mūtraṃ pathi kurvīta na bhasmani na govraje nāpsu mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vā ṣṭhīvanaṃ vā samutsṛjet | amedhyaliptaṃ anyadvā lohitaṃ vā viṣāṇi vā
translation: In this world, one should not eat today for the first time with a single garment; nor should they remain naked. They should not perform ablutions in unclean places, or relieve themselves on roads, in ash-heaps, or at cattle enclosures, nor should they urinate or defecate in water or onto ground that is already impure, stained with red sandalwood paste or other substances.

sloka: na pādau dhāvayetkāṃsye kadā cidapi bhājane | na bhinnabhāṇḍe bhuñjīta na bhāvapratidūṣite upānahau ca vāsaśca dhṛtaṃ anyairna dhārayet | upavītaṃ alaṅkāraṃ srajaṃ karakaṃ eva ca
translation: Never should one run with shoes on a pottery shop, nor eat from a cracked pot, or wear someone else's clothes when one's own are unwashed. Only the sacred thread, ornament, garland, and water pot are to be used.

sloka: na saṃhatābhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ kaṇḍūyedātmanaḥ śiraḥ | na spṛśeccaitaducchiṣṭo na ca snāyādvinā tataḥ nadīṣu devakhāteṣu taḍāgeṣu saraḥsu ca | snānaṃ samācarennityaṃ gartaprasravaṇeṣu ca
translation: One should not scratch oneself with both hands nor touch this impure thing, and should not bathe in rivers, sacred streams or ponds, except for ritual purposes. One should always perform daily ablutions in a pit or at the base of a tree.

sloka: adhastānnopadadhyācca na cainaṃ abhilaṅghayet | na cainaṃ pādataḥ kuryānna prāṇābādhaṃ ācaret na vārayedgāṃ dhayantīṃ na cācakṣīta kasya cit || gavāṃ ca yānaṃ pṛṣṭhena sarvathaiva vigarhitam
translation: One should not study under or support, nor should one embrace this [student]; one should not impose bodily restrictions, nor cause disturbance to his breathing; one should not forbid the milking of a cow, nor should one look at the urinating cow; all of these are improper when done towards a worthy student seated on the back of a cow.

sloka: hīnāṅgānatiriktāṅgānvidyāhīnānvayo'dhikān | rūpadraviṇahīnāṃśca jātihīnāṃśca nākṣipet abhivādayedvṛddhāṃśca dadyāccaivāsanaṃ svakam | kṛtāñjalirupāsīta gacchataḥ pṛṣṭhato'nviyāt
translation: Even though deprived of limbs or with missing limbs, one who neither despises nor neglects the ignorant, the over-knowledgeable, those lacking in physical beauty, wealth, or lineage; but instead shows them respect, offers a seat and care for the elderly, approaches them with folded hands and pays obeisance as he departs – such a person is truly worthy of veneration.

sloka: ṛtvikpurohitācāryairmātulātithisaṃśritaiḥ | bālavṛddhāturairvaidyairjñātisaṃbandhibāndhavaiḥ ākāśeśāstu vijñeyā bālavṛddhakṛśāturāḥ | bhrātā jyeṣṭhaḥ samaḥ pitrā bhāryā putraḥ svakā tanuḥ chāyā svo dāsavargaśca duhitā kṛpaṇaṃ param | tasmādetairadhikṣiptaḥ sahetāsaṃjvaraḥ sadā
translation: "In this world, it should be understood that one is constantly tormented by disease who is surrounded by priests, teachers, and relatives as friends, both young and old; one's elder brother, equal, father, spouse, son, one's own body, shadow, servants, and even one's own daughter - all being merciless."

sloka: ācāryaṃ ca pravaktāraṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum | na hiṃsyādbrāhmaṇāngāśca sarvāṃścaiva tapasvinaḥ na kurvīta vṛthāceṣṭāṃ na vāryañjalinā pibet | notsaṅge bhakṣayedbhakṣyānna jātu syātkutūhalī |
translation: Should not harm the brahmans, nor cause distress to the spiritual ascetics, nor should engage in purposeless actions. Also, should not drink water with joined palms out of curiosity or greed, and should not eat food without consideration, at any time.

sloka: nākṣairdīvyetkadā cittu svayaṃ nopānahau haret | śayanastho na bhuñjīta na pāṇisthaṃ na cāsane | ārdrapādastu bhuñjīta nārdrapādastu saṃviśet | ārdrapādastu bhuñjāno dīrghaṃ āyuravāpnuyāt |
translation: With uncovered head, never should one eat at an arbitrary time; nor lying down, nor when just having consumed water; nor should one indulge in eating while seated on a low seat or while holding the hands (palms) up. However, one may eat while seated and with wet feet; one who eats thus with wet feet will attain long life.

sloka: na snānaṃ ācaredbhuktvā nāturo na mahāniśi | na vāsobhiḥ sahājasraṃ nāvijñāte jalāśaye mattakruddhāturāṇāṃ ca na bhuñjīta kadā cana | keśakīṭāvapannaṃ ca padā spṛṣṭaṃ ca kāmataḥ
translation: One should never perform a bath after eating, nor in the middle of the night, nor in the company of women without end. One should never consume food when afflicted or angry, and especially not during eclipses or when a comet is visible. And one should avoid contact with donkeys and crow's feathers out of desire.

sloka: nekṣetodyantaṃ ādityaṃ nāstaṃ yāntaṃ kadā cana | nopasṛṣṭaṃ na vāristhaṃ na madhyaṃ nabhaso gatam na laṅghayedvatsatantrīṃ na pradhāvecca varṣati | na codake nirīkṣeta svarūpaṃ iti dhāraṇā
translation: Never can the sun's disk at rising or setting, at any time, be reached by one looking upwards, nor can it be touched by climbing, nor passed beyond by going up into the sky; never can it be wetted by water, or seen in its true form; such is the firm belief.

sloka: nādharmike vasedgrāme na vyādhibahule bhṛśam | naikaḥ prapadyetādhvānaṃ na ciraṃ parvate vaset bālātapaḥ pretadhūmo varjyaṃ bhinnaṃ tathāsanam | na chindyānnakharomāṇi dantairnotpāṭayennakhān
translation: One should not dwell in an immoral village, nor stay for long in a place overrun with disease. One should not seek shelter in a solitary spot, nor expose oneself to the heat of the sun or the smoke of a funeral pyre. One should not chew with teeth that are broken off or cause one's nails to split.

sloka: na mṛlloṣṭhaṃ ca mṛdnīyānna chindyātkarajaistṛṇam | na karma niṣphalaṃ kuryānnāyatyāṃ asukhodayam advāreṇa ca nātīyādgrāmaṃ vā veśma vāvṛtam | rātrau ca vṛkṣamūlāni dūrataḥ parivarjayet
translation: One should not in this world crush the soft grass nor cut it with a stick; one should not perform fruitless actions; one should not approach an inhabited village or house uninvited; during the night, one should keep away from tree roots situated at a distance.

sloka: acakṣurviṣayaṃ durgaṃ na prapadyeta karhi cit | na viṇmūtraṃ udīkṣeta na bāhubhyāṃ nadīṃ taret adhitiṣṭhenna keśāṃstu na bhasmāsthikapālikāḥ | na kārpāsāsthi na tuṣāndīrghaṃ āyurjijīviṣuḥ
translation: The one with eyes should never seek refuge in tough-to-conquer material possessions at any time. Nor should they look towards urine and excrement, or cross a river with arms. They shouldn't sit on a seat made of hair or skulls, nor carry a rod made of wood or iron. They shouldn't desire a long life, but instead, strive to live wisely.

sloka: keśagrahānprahārāṃśca śirasyetānvivarjayet | śiraḥsnātaśca tailena nāṅgaṃ kiṃ cidapi spṛśet devatānāṃ guro rājñaḥ snātakācāryayostathā | nākrāmetkāmataśchāyāṃ babhruṇo dīkṣitasya ca
translation: A shaven-headed one should abandon attacks on the hair; one should not touch with even a little of the body the divinities or the preceptor, nor the king. After bathing , one should bathe the head with oil . A person initiated into the vow of renunciation should not move around at will in the shade .

sloka: kṣatriyaṃ caiva sarpaṃ ca brāhmaṇaṃ ca bahuśrutam | nāvamanyeta vai bhūṣṇuḥ kṛśānapi kadā cana nātmānaṃ avamanyeta purvābhirasamṛddhibhiḥ | ā mṛtyoḥ śriyaṃ anvicchennaināṃ manyeta durlabhām
translation: A Kshatriya, a serpent, and a highly learned Brahmin should never be disrespected, nor should one of thin physique ever belittle themselves. One should always strive to attain the prosperity acquired by those in the past. Approaching (the goddess) Śriyā before death is considered rare.

sloka: dharmaṃ śanaiḥ saṃcinuyādvalmīkaṃ iva puttikāḥ | paralokasahāyārthaṃ sarvabhūtānyapīḍayan dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: One should cultivate dharma gradually, like a creeper, with the intention of benefiting otherworldly beings and not oppressing other creatures. By practicing non-violence, self-restraint, and charity, one will surely attain heaven.

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktaḥ syātprayatātmā jitendriyaḥ | japecca juhuyāccaiva nityaṃ agniṃ atandritaḥ vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: One who is engaged in auspicious acts, disciplined in mind and senses, should always worship the fire with repetition and offering, being steadfast, constantly practicing the Vedas, cleanliness, and austerity. Always remembering the natural classification of beings, one attains Brahman through repeated practice. Through constant practice of Brahman, one enjoys immeasurable and eternal bliss.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: By following this conduct, O brahmin scholar, who is versed in the Vedic scriptures and is free from all moral impurities, constantly becomes glorious in the abode of Brahman.

sloka: ye vai brāhmaṇāḥ śuśruvāṃso'nūcānāste viprāstānevaitadabhyāha
translation: Indeed, the brahmans who have listened (to the scriptures) and followed (the teachings), they, as true learned scholars, proclaim this.

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate ||
translation: The one who performs rituals such as agnihotra, new and full moon sacrifices, starting with agniṣṭoma and including other makha ceremonies, is considered the ritual priest of that person.

sloka: iha hi dravyaṃ pañcamahābhūtātmakam |
translation: Indeed, here the substance is made up of five great elements.

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī |
translation: From ether (space) comes air, from air comes fire, from fire comes water, and from water comes earth.

sloka: tatra gandhavatī pṛthivī | sā dvividhā nityā'nityā ca | nityā paramāṇurūpā | anityā kāryarūpā | punastrividhā śarīrendriyaviṣayabhedāt |
translation: There, the earth is fragrant and of two kinds, eternal and ephemeral. The eternal one is composed of atoms, while the ephemeral one has the form of an effect or result. Furthermore, the components of the body and senses are threefold.

sloka: madhukaiṭabhayormedaḥ saṃyogānmedinī smṛtā | dhāraṇācca dharā proktā pṛthvī vistārayogataḥ || mahī cāpi mahīyas |
translation: The earth, remembered as Medinī, is considered the union of madhu and Kaiṭabha; it is called dharā due to its quality of supporting . It is also known as Mahī, which is more excellent due to supporting all living beings and vegetation.

sloka: athāgamya mahārājannamaskṛtyi ca kaśyapam | pṛthavī kāśyapī jajñe sutā tasya mahātmanaḥ ||
translation: Having approached great King Kashyapa and paid obeisance to him, the earth (Prithivi) was born as the daughter of Kashyapa.

sloka: prathate vistāraṃ yātīti pṛthivī | pṛthvī sthūlatvaguṇayuktā | pṛthorduhitṛtvasvīkārādetannāma |
translation: Dawn unfurls its expanse, they say, as "Prithivi" (the Earth), endowed with the quality of being tangible and solid; this is named after being the daughter of "Parthiva" (an epithet of Brahma, meaning "relating to the earth").

sloka: duhitṛtvaṅgatā yasmāt pṛthaurdharmmavato mahī| tadānurāgayogācca pṛthivī viśrutā budhaiḥ||
translation: The earth, renowned among the wise, becomes dear (to someone) due to its quality of being a giver of wealth and daughter-like affection.

sloka: gataprāṇau tadā jātau dānavau madhukaiṭabhau | sāgaraḥ sakalo vyāptastadā vai medasā tayoḥ || medinīti tato jātaṃ nāma pṛthvyāḥ samantataḥ |
translation: Once the two asuras, Madhu and Kaitabha, had departed from their bodies, the entire ocean became full with their fat. Then, at that very moment, the earth, which is named "Prthvyah" after encompassing all around, was born.

sloka: evaṃ sarvaṃ kṛtrimaṃ ca bāhyābhyantarameva ca ||tadvināśe vināśaśca sarveṣāmeva nārada | jalabud‌budavatsarvaṃ viśvasaṃghamanityakam ||
translation: In this way, everything artificial, both external and internal, is destroyed; along with their destruction, all beings are also destroyed, O Narada; the whole creation becomes like water bubbles and transient like a village in the forest.

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |
translation: The one who sustains me from above is my father, the navel of the earth is my mother here.

sloka: viśvaṃbharā vasudhānī pratiṣṭhā hiraṇyavakṣā jagato niveśanī | vaiśvānaraṃ bibhratī bhūmiragnimindraṛṣabhā draviṇe no dadhātu ||
translation: Bearing universally nourishing Hiranyavaksha and established as Vasudha, may the earth, with the qualities of both Agni and Indra, grant us wealth.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: Whatever I swiftly scatter on the ground, may that quickly sprout. Let not my secrets be known, let not my heart's core be pierced.

sloka: na vā araṇyānirhantyanyaścennābhigacchati |
translation: Not does anyone else enter the forest except him (who is authorized). Nor does anyone else approach (the forest).

sloka: iyaṃ pṛthivī sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ madhu | asyai pṛthivyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu |
translation: This earth is the honey for all beings; to this earth, all beings are the honey.

sloka: saktuprasthena vo nāyaṃ yajñastulyo narādhipāḥ| uñchavṛttervadānyasya kurukṣetranivāsinaḥ||
translation: With offerings as the standard, this sacrifice is not equal to kings who reside in Kurukshetra and are content with meager means of livelihood.

sloka: dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre dharmajñairbahubhirvṛte| uñchavṛttirdvijaḥ kaścitkāpotirabhavattadā||
translation: In the sacred field of Kuru, known as Dharmakshetra, some brahmin who is versed in scriptures and is accompanied by many such individuals , began to cultivate a high-yielding crop at that time .

sloka: athāgacchaddvijaḥ kaścidatithirbhuñjatāṃ tadā|| te taṃ dṛṣṭvātithiṃ prāptaṃ prahṛṣṭamanaso'bhavan| te'bhivādya sukhapraśnaṃ pṛṣṭvā tamatithiṃ tadā||
translation: Then a learned person arrived as a guest, and they saw his arrival. With joyful minds, they welcomed him and then engaged in pleasant conversation with him, asking about his well-being.

sloka: ityuktā sā tataḥ prāha dharmārthau nau samau dvija|| saktuprasthacaturbhāgaṃ gṛhāṇemaṃ prasīda me| satyaṃ ratiśca dharmaśca svargaśca guṇanirjitaḥ||
translation: Having been addressed thus, the twice-born one (dvija) replied: "Duty and wealth are equal. Take this fourfold division of yours, consisting of 'saktu' (a type of grain), O please me, as well as truth, desire, and virtue - all of which lead to heaven and are characterized by good qualities."

sloka: apatyamasmi te puṃsastrāṇātputra iti smṛtaḥ| ātmā putraḥ smṛtastasmāttrāhyātmānamihātmanā||
translation: I am your child, thus remembered as 'puṃsastrāṇātputra'. The self is considered as a son, therefore one should not treat the self as separate from the 'aham' (the inner self).

sloka: tava prasādānnirvṛttā mama lokāḥ kilākṣayāḥ| putreṇa tānavāpnoti yatra gatvā na śocati|| dharmādyo hi yathā tretā vahnitretā tathaiva ca| tathaiva putrapautrāṇāṃ svargastretā kilākṣayaḥ|| pitṝnṛṇāttārayati putra ityanuśuśruma| putrapautraiśca niyataṃ sādhulokānupāśnute||
translation: Through your grace, my worlds have been made immortal. With a son, one attains that place where there is no sorrow. Just as in the age of Treta, dharma and other virtues prevailed through the sacrificial fire, similarly, for the sons and grandsons, heaven has been made immortal. We have heard that the son rescues the ancestors from their debt and partakes in the merits of the good worlds.

sloka: baṭ śrat satrā addhā itthā ṛtam iti satyasya
translation: With firm resolve and honest in this way, (one) is indeed the truthful one.

sloka: ṛtasya hi śurudhaḥ santi pūrvīrṛtasya dhītirvṛjināni hanti | ṛtasya śloko badhirā tatarda karṇā budhānaḥ śucamāna āyoḥ || ṛtasya dṛl̤hā dharuṇāni santi purūṇi candrā vapuṣe vapūṃṣi | ṛtena dīrghamiṣaṇanta pṛkṣa ṛtena gāva ṛtamāviveśuḥ || ṛtaṃ yemāna ṛtamidvanotyṛtasya śuṣmasturayā u gavyuḥ | ṛtāya pṛthvī bahule gabhīre ṛtāya dhenū parame duhāte ||
translation: The ancient ones who are established in truth, indeed, destroy the harmful elements of truth. The wise ones, with unobstructed ears, praise

sloka: indriyam indraliṃgam indradṛṣṭamindraṛṣṭamindrauṣṭamindrāttaṃ iti vā |
translation: The organ is known as Indra's mark, Indra's choice, Indra's victory, and Indra's dominion; indeed, this is said .

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra, like a thresher to the enemies of sacrificers, became distinct; just as a sharp weapon cuts through grass, so did he penetrate the rakshasa's vana.

sloka: akṛtvā pādayo: śaucaṃ diti: śayanamāviśat nidrāṃ cāhārayāmāsa tasyā: kukṣiṃ praviśya sa: vajrapāṇirmahāgarbhaṃ cicchedātha sa saptadhā sampīḍyamāno vajreṇa sa rurodātidāruṇam mā rodīriti taṃ śakra: puna:punarabhāṣata so'bhavatsaptadhā garbhastamiṃdra: kupita: puna: maruto nāma devāste babhūvurativeginaḥ | yaduktaṃ vai maghavatā tenaiva maruto'bhavan | devā ekonapañcāsat sahāyā vajrapāṇinaḥ ||
translation: Having not yet performed the ablutions of his feet, a certain one, having lain down for sleep in the daytime, was entering into a deep sleep. Then Vajrapani, the great being, split open her womb with his thunderbolt. He was being squeezed sevenfold by the thunderbolt and cried out in great pain. Indra, angered, spoke to him again and again: "Do not cry!" Then he became the embryo of seven lesser gods who were allies of Vajrapani. For it was spoken by Maghavat (Indra) himself that these Maruts would become so. The gods numbering eighty-five were helpers of Vajrapani.

sloka: yaḥ pṛthavīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatāna prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who brings tranquility to the agitated earth, stills the anger of mountains, calms down atmospheric disturbances, shines like a lightning, and showers compassion is the Indra among people.

sloka: sa vajrabhṛd dasyuhā bhīma ugraḥ sahasracetāḥ śatanītha ṛbhvā camrīṣo na śavasā pāñcajanyo marutvān no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: He, wielding the thunderbolt, strikes the Dasyus (enemies) with fierce, thousand-fold, unshakeable resolve; may he never become like an ordinary mortal, but instead be a source of strength and protection like Indra.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who, by slaying himiriṇāt, made seven rivers flow, who released the cows from valasya, discovered the fire within aśmanoḥ's interior, and united with saṃvṛk, is indeed the Indra of the people .

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: Just as Indra, by striking the mountain with his thunderbolt, revealed himself to the daughter of Sarama who was carrying a child in her womb and fearing for her relatives' safety, so too does a man, when faced with similar circumstances, reveal his lineage through his actions.

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The first among beings, the mind-born deity who adorned himself with sacrifices and whose exhale fills the two worlds, is known as Indra by people.

sloka: prajāpatirindra masṛjatānujāvaraṃ devānām | taṃ prāhiṇot | parehi | eteṣāṃ devānāmadhipatiredhīti | taṃ devā abruvan | kastvamasi | vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti | so'bravīt | kastvamasi vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti mā devā avocanniti | ko ha vai nāma prajāpatiḥ | ya evaṃ veda vidurenaṃ nāmnā | tadasmai rukmaṃ kṛtvā pratyamuñcat | tato vā indro devānāmadhipatirabhavat | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: Prajapati, the progenitor, produced for the enjoyment of the gods a son resembling himself. Him he bestowed upon (them). They said to him, "Who are you?" "I am your superior," he replied. They said, "Who indeed is this Prajapati?" He who knows this by an exclusive name, to him is offered gold and he becomes famous. Then Indra became the lord of the gods, he who knows this.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who brings tranquility to the agitated earth, calms the enraged mountains, steadies the unstable atmosphere, and showers mercy on all is hailed as Indra among people.

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the previous age of Krta, oh dear one, mountains became bird-like, moving in all directions, swift as Garuda and the wind.

sloka: na nūnamasti no śvaḥ kastad veda yadadbhutam anyasya cittamabhi saṃcareṇyamutādhītaṃ vi naśyati
translation: Surely, it does not exist now, either in a dog or in whom else could that wondrous consciousness abide, which has not been studied and is lost as soon as it is perceived?

sloka: kiṃ na indra jighāṃsasi bhrātaro marutastava tebhiḥ kalpasva sādhuyā mā naḥ samaraṇe vadhīḥ
translation: Why, O Indra, do you not long for your brother the Maruts as allies in our battle? May no harm befall us in this fight.

sloka: kiṃ no bhrātaragastya sakhā sannati manyase vidmā hi te yathā mano'smabhyaminna ditsasi
translation: What do you think of us, O friend Gastya, as a brother? Tell us the true thoughts in your mind.

sloka: araṃ karṇvantu vediṃ samagnimindhatāṃ puraḥ tatrāmṛtasya cetanaṃ yajñaṃ te tanavāvahai
translation: May the sacrificial post and the fire of the sacrifice meant for the immortal gods be made thoroughly auspicious; may the conscious ritual invigorate those who tend to it.

sloka: tavamīśiṣe vasupate vasūnāṃ tavaṃ mitrāṇāṃ mitrapate dheṣṭhaḥ indra tvaṃ marudbhiḥ saṃ vadasvādha prāśāna ṛtuthā havīṃṣi
translation: You are the greatest among the Vasus and the foremost as the friend of the Mitras. O Indra, you command the Maruts and should proclaim your acceptance of the sacrificial offerings presented during proper rituals.

sloka: svāyaṃbhuvo manuḥ pūrvaṃ paraḥ svārociṣastathā | uttamastāmasaścaiva raivataścākṣuṣastathā ||
translation: The first Manu, self-existent, was previous; the next, Para, followed by Svāroci and Uttama and Tamasa, and then Raivata.

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who first, as a thinking god, adorned the gods with a vow; from whose subtle essence both heaven and earth are pervaded; he indeed is Indra to people, endowed with manly strength.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who brings peace to the agitated earth, calms the enraged mountains, steadies the unsteady atmosphere, and shows mercy to all beings, is indeed the Indra among men.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who, by slaying the serpent Ahi-marinata, made seven rivers flow, who brought forth fire from within the stone, is indeed the Indra revered by people.

sloka: caturāśītisāhasramutsedhena prakīrtitaḥ|| praviṣṭaḥ ṣoḍaśādhastādviṃstṛtaḥ ṣoḍaśaiva tu|| ||
translation: Having been praised in a hundred thousand four times over, the one who has entered into the sixteen-fold division is indeed the sixteen-fold division itself.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Be the divine mother, be the father-deity, be the teacher-deity, be the guest-deity.

sloka: ekarātraṃ tu nivasannatithirbrāhmaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ | anityaṃ hi sthito yasmāttasmādatithirucyate | | | | na brāhmaṇasya tvatithirgṛhe rājanya ucyate | vaiśyaśūdrau sakhā caiva jñātayo gurureva ca | | | | yadi tvatithidharmeṇa kṣatriyo gṛhaṃ āvrajet | bhuktavatsu ca vipreṣu kāmaṃ taṃ api bhojayet | | | | itarānapi sakhyādīnsamprītyā gṛhaṃ āgatān | prakṛtyānnaṃ yathāśakti bhojayetsaha bhāryayā | | | |
translation: A once-a-night staying guest is remembered as a Brahmana. Indeed, one who remains temporary is called an "atithi." A Kshatriya, however, is not referred to as an "atithi" in a Brahmana's home. Vaishyas, Shudras, friends, relatives, and teachers are considered as "atithis." If a Kshatriya comes to one's house following the guest-receiving custom, then he should be fed with desire, even if it means consuming the offerings set aside for Brahmanas. Similarly, other acquaintances who come motivated by affection should also be fed as per one's ability, together with one's wife.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: Upon the arrival of a yearly visit from the priest who has completed his initiatory rites, one should honor respectfully with a gift of honey, the king's dear father-in-law and mother's brother. He should offer a seated space, water, and food according to his ability, performing each action in accordance with customary rituals.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | | | | vaiśvadeve tu nirvṛtte yadyanyo'tithirāvrajet | tasyāpyannaṃ yathāśakti pradadyānna baliṃ haret | | | |
translation: The sun sets at evening time, whether it is due or not, one should not remain without eating in the house. If another observance overtakes Vaiśvadeva, then after giving food as much as possible, one may take the remnants.

sloka: suvāsinīḥ kumārīśca rogiṇo garbhiṇīḥ striyaḥ | atithibhyo'gra evaitānbhojayedavicārayan | | | | bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | | | |
translation: The gracious girls and unmarried young women, as well as the sick and pregnant women, should first offer hospitality to the guests after due consideration. Having partaken themselves, the Brahmins, one's own servants, and others should then eat. Afterward, the couple may consume the leftovers.

sloka: na vai svayaṃ tadaśnīyādatithiṃ yanna bhojayet | dhanyaṃ yaśasyaṃ āyuṣyaṃ svargyaṃ vātithipūjanam | | | | śilānapyuñchato nityaṃ pañcāgnīnapi juhvataḥ | sarvaṃ sukṛtaṃ ādatte brāhmaṇo'narcito vasan | | | |
translation: A host neither personally partakes nor feeds the guest at the proper time, such hospitality is considered auspicious, leading to wealth, fame, long life, and heaven; even offering a stone to a brahmin every day, while performing the five daily fires rituals, brings great merit and rewards the host, if the brahmin is respectfully unadorned.

sloka: ya evaṃ vetti puruṣaṃ prakṛtiṃ ca guṇaiḥ saha | sarvathā vartamāno'pi na sa bhūyo'bhijāyate || puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅ‌kte prakṛtijānguṇān | kāraṇaṃ guṇasaṅgo'sya sadasadyonijanmasu ||
translation: One who understands the person and nature along with their qualities in this way, even while constantly involved, is not reborn. The person, inherently related to nature, enjoys the products of nature's qualities. The association with qualities becomes the cause of his manifestation in births, whether they are perishable or imperishable.

sloka: paraṃ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṃ jñānamuttamam | yajjñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṃ siddhimito gatāḥ ||
translation: I will further expound the supreme knowledge among knowledges. Having known this, all sages have attained highest accomplishment.

sloka: idaṃ jñānamupāśritya mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ | sarge'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca ||
translation: Having taken refuge in this knowledge, they have attained similarity to me; they do not take birth at creation and are not destroyed at dissolution.

sloka: mama yonirmahadbrahma tasmingarbhaṃ dadhāmyaham | saṃbhavaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ tato bhavati bhārata ||
translation: My womb is the great Brahman; there I deposit the seed. From that, all beings originate, O Bharata.

sloka: sarvayoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ saṃbhavanti yāḥ | tāsāṃ brahma mahadyonirahaṃ bījapradaḥ pitā ||
translation: In all wombs, O Kaunteya, the forms that arise, of those I am the great divine seed-giving father, the source.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The three qualities born of Prakriti (sattva, rajas, tamas) bind the imperishable self within the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: tatra sattvaṃ nirmalatvātprakāśakamanāmayam | sukhasaṅgena badhnāti jñānasaṅgena cānagha ||
translation: There, pure sattva illumines due to its own nature; it binds through the association of happiness and knowledge, O sinkss one.

sloka: rajo rāgātmakaṃ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam | tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam ||
translation: Kaunteya, recognize that desire-driven craving arises from a materialistic disposition. It is this craving that binds the embodied being through engagement in fruitive activities.

sloka: tamastvajñānajaṃ viddhi mohanaṃ sarvadehinām | pramādālasyanidrābhistannibadhnāti bhārata ||
translation: Identify that as the delusion born of ignorance, which, O Bharata, binds to negligence, heedlessness, and drowsiness, all embodied beings.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: Purity (sattva) thrives in happiness, passion (rajaḥ) in activity, O Bhārata; knowledge (jñānam), however, is obscured by ignorance (tamaḥ) when there is a mistake.

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: In the presence of either Rajas or Tamas, O Bharthari, Sattva prevails; similarly, Sattva can overcome both Rajas and Tamas.

sloka: sarvadvāreṣu dehe'sminprakāśa upajāyate | jñānaṃ yadā tadā vidyādvivṛddhaṃ sattvamityuta ||
translation: When light arises in all the body's gates, then knowledge grows and sagehood is attained.

sloka: lobhaḥ pravṛttirārambhaḥ karmaṇāmaśamaḥ spṛhā | rajasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha || aprakāśo'pravṛttiśca pramādo moha eva ca | tamasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe kurunandana ||
translation: Greed, initiation, endeavor, and restlessness in action, as well as desire – these are born from passion when it is on the rise, O best of the Bharatas. And lack of clarity, idleness, confusion, and delusion – these are born from darkness when it is on the rise, O delight of the Kurus.

sloka: nānyaṃ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṃ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati | guṇebhyaśca paraṃ vetti madbhāvaṃ so'dhigacchati ||
translation: Only when one truly sees and perceives the doer beyond all gunas (qualities), and recognizes the superior nature of my true self, does one attain me.

sloka: guṇānetānatītya trīndehī dehasamudbhavān | janmamṛtyujarāduḥkhairvimukto'mṛtamaśnute ||
translation: Surpassing these qualities, the embodied being free from birth, death, aging, and suffering attains immortality.

sloka: kairliṅgaistrīnguṇānetānatīto bhavati prabho | kimācāraḥ kathaṃ caitāṃstrīnguṇānativartate ||
translation: By which marks, O Lord, does one transcend these three qualities (sattva, rajas, tamas); what conduct should be adopted and how?

sloka: prakāśaṃ ca pravṛttiṃ ca mohameva ca pāṇḍava | na dveṣṭi saṃpravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati || udāsīnavadāsīno guṇairyo na vicālyate | guṇā vartanta ityeva yo'vatiṣṭhati neṅgate || samaduḥkhasukhaḥ svasthaḥ samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ | tulyapriyāpriyo dhīrastulyanindātmasaṃstutiḥ || mānāpamānayostulyastulyo mitrāripakṣayoḥ | sarvārambhaparityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate ||
translation: Pandava, neither does he hate the arisen nor longs for the ceased , being even-minded towards gain and loss, not shaken by qualities ; knowing that pleasures and pains are even , like earth , regarding all censure and praise, honor and dishonor as equal ; having friends and enemies that are the same , he is detached from all undertakings; such a one is said to have transcended qualities.

sloka: māṃ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate || brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca | śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca ||
