translation: The one who exclusively serves Me with unwavering devotional service, transcending these qualities, is eligible for becoming one with Brahman, for I am the foundation of Brahman, the imperishable nectar, eternal righteousness, and ultimate happiness.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣeyaḥ yonāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñāātaṃ vijñātamiti kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti
translation: How can that, which is unseen and unknown, become known as declared, undeclared, understood, or not understood? What is Your command, O Bhagavan, regarding this?

sloka: hovācānanuśiṣya vāva kila mā bhagavānabravīdanutvā'śiṣamiti
translation: "The Blessed One then said to his disciple, 'Nevertheless, let me teach you further.'"

sloka: sa hovāca tavaiva rājanmānuṣaṃ vittaṃ yāmeva kumārasyānte vācamabhāṣathāstāmeva me brūhiti sa ha kṛcchrī babhūva
translation: He, the one, replied to you, O king, regarding the human wealth of the boy, who at the end spoke those words; please tell me which one became difficult for him (to give up).

sloka: sūryaḥ dyusthānaḥ | vāyuḥ vā indraḥ vā antarikṣasthānaḥ | agniḥ pṛthivīsthānaḥ |
translation: The sun dwells in the sky; alternatively, it may be the wind that dwells in the mid-region; or Indra in the sky; or Agni on earth.

sloka: baḍavāyāḥ samudrasthitāyāḥ ghoṭakyā mukhastho'gniḥ | samudrasthāgniḥ |
translation: The fire, located at the mouth of the Ghoṭakya, situated in the sea of Baḍavā.

sloka: jaṭharasthito'gniḥ | kaukṣeye annādipācake vahnau “annarasojaṭharāgninā pacyamānoraktatāṃ pratipadyate”|
translation: The digestive fire residing in the stomach; in the sacrificial fire located in the altar of the senses, it is through the transformed essence of food that it becomes capable of producing heat and color.

sloka: agnirvaiśvānaro vahnirvītihotro dhanaṃjayaḥ | kṛpīṭayonirjvalano jātavedāstanūnapāt || barhiḥ śuṣmā kṛṣṇavartmā śociṣkeśa uṣarbudhaḥ | āśayāśo bṛhdabhānuḥ kṛśānuḥ pāvakonalaḥ || rohitāśvo vāyusakhaḥ śikhāvānāśuśukṣaṇiḥ | hiraṇyaretā hutabhugdahano havyavāhanaḥ || saptārcirdamunāḥ śukraścitrabhānurvibhāvasuḥ | śucirappittamaurvastu vāḍavo vaḍavānalaḥ || vahnerdvayorjvālakilāvarcirhetiḥ śikhā striyām | triṣu sphuliṅgognikaṇaḥ saṃtāpaḥ saṃjvaraḥ samau
translation: Agni, Vaishvanara, fire, Viti, Hotra, Dhananjaya, Kripita-yoni, Jvalana, born of Vedas, body, falling, barhi, susma, krisha, path, sociṣkeśa, usharbuda, desire, hope, bright, thin, pavaka, nala, rohita, asva, vayu, sakha, crest, having many sharp points, hiraṇya, retah, consuming oblations, carrying oblations, seven rays, shining, multicolored, Bhanur, Vibhavasu, pure, ap-pitta, maurva, tu, Vaḍava, Vaḍavānala, two fires' jvala, kilāvriti, crest, striyaam, in three, sphulinga, gnina, santapah, samjvarah, same.

sloka: haviḥ prakṣepādhikaraṇeṣu gārhapatyāhavanīyadakṣiṇāgnisabhyāvasathyaupāsanākhyeṣu ṣaḍgniṣu |
translation: In the six sacrificial fires, namely the domestic fire, the havan fire, the southern fire, the sabhartha fire, the avasathya fire, and the agnikheela fire, [one should use] oblations, articles of offering, ghee, the sacrificial butter, the fee for the priest, and the wood as directed.

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: The Creator of living beings, indeed, was alone in the beginning. Pondering how to bring forth progeny, he practiced severe austerities. Then from his mouth he milked out fire and henceforth food is obtained from fire.

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: With agni (fire) at the crown, the sun and moon as eyes, the directions as ears, and the Vedas as speech; with air as life breath, the heart as the center of the universe, the earth below, this inner self as the soul of all beings, residing in one's own self; having recognized the banyan tree and the seed of the shrub shamī - taking two pieces of wood (arani) in this way with the desire for Urvasi's boon.

sloka: ityuktvā niḥsṛto'śvatthādagnirvāraṇasūcitaḥ| praviveśa śamīgarbhamatha vahniḥ suṣupsayā||
translation: Having said "so be it," the fire, invoked near the ashvattha tree, entered the śamī tree's cavity, in accordance with the ritual injunctions, consuming it completely.

sloka: kravyādamagniṃ pra hiṇomi dūraṃ yamarājño gacchatu ripravāhaḥ | ihaivāyamitaro jātavedā devebhyo havyaṃ vahatu prajānan ||
translation: Indeed, I offer cattle sacrifice to the distant fire. Might the enemy river (of sins) depart to Yama's abode. Here, this other (fire), born from knowledge, should carry the oblation to the gods.

sloka: jātavedase sunavāma somamarātīyato nidahāti vedaḥ | sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ ||
translation: We have been reciting to Jātavedas (the fire god), the hymns from Rigveda, which banishes darkness and illuminates. That same Agni, we invoke, skillfully overcomes all our unsurmountable difficulties and never abandons us like a river in spate.

sloka: purā kalpe mahākāle prapanne lokaviśrute āyudhyetāṃ mahātmānau brahmaviṣṇū parasparam tayormānaṃ nirākartuṃ tanmadhye parameśvaraḥ niṣkalastaṃbharūpeṇa svarūpaṃ samadarśayat tataḥ svaliṃgacihnatvātstaṃbhato niṣkalaṃ śivaḥ svaliṃgaṃ darśayāmāsa jagatāṃ hitakāmyayā
translation: In a previous age, at the end of the great cycle of time, well-renowned in the world, two great souls, Brahma and Vishnu, had set out to engage in a debate to ascertain who among them was superior. At that moment, the supreme Lord Parameshvara, in his undivided form, revealed his true form to both of them. Then, as Shiva, he concealed his divine form and instead displayed his linga form for the welfare of all beings.

sloka: yatra jāto mahātejāḥ kārtikeyo agni saṃbhavaḥ
translation: Where great-in-tejas Kartikeya was born, associated with fire.

sloka: vā॒yurani̭lama॒mṛta॒mathe॒daṃ bhasmā̭nta॒ śarī̭ram | oṃ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra॒ krato॒ smara̭ kṛ॒ta sma̭ra ||
translation: Vaayu, free from aging and death, pervades this physical body as ashes; O Krato, remember, I have remembered the deeds.

sloka: pratiṣṭhāpanaṃ savidhikotsarjanamityarthaḥ |
translation: The establishment's purpose is to emit a well-directed flow (of offerings), as its meaning.

sloka: prapāstaḍāgāni ca paropakārāya na dharmāyetyevāvagamyate tathā ca darśanam dhanvanniva prapā asīti tathā sthalayodakaṃ parigṛhṇantīti ca || pra te yakṣi pra ta iyarmi manma bhuvo yathā vandyo no haveṣu | dhanvanniva prapā asi tvamagna iyakṣave pūrave pratna rājan ||
translation: Just as a river flows for the benefit of others, it is understood to be not against dharma. Similarly, one who observes like a bowman, bends (towards) water on the ground and receives it, they are worthy of being worshipped like a tree in the village. You too, O ruler, have become like that river full of water for the thirsty Iyarmi (a name of a person or entity).

sloka: bhojāyāśvaṃ saṃ mṛjantyāśuṃ bhojāyāste kanyā śumbhamānā | bhojasyedaṃ puṣkariṇīva veśma pariṣkṛtaṃ devamāneva citram ||
translation: The horse is being washed for the feast, and here a maiden adorns herself, making herself even more radiant; indeed, this dwelling of the feast-giver has been made splendid, as if it were a lotus, like a god's abode.

sloka: iṣṭāpūrtau smṛtau dharmau śrutau tau śiṣṭasaṃmatau | bhuktimuktipradaṃ pūrtamiṣṭaṃ bhogārthasādhanam ||
translation: That which is desired and fulfilled are remembered as the two forms of dharma, as approved by the noble ones. The fulfillment of desires and liberation is the complete form of the desired, while the means of obtaining worldly enjoyments.

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: Devas, humans, gandharvas, pitrs, rakshasas, and even living, immobile beings seek refuge in the water bodies.

sloka: triṣu lokeṣu sarvatra pūjanīyastaḍāgavān|| dharmasyārthasya kāmasya phalamāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ| taḍāgasukṛtaṃ deśe kṣetramekaṃ mahāśrayam||
translation: In all three worlds, everywhere, worthy of worship is the one who gives charity; according to the wise, the fruit of dharma, artha, and kama is said to be that. A single great refuge for such auspicious deeds exists in this place.

sloka: devā manuṣyagandharvāḥ pitaroragarākṣasāḥ| sthāvarāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃśrayanti jalāśayam||
translation: Devas, humans, gandharvas, ancestors, rakshasas, and even living beings that are immobile take refuge in this water body.

sloka: prāvṛṭkāle tu pānīyaṃ taḍāge yasya tiṣṭhati || ||agniṣṭomaphalaṃ tasya puruṣasya prakīrtitam |
translation: In the prescribed time, if one's hand remains steady in taking the offering, then the glory of that person is renowned as the fruit of the Agniṣṭoma ritual.

sloka: śakralokamavāpnoti taḍāgakaraṇātpathi | marau taḍāge pānīyaṃ yasya tiṣṭhati vai dvijāḥ ||vimānenārkavarṇena brahmalokaṃ sa gacchati |
translation: A worthy one reaches the realm of Indra by constructing a sacrificial altar; for the sacred waters are present where the twice-born resides; and with a splendid sun-like radiance, he attains the abode of Brahma.

sloka: atha kūpakartustatpravṛtte pānīye duṣkṛtasyārdhaṃ vinaśyati || || taḍāgakṛnnityatṛpto vāruṇaṃ lokaṃ aśnute || || jalapradaḥ sadā tṛpto bhavati || ||
translation: Once the builder of a water pit becomes engaged in wrongdoing, half of it is destroyed. Always content, the creator of a pond enjoys the world of Varuna. Ever providing water, one always becomes content.

sloka: devāyatanakārī yasya devasyāyatanaṃ karoti tasyaiva lokaṃ āpnoti || || sudhāsiktaṃ kṛtvā yaśasā virājate || ||vicitraṃ kṛtvā gandharvalokaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: The one who creates the abode of the god, indeed attains his world. Illuminating with fame by making it pure like nectar, or by creating a variegated Gandharvaloka (world of gandharvas), one gains that.

sloka: puṣpapradānena śrīmānbhavati || || anulepanapradānena kīrtimān || ||dīpapradānena cakṣuṣmānsarvatrojjvalaśca || ||annapradānena balavān || ||
translation: By offering flowers, one becomes prosperous; by applying sandalwood paste, one gains fame; by lighting a lamp, one's vision brightens and illuminates all around; by giving food, one becomes strong.

sloka: devanirmālyāpanayanātgodānaphalaṃ āpnoti || ||devagṛhamārjanāttadupalepanātbrāhmaṇocchiṣṭamārjanātpādaśaucādakalyaparicaraṇācca || || kūpārāmataḍāgeṣu devatāyataneṣu ca | punaḥ saṃskārakartā ca labhate maulikaṃ phalam || ||
translation: By offering divine garlands and making charitable donations, one gains the fruit of those actions. Additionally, by cleaning the deity's dwelling, applying sandalwood paste, purifying Brahmins' leftovers, maintaining foot cleanliness, and regularly serving deities in sacred shrines and water bodies, one acquires the results of being a consecrator or purifier.

sloka: dvārībandhiṣu kartavyamutsargaṃ gopradānikam | gosahasraṃ śubhaṃ deyaṃ mahīṃ hemañca dakṣiṇām ||
translation: The duty concerning door-locks is to donate a cow and its calf, along with other pure gifts such as gold and land.

sloka: sadā jalaṃ pavitraṃ syādapavitramasaṃskṛtam | kuśāgreṇāpi rājendra spraṣṭagyamasaṃskṛtam || vāpīkūpataḍāgadau yajjalaṃ syādasaṃskṛtam | apeyaṃ tadbhavetsarve pītvā cāndrāyaṇaṃ caret ||
translation: May water always be pure and impure when touched by the tip of kusa grass, or in a well, tank, or pond. After drinking such water, one should perform the lunar observance (andrāyaṇa).

sloka: puṣpaiḥ suragaṇān vṛkṣāḥ phalaiścāpi tathā pitṝn | chāyayā cātithiṃ tāta pūjayanti mahīruhaḥ ||
translation: Trees honor guests with shade and flowers, as do the companies of gods with fruits and flowers, and fathers do so with help and support.

sloka: vṛkṣāropayiturvṛkṣāḥ paraloke putrā bhavanti || ||vṛkṣaprado vṛkṣaprasūnairdevānprīṇayati || ||phalaiścātithīn || ||chāyayā cābhyāgatān || || deve varṣatyudakena pitṝn || || setukṛtsvargaṃ āpnoti || ||
translation: The one who nurtures trees becomes, in another world, a father to their offspring, the trees. By providing them with shade and receiving guests, he pleases the gods with flowers and offerings, and is cleansed by the rains from above. Thus, becoming a bridge to heaven, he attains it.

sloka: sthāvarāṇāṃ ca bhūtānāṃ jātayaḥ ṣaṭ prakīrtitāḥ | vṛkṣagulmalatāvallyastvaksārāstṛṇajātayaḥ||
translation: The six types of births that are designated among stationary beings - those of trees, shrubs, creepers, vines, and grasses.

sloka: athodyāne pravakṣyāmi praśastānpādapāndvija | ariṣṭāśokapunnāgaśirīṣāmrapriyaṅgavaḥ || || panasāśokadacalījambūlakucadāḍimāḥ | māṅgalyāḥ pūrvamārāme ropaṇīyā gṛheṣu vā || || śālmaliṃ kovidāraṃ ca varjayitvā vibhītakam || || asanaṃ devadāruṃ ca palāśaṃ puṣkaraṃ tathā | na vivarjyastathā kaściddevodyāneṣu jānatā || ||
translation: In my discourse about gardens, I will mention the excellent tree species that are praiseworthy:

sloka: āmrāśca siktāḥ pitaraśca prīṇitāḥ ||
translation: The mangoes have been eaten and the fathers have been pleased.

sloka: naiyagrodha audumbara āśvatthaḥ plākṣa itīdhmo bhavatyete vai gandharvāpsarasāṃ gṛhāḥ ||
translation: The mansion of Gandharvas and Apsaras is designated as Nyagrodha, Audumbara, Ashvattha, and Plaksha, according to popular belief.

sloka: evameṣu purāṇeṣu taḍāga vidhirucyate|| || kūpavāpīṣu sarvāsu tathā puṣkariṇīṣu ca| eṣa eva vidhirdṛṣṭaḥ pratiṣṭhāsu tathaiva ca|| || mantratastu viśeṣaḥ syāt prasādodyānabhūmiṣu|
translation: In ancient traditions, the creation of reservoirs is praised, and so are wells and ponds. Similarly, lotus ponds are also mentioned. This very method is observed in establishing bases as well. However, there is a special distinction when it comes to mantras in gardens of joy and prosperity.

sloka: vṛkṣāgrātpatitasyāpi ārohātpatitasya ca| maraṇe vāsthibhaṅge vā kartā pāpairna lipyate ||||
translation: Even the climber who ascends or descends from a tree, or the person who falls and becomes injured or dies due to it, is tainted by sin.

sloka: jayaṃtyāḥ somavṛkṣasya tathā somavaṭasya ca | panasasya kadaṃbasya niṃbasya dvijasattamāḥ || || pāṭalā kanakasyaiva śālmalīniṃbakasya ca| biṃbāśokavaṭasyaiva pratiṣṭhāṃ naiva kārayet || || bhadrakasya śamīkoṇacaṃḍātakabakasya ca | khadirasyaiva kartavyaṃ karṇavedhaṃ na kārayet ||||
translation: The most excellent of the twice-born should not have the root of a somavṛkṣa or a somavaṭ tree dug up, nor that of a panasasya or kadambasya nimba tree. They should not establish the base of a pāṭalā or a golden śālmalī or nimbakasya bimba aśoka tree, but they should have the bark of a bhadraka, śamī, koṇacaṇḍātaka or khadira tree removed.

sloka: kārayitvā dṛḍhastaṃbhaṃ śubhapakveṣṭakāmayam | śubhaṃ kamaṭhapṛṣṭhābhaṃ bhābhāsitadigaṃtaram || pratiśraye tu vistīrṇe kārite sajale ghane || || dīnānāthajalārthāya kṛtaṃ kiṃ na kṛtaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Having established a firm support, desiring to benefit all, with auspiciousness as its core and adorned with mature virtues, shining from the back and pervading all directions, if one takes refuge in it when expanded and soaked in the rains, then how can it not be considered as having been done for the sake of providing sustenance to the helpless and needy through water?

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established conclusion regarding the acceptance of the authority in a treatise's domain.

sloka: saḥ caturvidhaḥ sarvatantrapratitantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthityarthāntarabhāvāt|| {tantrabhedauddeśasūtram}
translation: Based on the given Sanskrit verse and its word-split, the enhanced translation is: "He, being established in the inner meaning of all that is dependent and independent (tantra and atantra), is of four kinds." The term 'caturvidhaḥ' means 'of four kinds', 'sarvatantrapratitantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthityarthāntarabhāvāt' refers to the state of being established in the inner meaning of all that is dependent (pratitanta) and independent (tantra), and 'saḥ' refers to 'he'. The use of 'dependent and independent' here could be referring to objects or concepts that are either conditioned by causes and conditions (dependent) or unconditioned (independent). Therefore, the translation should reflect this nuanced meaning.

sloka: tantrārthasaṃsthitiḥ tantrasaṃsthitiḥ tantramitaretarābhisaṃbaddhasyārthasamūhasyopadeśaḥ śāstram | adhikaraṇānuṣaṅārthā saṃsthitiradhikaraṇasaṃsthitiḥ abhyupagamasaṃsthitiranavadhāritārthaparigrahaḥ tadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇāyābhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ | tantrabhedāttu khalu sa caturvidhaḥ |
translation: The establishment of tantra's meaning is the exposition of the interconnection of various aspects of tantra; the scripture provides instructions regarding this. The proper arrangement of context and the correct understanding of its meaning is the established order of a topic; similarly, acceptance of a position for the sake of inquiry into a specific aspect of tantra is also considered as an established order. Indeed, there are four types of divisions in tantra.

sloka: sarvatantrāviruddhaḥ tantre adhikṛtaḥ arthaḥ sarvatantrasiddhāntaḥ|| {sarvatantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The meaning established in all treatises that is not contrary to any of the scriptures and has been appointed as such.

sloka: yathā dhrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi gandhādaya indriyārthāḥ pṛthivyādī bhūtāni pramāṇairarthasya grahaṇamiti|
translation: Like the perception of sensory objects such as smell through the senses led by the nose, and the apprehension of objects such as earth and others through appropriate means of knowledge.

sloka: samānatantrāsiddhaḥ paratantrāsiddhaḥ pratitantrasiddhāntaḥ||{pratitantrasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: Equal principles are not established by external authority; they are established by self-realization.

sloka: yatsiddhau anyaprakaraṇasiddhiḥ saḥ adhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ|| {adhikaraṇasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: That which is the criterion of success in any other context is the established principle of the locus.

sloka: yasyārthasya sidhdāvanye'rthā yadadhiṣṭhānāḥ so'dhikaraṇasiddhāntaḥ | yathā dehendriyavyatirikte jñātā darśanasparśanābhyāmekārthagrahaṇādibhiḥ| atrānuṣaṅgiṇo'rthā indriyanānātvaṃ niyataviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi svaviṣayagrahaṇaliṅgāni jñāturjñānasādhanāni gandhādiguṇavyatiriktāṃ dravyaṃ guṇādhikaraṇamaniyataviṣayāścetanā iti pūrvārthasidhdāvete'rthāḥ sidhyanti na tairvinā so 'rthaḥ saṃbhavatīti|
translation: The established meaning of a thing is achieved when its dependencies are fulfilled; just as the knowledge of an object is attained by the senses of perception like sight and touch. Here, associated meanings are the sense organs, distinct from the self, having specific objects as their domain; they serve as means of knowing the dravya (substance) and guṇas (qualities) that exist independently. Therefore, the meaning cannot arise without these prerequisites.

sloka: aparīkṣitābhyupagamāttadviśeṣaparīkṣaṇaṃ abhyupagamasiddhāntaḥ|| {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: Assessment of the unassessed should be based on examination of its specifics, according to established acceptance.

sloka: adhaḥ svidāsīt upari svidāsīt bhīriva vindantī |
translation: Has ventured below or might have ascended above, the fearless one finds (the treasure).

sloka: pravṛttaṃ ca nivṛttaṃ ca dvividhaṃ karma vaidikam āvartate pravṛttena nivṛttenāśnute'mṛtam
translation: The Vedic action is of two kinds: engaged in and abstained from. Consuming the nectar-like reward comes from engaging in and abandoning it.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: The offerings for the agnihotra and other rituals, consisting of harmful physical objects, are meant for appeasement. The new moon and full moon sacrifices, as well as the Caturmasya animal sacrifice, are all included in what is prescribed and performed. These, along with the places of enjoyment such as the heavenly gardens and ponds, are considered symbols of sensual pleasure and sustenance.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: My illusion has been destroyed, and through your grace, I have regained my memory. Firmly established am I now, with doubts dispelled; I will carry out your command.

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Renunciation and Karma-yoga, both lead to liberation; however, of the two, Karma-yoga is superior due to the complete renunciation of actions.

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: Among the ascetics and those devoted to self-discipline, a yogi is considered superior even to one who is wise. A yogi is also deemed superior to those who are engaged in fruitive activities. Therefore, Arjuna, strive to become a yogi.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The supreme being, O Partha, is attainable through devotion and nowhere else. All beings and elements within them are established in him, and it is he who pervades all this.

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, always perform your duty with dedication, for a person who is unattached to the outcome attains the supreme.

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: One who performs actions, having placed them in Brahman, and abandoned attachment, is not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf in water.

sloka: oṃ brahmavādino vadanti | kiṃ kāraṇaṃ brahma kutaḥ sma jātā jīvāma kena kva ca sampratiṣṭhā | adhiṣṭhitāḥ kena sukhetareṣu vartāmahe brahmavido vyavasthām || ||
translation: The knowers of Brahman declare "Om is Brahman." What is the reason and source of Brahman? How have we been living, and where have we been established in happiness until now? By what power are we supported in these [different] abodes? Knowers of Brahman describe this arrangement.

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: By understanding whom, O blessed one, everything in this world becomes understood.

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe | mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca | sthitaṃ ca yacca | sacca tyaṃ ca || bṛha ||
translation: Indeed, there are two forms of Brahman: the physical and the formless; the mortal and the immortal; the stationary and the mobile; the real and the absolute.

sloka: ātmetyevopāsītātra hyete sarva ekaṃ bhavanti |
translation: Considering them as Atman, they all become one here.

sloka: saṃyuktametatkṣaramakṣaraṃ ca vyaktāvyaktaṃ bharate viśvamīśaḥ | anīśaścātmā badhyate bhoktṛbhāvājjñātvā devaṃ mucyate sarvapāśaiḥ || ||
translation: The Lord of the universe, who pervades both the manifest and unmanifest, the eternal and non-eternal, frees oneself from bondage when one realizes the divine being as the enjoyer and the enjoyed.

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: I am an eternal fragment myself, in this world of living beings; the mind and the six senses are what the natural existence pulls.

sloka: na puṇyapāpe mama nāsti nāśo na janma dehendriyabuddhirasti | na bhūmirāpo na ca vahnirasti na cānilo me'sti na cāmbaraṃ ca || || evaṃ viditvā paramātmarūpaṃ guhāśayaṃ niṣkalamadvitīyam | samastasākṣiṃ sadasadvihīnaṃ prayāti śuddhaṃ paramātmarūpam || ||
translation: I have no destruction of merits and demerits, no disappearance of birth, body, senses, or intellect. There is no earth, water, fire, air, or ether in me. Understanding the form of the supreme self as indivisible, hidden, and without a second; omniscient, devoid of existence and non-existence, one attains the pure form of the paramatma.

sloka: manorhairaṇyagarbhasya ye marīcyādayaḥ sutāḥ | teṣāṃ ṛṣīṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ putrāḥ pitṛgaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ ṛṣibhyaḥ pitaro jātāḥ pitṛbhyo devamānavāḥ | devebhyastu jagatsarvaṃ caraṃ sthāṇvanupūrvaśaḥ
translation: The offspring of the sages starting from Marici, who are known as the sons of all these revered rishis, are remembered as the ancestors of the gods. Similarly, humans have originated from their ancestors; indeed, everything animate and inanimate in this universe has initially emerged from them.

sloka: vasūnvadanti tu pitṝnrudrāṃścaiva pitāmahān | prapitāmahāṃstathādityānśrutireṣā sanātanī
translation: The Vasus indeed proclaim the ancestors, Rudras as well, and even the great-grandsires. So too have we heard that this Sanatani (eternal) tradition concerns the Adityas.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The one named Soma among the brahmins, the sacrificial offering-bearer among the kshatriyas, the ghee-offering among the vaishyas, and the unctuous offering among the shudras - the sons of the wise Kave, who are endowed with abundant offerings, are named Havishmantha; the sons of Angirasa; the sons of Pulastya and Vasiṣṭha are named Ajyapaa.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Therefore, it nourishes the waters, therefore it enriches the earth with its moisture, therefore the sky and the atmosphere are increased by it, therefore the plant life is nourished by it.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: during the lunar mansion of Krittika, Rohini, Mriga Shirisham (Orion), Phalguni, and the Prosthapada of Uttara and Vishaakha.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati || gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: Among the constellations Kritika, a brahmin who has studied becomes the chief source of spiritual knowledge; similarly, he becomes the domestic fire for his household.

sloka: kṛttikāsvagnī ādadhīta | etyāhuretadhda vā agnernakṣatraṃ
translation: The fire constellation (Agnier Nakshatram), it is said, was established among the Krittikas.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are spring, summer, and the rains; those are the divine rituals (or time divisions). Autumn, late autumn, and cool weather – those are the fatherly ones.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: During the entire night, or even a part of it, who vigilantly stays awake?

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: This, the sacrificial form of fire, is churned from the womb of a śamī tree; indeed it is.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: With these three syllables "bhūr, bhuvaḥ, iti," the householder establishes (performs) the Gārhapatya sacrifice, preventing harm from coming to him in two ways.

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: I will now offer with fire, together with oblations and sacrificial fees, the sacred post that has grown from the seed of a śamī tree, like an ashvattha tree, which causes doubt and wonder.

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: Again appointed for consecration, if one who has previously promised the throne or enjoyment of desire neglects to perform the ritual of kindling the sacred fire for three nights and then suddenly abandons it, or in the middle of the rainy season, he should establish an offering made from ripe paddy, barley, and arka leaves in the gārhapatya fire. This is how one should fulfill their duties to the deserving.

sloka: viṣṇuranyā devatāsītso'bravīdviṣṇavehīdamā hariṣyāvo yenāyamidamiti sa viṣṇustredhātmānaṃ vi nyadhatta pṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamantarikṣe tṛtīyaṃ divi tṛtīyamabhiparyāvartāddhyabibhedyatpṛthivyāṃ tṛtīyamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravītanmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: Viṣnu, being distinct from other deities, said, "Who among you can lift this (objects) that I have placed on earth, sky, and the highest firmament?" When Indra, holder of the thunderbolt, was established by that very Viṣnu, he proclaimed, "Give me this (objects) or else what is this (that I have to do)?"

sloka: mayi vīryaṃ tatte pra dāsyāmīti tadasmai prāyacchattatpratyagṛhṇādadhā meti tadviṣṇaveti prāyacchattadviṣṇuḥ pratyagṛhṇādasmāsvindra indriyaṃ dadhātviti yadantarikṣe tṛtī̭yamāsīttenendro vajramudayacchadviṣṇvanusthitaḥ so'bravīnmā me pra hārasti vā idaṃ
translation: He declares, "I will give all my power to him," and offers it to him. He, Viṣṇu, accepts it from him. Viṣnu then says, "Give me your divine sensorium." When this is offered, a thunderbolt appears in the sky. Indra, having established himself therein, declares, "What do you want from me? Is it this or that?"

sloka: saptadhā tu kṛte garbhe ditiḥ parama duḥkhitā sahasrākṣam durādharṣam vākyam sa anunayā abravīt
translation: In deep distress, the second wife Diti spoke these words to the thousand-eyed and invincible one, after her conception was marked by seven distinct features.

sloka: vāta skaṃdhā ime sapta carantu divi putraka mārutā iti vikhyātā divyarūpā mama ātmajāḥ
translation: Let these seven identified as the "mārutā" and resembling the wind (vāta) roam the skies, they are my divine-formed offspring, O son.

sloka: yadacarastanvā vāvṛdhāno balānīndra prabruvāṇo janeṣu | māyetsā te yāni yuddhānyāhurnādya śatruṃ nanu purā vivitse ||
translation: Having grown in strength, the one who speaks boldly among people, proclaiming his power and authority; do not let such a rival escape now, whom you could have defeated before.

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: In a hundred (situations), a warrior is born, among thousands, a scholar; a speaker, possibly, every hundred times, or maybe not; a giver, becomes (only) rarely.

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: That which exceeds the necessary property for family maintenance, if given away as charity, will not result in acquiring fault.

sloka: śaktaḥ parajane dātā svajane duḥkhajīvini | madhvāpāto viṣāsvādaḥ sa dharmapratirūpakaḥ | |
translation: A giver to strangers, miserly to one's own, living off others' misery, tasting alcohol and poison - such a person embodies the opposite of dharma.

sloka: tatra guṇānsamīkṣya yathāśakti deyam
translation: There, considering the qualities as per one's ability to give.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: The purpose of begging for one's livelihood should be determined by sense pleasure's object, not by the senses themselves. One should not become attached to it. Also, as a follower of dharma, one should arrange for offerings at holy sites, and should also engage in proper acquisition and protection of resources necessary for religious duties.

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: Where rulers lead such that there is no fear at holy sites, and where people are gathered.

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: He lays down (pratipadyati) gifts (dānāni) that are given at the proper time and place, in a clean state, completely received, and by a proper giver.

sloka: yadyasya vihitaṃ carma yat sūtraṃ yā ca mekhalā | yo daṇḍo yacca vasanaṃ tattadasya vrateṣvapi || sevetemāṃstu niyamān brahmacārī gurau vasan | sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ tapovṛddhyarthamātmanaḥ ||
translation: If one who is engaged in brahmacarya (celibate studenthood) is to follow the rules, then they should wear the prescribed garment, belt, and hold the staff, and don the sacred thread. They should also keep their senses in check while residing with the guru, for the purpose of increasing their spiritual growth through tapas (asceticism).

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Beginning each day, one should always pay respects after making offerings of alms, carrying a staff, wearing an ascetic's garland, and being adorned with a belt.

sloka: brahma vedastadadhyayanārthaṃ yadvrataṃ tadapi brahmataccaratīti brahmacārī |
translation: A student of Brahmana conduct (brahmacārī) should study the Vedas for the purpose of realizing Brahman (brahma). This is their vow (vratam); such is their behavior (carati).

sloka: mekhalājinavāsāṃsi jaṭādaṇḍakamaṇḍalūn | bibhṛyādupavītaṃ ca darbhapāṇiryathoditam || ||
translation: Wearing a girdle, covered in animal hide, adorned with matted hair and a staff, modestly draped in a sacred thread and holding a handful of darbha grass, as described.

sloka: daṇḍājinopavītāni mekhalāṃ caiva dhārayet |
translation: He should wear the sacred threads (upavita), animal hide (ajina) and belt (mekhala) along with the staff (danda).

sloka: muñjānāṃ valkalānāntu kramānmaujjyāḥ prakīrtitāḥ || mārgavaiyādhravāstāni carmāṇi vratacāriṇāṃ | parṇapippalavilvānāṃ kramāddaṇḍāḥ prakīrtitāḥ ||
translation: Of Kusa grass and bark cloth, sequentially worn, are known as "mujjyah"; for ascetics observing vows, the clothes are called "margavaiya" and the staffs are called "danda," while those made from leaves of trees are renowned.

sloka: kārṣṇarauravabāstāni carmāṇi brahmacāriṇaḥ | vasīrannānupūrvyeṇa śāṇakṣaumāvikāni ca | | | |
translation: Wearing deerskin and bark garments, the brahmacharis (celibate students) should put on, in proper sequence, the sacred threads made of thread, muñja grass, and darbha grass.

sloka: aiṇeyamajinamuttarīyaṃ brāhmaṇasya rauravaṃ rājanyasya ājaṃ gavyaṃ vā vaiśyasya sarveṣāṃ vā gavyamasati pradhānatvāt
translation: The dung of a cow is to be regarded as the foremost among all (kinds of) excreta, whether it belongs to a Brahmin's or a king's or even a commoner's; such is its preeminent status.

sloka: avakrāḥ satvacaḥ sarve nāvipluṣṭāstu daṇḍakāḥ ||
translation: All beings, straightforward in nature, have not been shaken; only the daṇḍakāḥ are an exception.

sloka: kauśaṃ sautraṃ vā tristrivṛd yajñopavītam || ā nābheḥ ||
translation: It could be the sacred thread made of Kauśa or Sautra material, or perhaps one woven three times , but it should definitely be placed near the navel .

sloka: kārpāsaṃ upavītaṃ syādviprasyordhvavṛtaṃ trivṛt | śaṇasūtramayaṃ rājño vaiśyasyāvikasautrikam | | | | vāsopavīte kārpāsakṣaumorṇānāṃ yathākramaṃ |
translation: The sacred thread made of cotton should be worn by the brahmin , with its upper end extending upwards, in three rounds . The merchant class should wear a similar thread made of silk threads, following the proper sequence of kshauma and urna fibers.

sloka: mekhalāṃ ajinaṃ daṇḍaṃ upavītaṃ kamaṇḍalum | apsu prāsya vinaṣṭāni gṛhṇītānyāni mantravat | | | |
translation: Belt, deer skin, staff, sacred thread, water pot – after releasing these, now gone, one should again take them up, as if they were mantras.

sloka: upanīya guruḥ śiṣyaṃ sikṣayecchaucamāditaḥ | ācāramagnikāryaṃ ca sandhyopāsanameva ca ||
translation: Having initiated (upanīya), the teacher should diligently (āditaḥ) instruct the student, inspiring him towards learning and cleanliness. Additionally, he must teach proper conduct, tending to fire and performing sandhyopasana.

sloka: snānaṃ abdaivatairmantrairmārjanaṃ prāṇasaṃyamaḥ | sūryasya cāpyupasthānaṃ gāyatryāḥ pratyahaṃ japaḥ | | | |
translation: Bathing with sacred hymns, purification of the life-force, paying respect to the sun, and daily recitation of the Gayatri mantra.

sloka: nityaṃ snātvā śuciḥ kuryāddevarṣipitṛtarpaṇam | devatābhyarcanaṃ caiva samidādhānaṃ eva ca | | | |
translation: Always bathe and, being pure, one should offer obligations to deities, Ṛṣis, and ancestors; (and) also perform worship of deities and kindling of the fire.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātarupāsīta gurvagnyarkasurottamān | ubhe sandhye ca yatavāgjapan brahma samāhitaḥ || ||
translation: At dawn and dusk, one should meditatively worship the guru, the fire, the sun, and the best of the gods. A dedicated recitation of Brahman should be performed at both sandhyas.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaśca juhuyānnāmedhyaṃ vyastahastakaṃ | dūrādāhṛtya samidhaḥ sannidadhyādvihāyasi | sāyaṃḥ prātaśca juhuyāttābhiragniṃ atandritaḥ | | | |
translation: In the evening and in the morning, one should offer oblations with a focused mind, having collected firewood from a distance. Unwavering, one should kindle the sacred fire at both times.

sloka: chandāṃsyadhīyīta gurorāhūtaścetsuyantritaḥ | upakrame'vasāne ca caraṇau śirasā namet || ||
translation: On beginning and end, one should mindfully bow the head and touch the feet of the teacher, having been called upon and guided by him, as well as while studying the hymns.

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: Should be constantly guided by the guru or independently studied? One should make effort in study and serving the teacher's interests.

sloka: yajñānāṃ tapasāṃ caiva śubhānāṃ caiva karmaṇām | veda eva dvijātīnāṃ niḥśreyasakaraḥ paraḥ | | | |
translation: The performance of sacrifices, austerities, and other auspicious actions is certainly the supreme means of welfare for twice-born individuals.

sloka: vedaṃ eva sadābhyasyettapastapsyandvijottamaḥ | vedābhyāso hi viprasya tapaḥ paraṃ ihocyate | | | |
translation: The highest austerity for a brahmin is the constant recitation of the Vedas; such a learned person who diligently practices it becomes superior.

sloka: madhunā payasā caiva sa devāṃstarpayeddvijaḥ | pitṝnmadhughṛtābhyāṃ ca ṛco'dhīte ca yo'nvaham | | | | yajūṃṣi śaktito'dhīte yo'nvahaṃ sa ghṛtāmṛtaiḥ | prīṇāti devānājyena madhunā ca pitṝṃstathā | | | | sa tu somaghṛtairdevāṃstarpayedyo'nvahaṃ paṭhet | sāmāni tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | | medasā tarpayeddevānatharvāṅgirasaḥ paṭhan | pitṝṃśca madhusarpirbhyāṃ anvahaṃ śaktito dvijaḥ | | | | vākovākyaṃ purāṇaṃ ca nārāśaṃsīśca gāthikāḥ | itihāsāṃstathā vidyāḥ śaktyādhīte hi yo'nvaham | | | | māṃsakṣīraudanamadhu tarpaṇaṃ sa divaukasām | karoti tṛptiṃ kuryācca pitṝṇāṃ madhusarpiṣā | | | |
translation: A twice-born (dvija) shall appease the gods with madhu and payas, as well as with ghee offered in the rituals of ṛcō'dhīte, yajūṃṣi, and others, while reciting mantras. With ghṛtāmṛta, one can please the gods, as well as the ancestors using madhu. One who is capable should offer soma-ghee to the gods during these rituals. The ṝc chants bring satisfaction to the ancestors when offered with madhusarpiṣa. With the fat of sacrifices, one can appease and satisfy both the devas and pitṛs. One who is capable should recite the ancient Vedic texts (vākovākya purāṇam), nārāśaṃsī gāthikāḥ, itihāsān, and vidyāḥ, while performing tarpana with māṃsa, kṣīra, udana, and madhusarpiṣa for the devas.

sloka: yaṃ yaṃ kratuṃ adhīte ca tasya tasyāpnuyātphalam | | | |
translation: Whichever ritual one studies diligently, they will surely attain its fruit.

sloka: trirvittapūrṇapṛthivī dānasya phalaṃ aśnute | tapasaśca parasyeha nityaṃ svādhyāyavāndvijaḥ | | | |
translation: By giving generously to a complete and filled earth three times, a dvija partakes in the fruit of charity. And, always performing self-study, he also enjoys the results of austerity for the benefit of others.

sloka: bhaikṣeṇa vartayennityaṃ naikānnādī bhavedvratī | bhaikṣeṇa vratino vṛttirupavāsasamā smṛtā | | | |
translation: The practice of alms-collecting should be carried out continuously; it should never be devoid of any kind of food. For ascetics, this mode of livelihood is considered equivalent to a fast.

sloka: brāhmaṇeṣu caredbhaikṣaṃ anindyeṣvātmavṛttaye | | | |
translation: Offer beggarly alms to brahmins, being unobjectionable and focusing on self-conduct.

sloka: prathamaṃ tatra bhhikṣeta yatra bhikṣā dhruvaṃ bhavet |
translation: In that place, he should beg first where a certain alms is assured.

sloka: mātaraṃ vā svasāraṃ vā māturvā bhaginīṃ nijām | bhikṣeta bhikṣāṃ prathamaṃ yā cainaṃ nāvamānayet | | | |
translation: Seeking alms from either one's mother or sister should be the first preference; one must not despise such a relative who approaches him for alms.

sloka: sāyaṃ prātaścaredbhaikṣaṃ gurave tannivedayet | bhuñjīta yadyanujñāto no cedupavasetkvacit || ||
translation: In the morning and evening, one should beg for alms and offer it to the teacher, if allowed, one may consume (the food); otherwise, let not even a morsel be eaten.

sloka: vratavaddevadaivatye pitrye karmaṇyatha rṣivat | kāmaṃ abhyarthito'śnīyādvrataṃ asya na lupyate | | | | brāhmaṇasyaiva karmaitadupadiṣṭaṃ manīṣibhiḥ | rājanyavaiśyayostvevaṃ naitatkarma vidhīyate | | | |
translation: Like the behavior of sages towards their duties to their forefathers, one should respectfully follow their own vow as if it were their only deity, and it should not be broken. This duty is specifically instructed for a brāhmaṇa by wise men, and it is not ordained for a rājanya or a vaiśya in this way.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: For those who are praiseworthy but lack Vedic studies, let them practice celibacy and consume only fruits while away from home. They should not beg for alms in the guru's family or among relatives, but if necessary, they can do so in other places. If all means of sustenance fail, they may beg from others, but only as a last resort. Alternatively, they may engage in all occupations outside of the village while adhering to the previously mentioned rules and refraining from harsh speech.

sloka: akṛtvā bhaikṣacaraṇaṃ asamidhya ca pāvakam | anāturaḥ saptarātraṃ avakīrṇivrataṃ caret | | | |
translation: Having not practiced begging and with a mind indifferent, one should spend seven nights near a fire without breaking their vow.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: Constantly observing the brahmacarya vow and disciplined, always engaged in undertaking the initiation ceremony, under control, constantly attentive to the guru's guidance, never deviating from the firm commitment to the vow - such is the duty that should always be performed.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: A virtuous, self-restrained, and faithful man of good character and skilled in his actions, engages in activities with women among the defeated and conquered, as long as it is necessary.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Devoting oneself to a single teacher, Yudhishthira, should carefully and diligently study all the Vedas, discarding the impurities of ignorance.

sloka: guruṃ caivāpyupāsīta svādhyāyārthaṃ samāhitaḥ | | | |
translation: One should also revere the guru, being fully focused, for the purpose of self-study.

sloka: brahmacārī gurukule vasan dānto gurorhitam | ācaran dāsavannīco gurau sudṛḍhasauhṛdaḥ || || āhūtaścāpyadhīyīta labdhaṃ cāsmai nivedayet | hitaṃ tasyācarennityaṃ manovākkāyakarmabhiḥ | | | |
translation: Residing in the Guru's abode as a brahmacārī, calm and obedient to the Guru's commands, acting according to his instructions, devotedly serving the Guru with a steady mind, body, and speech; one should listen attentively when called upon by the Guru, communicate what has been learned, offer everything acquired to him, and always act for his welfare.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: Upon performing the duties of lying down and getting up, one does not settle for anything less than what is auspicious. Having gotten up, one should first greet this very person; upon doing so, the life force of both youths and elders becomes invigorated.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |
translation: One should always follow the conduct of a guru (teacher), which is auspicious and supreme. This applies to the guru's own children and students as well as to those related by blood. A child or a student, whether born in the same family or not, should be taught this way. The son of a guru deserves respect and honor. Just as a person becomes noble through his actions, one attains spiritual wisdom and understanding through service and devotion towards the guru.

sloka: teṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ śuśrūṣā paramaṃ tapa ucyate | | | | triṣveteṣvitikṛtyaṃ hi puruṣasya samāpyate | | | | tayornityaṃ priyaṃ kuryādācāryasya ca sarvadā | teṣveva triṣu tuṣṭeṣu tapaḥ sarvaṃ samāpyate | | | |
translation: Of the three [kinds of] service, intense austerity is declared; all actions come to fruition in these three. Constantly, one should perform what is dear to both oneself and the teacher. All austerities are accomplished when those three are fully pleased.

sloka: sarve tasyādṛtā dharmā yasyaite traya ādṛtāḥ | anādṛtāstu yasyaite sarvāstasyāphalāḥ kriyāḥ | | | |
translation: All duties of one who is devoted to only three of the [three-fold] religious duties become fruitless; and those duties that are not respected by him, all of them become ineffectual for him.

sloka: varjayetpramadāgāthāmagṛhastho bṛhadvrataḥ | indriyāṇi pramāthīni harantyapi yatermanaḥ || ||
translation: The householder, established in great vows, should avoid heedless songs. For, the uncontrolled senses can carry away even a wise person's mind.

sloka: keśaprasādhanonmardasnapanābhyañjanādikam | gurustrībhiryuvatibhiḥ kārayennātmano yuvā || || nanvagniḥ pramadā nāma ghṛtakumbhasamaḥ pumān | kalpayitvā''tmanā yāvadābhāsamidamīśvaraḥ | dvaitaṃ tāvanna viramettato hyasya viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: A young man should be anointed and massaged by respectable elder women with various ointments, starting from keşaprasādana, etc., **in a way that** the fire-like man, named Pramadā, **who is equal in size to a ghṛta-kumbha**, becomes manifest **until** the Lord Himself desires so. For, once started, this process should not be interrupted; otherwise, it would lead to the opposite result.

sloka: śuśrūṣāṃ satataṃ kurvanguroḥ saṃpraṇameta ca| ṣaṭ‌karmasvanivṛttaśca na pravṛttaśca sarvaśaḥ|| nācaratyadhikāreṇa seveta dviṣato na ca| eṣo''śramapadastāta brahmacāriṇa iṣyate||
translation: Constantly serving and paying respect to the guru, abstaining from the six senses' activities, neither acting nor encouraging others to act inappropriately, not serving or associating with enemies - one who follows this is called a brahmachari.

sloka: varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: Avoid at present in this world alcohol, meat, fragrant substances and garlands, causing harm to all living beings. Also, abstain from injuring the body by unnecessary things like anointing, collyrium, wearing eye-shades and carrying a parasol. Additionally, refrain from desires, anger, greed, dancing, singing, gambling, disputes among people, lying, and staring at women or causing harm to others.

sloka: ekaḥ śayīta sarvatra na retaḥ skandayetkva cit | kāmāddhi skandayanreto hinasti vrataṃ ātmanaḥ | | | | svapne siktvā brahmacārī dvijaḥ śukraṃ akāmataḥ | snātvārkaṃ arcayitvā triḥ punarmāṃ ityṛcaṃ japet | | | |
translation: Remaining alone everywhere, one should not ejaculate semen intentionally or unintentionally. For, indulging in desireful thoughts causes loss of the vow of celibacy and self-control. A learned Brahmin should practice and master celibacy even in dreams, remain pure and after bathing, worshipping the sun, repeat the mantra "trih punah maam iti rcham" three times.

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset | | | |
translation: Having properly studied the Vedas or even one of them in order, a steadfast student of brahmacharya can take up the gṛhasthāśrama (householder stage).

sloka: brahmavarcasakāmasya kāryo viprasya pañcame | rājño balārthinaḥ ṣaṣṭhe vaiśyasyehārthino'ṣṭame | | | |
translation: For the fifth stage of a brahmin's life, the desire for acquiring spiritual power is appropriate; for the sixth stage of a king's life, the pursuit of physical strength is suitable; and for the eighth stage of a merchant's life, the pursuit of wealth is fitting.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: One should undertake brahmacarya (celibacy) for a period of twelve days or five days, according to some; this includes the time up until the appearance of the grahaṇa (eclipse) and also on the sixteenth day, known as keśānta.

sloka: ṣaṭtriṃśadābdikaṃ caryaṃ gurau traivedikaṃ vratam | tadardhikaṃ pādikaṃ vā grahaṇāntikaṃ eva vā | | | |
translation: The 36-day ritual prescribed for the guru should be of the triple-Veda variety; it may also be half or merely the beginning of a grahaṇa (eclipse).

sloka: taṃ pratītaṃ svadharmeṇa brahmadāyaharaṃ pituḥ | sragviṇaṃ talpa āsīnaṃ arhayetprathamaṃ gavā | | | |
translation: Honor as first offering to the father, the one who has been identified, abiding in his own duty, as worthy of sacrificial rituals, wearing garlands and sitting on a low seat.

sloka: na pūrvaṃ gurave kiṃ cidupakurvīta dharmavit | snāsyaṃstu guruṇājñaptaḥ śaktyā gurvarthaṃ āharet | | | | kṣetraṃ hiraṇyaṃ gāṃ aśvaṃ chatropānahaṃ āsanam | dhānyaṃ śākaṃ ca vāsāṃsi gurave prītiṃ āvahet | | | |
translation: Never before has one who knows the path of dharma acted improperly towards a guru. I should carry out the guru's commands with devotion and for the guru's benefit. I will offer gold, a cow, a horse, an umbrella, a seat, grains, vegetables, and clothing to the guru to win their favor.

sloka: dattvā varamanujñāto guroḥ kāmaṃ yadīśvaraḥ | gṛhaṃ vanaṃ vā praviśetpravrajettatra vā vaset || ||
translation: Having received the boon and the permission from the guru, whether the lord chooses to dwell in a home or in the forest, that is up to him.

sloka: caritabrahmacaryasya brāhmaṇasya viśāṃpate| bhaikṣacaryāsvadhīkāraḥ praśasto dehamokṣaṇe||
translation: The conduct and celibacy of a Brahmin, O ruler of people, is praised as the means to physically liberate oneself; it is their superior authority.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If one desires to permanently reside in the abode of the guru, they must follow the prescribed duties for self-liberation. But if the guru has passed away, and there is no worthy successor or relative to carry on the guru's traditions, then one should maintain their own practices such as studying, serving at the sacred fire, and pursuing self-realization.

sloka: naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī tu vasedācāryasaṃnidhau | tadabhāve'sya tanaye patnyāṃ vaiśvānare'pi vā | | | |
translation: A perpetual student of Brahman, (he) should dwell in the presence of a preceptor; otherwise, for his son or even for his wife, (he) may adopt the lifestyle of a householder.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: In this way acts the pure, uninterrupted brahmachari, attaining the highest position, he does not return.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: There are, moreover, seven domestic sacrifices established [in the house of a grihastha]: Aupasana, Homo, Vaisvadeva, Parvana, Masthaka-Masi Sraddha, Sarpa Bali, and Rishabha Baliriti.

sloka: yatho etaddhutaḥ prahuta āhutaśśūlagavo baliharaṇaṃ pratyavarohaṇamaṣṭakāhoma iti sapta pākayajñasaṃsthā iti ||
translation: In this context, how the seven Agnihotra rituals, including the offering of clarified butter and a piece of wood , the withdrawal of oblations , and the eightfold sacrificial ceremony , are performed.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: During the period of taking care of a daughter, some (families) consider hospitality to guests as something to be postponed.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Is there anyone, who at the proper time, is devoted to the fires and is knowledgeable, wise, and straightforward in performing the ritual offerings and making them manifest? Always alert, they honor the oblations with pure fuel. Protect us constantly, O Uma's consort, during our homa rituals.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name indeed is Rigveda for the first, Yajurveda for the second, Sama Veda for the third, Atharvan for the fourth. The fifth is called Itihasa-Purana, the knowledge of sacred tradition, the traditional lore of the fathers, the treasure, the single expression, the word, the limb of Gods, the Brahma-vidya, the knowledge of created beings, the knowledge of kshatra, the knowledge of stars, the knowledge of serpent deities - this is their name, let one meditate on them thus.

sloka: vāgvāva nāmno bhūyasī vāgvā ṛgvedaṃ vijñāpayatu yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vāṅnābhaviṣyanna dharmo nādharmo vyajñāpayiṣyanna satyaṃ nānṛtaṃ na sādhu nāsādhu na hṛdayajño nāhṛdayajño vāgevaitatsarvaṃ vijñāpayati vācamupāssveti
translation: Let speech itself proclaim in abundance, let it make known the names ; let it reveal the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, Atharvaneda as the fourth, and the fifth Veda, the Itihāsapurāṇa. Speech will become all these Vedas. It will teach righteousness and not its opposite; it will proclaim truth and not falsehood; it will declare what is fitting and not what is unfitting; it will reveal what is in the heart and not what is not in the heart. Indeed, speech itself makes all this known through its own manifestation - by engaging with speech.

sloka: saṃkalpo vāva manaso bhūyānyadā vai saṃkalpatate'tha manasyatyatha vācamīrayati tāmu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmāṇi
translation: A thought, indeed, arises in the mind; then another one arises. Sometimes, the mind focuses on it; at other times, it does not. With a name, it is attached to a single word, and with that named word, various actions become associated.

sloka: tāni ha vā etāni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni samklṛpatāṃ dyāvāpṛthivī samakalpetāṃ vāyuścā''kāśaṃ ca samakalpantā''paśca tejaśca teṣā~ samklṛptyai saṃkalpamupāssveti
translation: These are indeed resolutions that, when established, uphold dyavia-prithivi (cosmic pair of heaven and earth), air, space, and tejas (radiant energy). Therefore, one should constantly meditate upon that resolution.

sloka: cittaṃ vāva saṃkalpādbhūyo yadā vai cetayate'tha saṃkalpayate'tha manasyatyatha vācasīrayati tāsu nāmnīrayati nāmni mantrā ekaṃ bhavanti mantreṣu karmaṇi
translation: When the mind contemplates on something, at that moment it is fixed in the mind . Further, when it is expressed through words , it becomes a name . In one mantra, there is only one action and this name takes place among many mantras .

sloka: prāṇo hyovaitāni sarvāṇi bhavati sa vā eṣa evaṃ paśyannevaṃ manvāna evaṃ vijānannativādī bhavati
translation: The life force (prana) indeed becomes all of these when one sees, reflects on, and truly understands in this way; it becomes a speaker of truth.

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: Achieved through dedicated effort, wealth that is free from causing harm to others and without any taints is referred to as either meager or plentiful.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ putradārādhisarvasvanyāsayācitam | pratiśrutaṃ tathānyasya na deyaṃ tvaṣṭadhā smṛtam || ||kuṭumbabhaktavasanāddeyaṃ yadatiricyate | madhvāsvādo viṣaṃ paścāddāturdhamo'nyathā bhavet || ||
translation: That which is common to sons and wives, established as one's own, and famously referred to as 'set aside' - such is not to be given up; it is remembered as being divided into eight parts for the sake of family affection. However, it should not be misused, but treated as a poison after consuming sweet words.

sloka: bhūdīpāṃś cānnavastrāmbhas tilasarpiḥpratiśrayān | naiveśikaṃ svarṇadhuryaṃ dattvā svarge mahīyate || yāsmṛ || gṛhadhānyābhayopānac chatramālyānulepanam | yānaṃ vṛkṣaṃ priyaṃ śayyāṃ dattvātyantaṃ sukhī bhavet || yāsmṛ ||
translation: By providing an illuminated lamp, food, clothing, and shelter to the needy, one becomes prominent in heaven; who, by giving away a golden pot, house, grains, fearlessness, umbrella, garland, anointment, vehicle, tree, beloved bedding, and ultimately attaining supreme happiness.

sloka: trīṇyāhuratidānāni gāvaḥ pṛthvī sarasvatī | atidānaṃ hi dānānāṃ vidhdānaṃ tato'dhikam||
translation: They declare (āhuḥ) that the three (trīṇi) primary offerings (atidānāni) of cows (gāvaḥ) are earth (pṛthvī) and sacred river Saraswati (sarasvatī). An offering that surpasses (atidānam) all other offerings (dānānām) is considered as the highest (adhikam), as prescribed (vidhdānam).

sloka: annaṃ dadhi madhu trāṇaṃ gobhūrukmāśvahastinaḥ | dānānyuttamadānāni uttamadravyadānataḥ || vidyādānādanāvāsaparibhogauṣadhāni ca | dānāni madhyamānīha madhyadravyadānataḥ || paribhoga iti paribhogasādhanaṃ khaṭvāsanādi | upānatpreṅkhayānāni chatrapātrāsanāni ca | dīpakāṣṭhaphalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam || bahutvādarthajātānāṃ saṃkhyā śeṣeṣu neṣyate |adhamānyavaśiṣṭāni sarvvadānānyatī viduḥ ||
translation: Food, curd, honey, and protection for cows, gold, silver, horses, and elephants; these are the supreme gifts given by the most generous. Knowledge, education, and other means of sustenance such as clothing, bedding, and vehicles; these are middling gifts given in the middle. Light sources like lamps, firewood, and fruits are the best recurring annual gifts. Among quantifiable things, only the remainder is counted, not the total. The lowest level of giving is understood to be what remains ungiven.

sloka: sarvadānairgurutaraṃ sarvagānairviśiṣyate | pānīyaṃ naraśārdūla tasmād dātavyameva hi||
translation: Among all types of gifts, the gift of education is the most weighty. Therefore, O best among men, it should certainly be given.

sloka: tasmāt tvaṃ sarvadānāni hitvānnaṃ samprayacchaha na hīdṛśaṃ puṇyaphalaṃ vicitramiha vidyate| annameva viśiṣṭaṃ hi tasmātparataraṃ na ca||
translation: Therefore, you should always give up all other offerings and only offer food to me. Indeed, there is no other fruit of merit as wonderful as this in this world . It is the most excellent , and there is nothing superior to it.

sloka: atidānāni sarvāṇi pṛthavīdānamucyate | acalā hyakṣayā bhūmirdogdhrī kāmānihottamān ||
translation: A gift that is excessive is called "pṛthvīdāna", and the supreme desires that are unchanging and inexhaustible are attributed to the earth.

sloka: yadaṅaga dāśuṣe tvamagne bhadraṃ kariṣyasi | tavet satyamaṅgiraḥ|| so aṅagirobhiraṅagirastamo bhūda vṛṣā vṛṣabhiḥ sakhibhiḥ sakhā san ṛgmibhirṛgmī gātubhirjyeṣṭho marutvāna no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: When, O Agni, you will make this offering to the serpent auspicious, then you will become the foremost among the Maruts, dear to the best of the friends , just as the most virtuous among the Angirasas . May Indra , the giver of strength , become favorable to us .

sloka: ta~hāṅgirā udgīthamupāsāṃcakra etamu evā''ṅgirasaṃ manyante'ṅgānāṃ yadrasaḥ
translation: There, the udgeeth (a type of hymn) composed by Angira is performed; this is indeed what the people of Angira clan consider as superior.

sloka: yenā naḥ pūrve pitaraḥ padajñāḥ svarvido abhi gā adrimuṣṇan
translation: The ancestors of ours, who knew the path to the heavenly world, have they reached the top of the mountain or not?

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: The wise and discerning brāhmaṇas understand these four words as the limited, bound feet that lead to the hidden boat (the spiritual teacher) who does not make a sound (remains inconspicuous), revealing the transcendental reality. This is what human beings call speech in the highest sense.

sloka: sūtrārtho varṇyate yatra padai: sutrānusāribhiḥ| svapadāni ca varṇyante bhāṣyaṃ bhāṣyavido vidu: ||
translation: Where the meaning of aphorisms is explained by footnoting words with corresponding words from the aphorisms themselves, and also where the commentator's own words are distinguished - such a commentary is understood by scholars.

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ||||{avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The components of a means of persuasion are the proposition, reason, example, supporting statement, and conclusion. (from Avayavauddesasutram)

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: The quality of this Tantra is also its explanation; it is adorned with those fifteen aspects.

sloka: tatra pradhānakalpanā dvidhā pradhānasya kalpanā pradhānena vā kalpanā pradhānakalpanā |
translation: There, the conceptualization of the primary [element] is twofold - through the conceptualization of the primary element itself or through the conceptualization of the secondary element.

sloka: saptadaśa tācchīlyādīnītyuktam |
translation: Seventeen mentioned, starting from the top of the head.

sloka: buddhimānātmanaḥkāryagurulāghavaṃkarmaphalamanubandhaṃdeśakālaucaviditvāyuktidarśanādbhiṣagbubhūṣuḥśāstramevāditaḥparīkṣeta
translation: The wise one, possessed of discrimination regarding his own actions, should carefully examine with the aid of scriptural injunctions, the qualities in a spiritual preceptor - such as lightness (in accepting disciples), being devoted to the performance of prescribed duties, and understanding the connection between actions and their results; as well as the proper time and place for them.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra and Dadhichi, invincible with their strengths, together vanquished ninety-nine enemies.

sloka: tad vāṃ narā sanaye daṃsa ugramāviṣkarṇomi tanyaturna vṛṣṭim dadhyaṅa ha yanmadhvātharvaṇo vāmaśvasya śīrṣṇā pra yadīmuvāca
translation: That, O men, I declare to you the mighty blow dealt by Indra in the battle of the gods and demons, when Madhavatharvan, commander of the demon army, had previously spoken.

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Approach Maghavan (Indra) swiftly, may you go with prosperity. Seek from him the best essence of knowledge and austerity, don't delay.

sloka: anannadānasya phalaṃ tvayedamupabhujyate | tarhyannadānato nānyaccharīrārogyakārakam || nānyadannādṛte puṃsāṃ kiñcitsañjīvanauṣadham | mahīṃ gatvā mahārāja kuruṣva vacanaṃ mama ||
translation: The fruit of not giving food is being enjoyed by you alone at this moment, for no other action promotes bodily health like the giving of food. O king, after going to the earth, make sure to carry out my command: nothing serves as a source of life for humans like the gift of food.

sloka: prabhāte kālyamutthāya sarastadupacakrame | athāpaśyaṃ śavaṃ tatra supuṣṭamajaraṃ kvacit || ||
translation: Upon waking at dawn, after getting up, he prepared the plowshare. Then he saw there a completely grown and unmoving corpse.

sloka: paśyato me tadā rāma vimānādavaruhya ca | taṃ śavaṃ bhakṣayāmāsa sa svargī raghunandana || || tathā bhuktvā yathākāmaṃ māṃsaṃ bahu supīvaram | avatīrya saraḥ svargī saṃspraṣṭumupacakrame || ||
translation: Upon seeing me, Lord Rama, descending from my aerial chariot, that celestial Raghunandan consumed the corpse as food. Having eaten his fill to his satisfaction with abundant and juicy flesh, he then alighted near the pond and prepared to converse with me.

sloka: tasya me svargabhūtasya kṣutpipāse dvijottama | bādhete paramodāra tato 'haṃ vyathitendriyaḥ ||| ||
translation: Of him who has attained to heaven, the best of the twice-born, if there is an obstruction in my receiving his food and drink offerings, then I, as the all-generous one, become agitated in my senses.

sloka: gatvā tribhuvanaśreṣṭhaṃ pitāmahamuvāca ha | bhagavanbrahmaloko 'yaṃ kṣutpipāsāvivarjitaḥ ||| ||
translation: Having gone to the best among the three worlds, my father spoke: "O Bhagavan of Brahmaloka, free from hunger and thirst."

sloka: pitāmahastu māmāha tavāhāraḥ sudevaja | svādūni svāni māṃsāni tāni bhakṣaya nityaśaḥ || ||
translation: The grandsire said to me, "O beloved one, you should daily partake of these delicious and own meats as your meal."

sloka: svaśarīraṃ tvayā puṣṭaṃ kurvatā tapa uttamam | anuptaṃ rohate śveta na kadācinmahāmate || || dattaṃ na te 'sti sūkṣmo 'pi tapa eva niṣevase | tena svargagato vatsa bādhyase kṣutpipāsayā || ||
translation: By nurturing your own body through the practice of superior austerity, it grows pure and unblemished. Never at any time have you given even the subtlest gift; solely by practicing austerities, you will go to heaven, my dear, and be free from hunger and thirst.

sloka: pūrvameva mayā sṛṣṭo jāmbavānṛkṣapuṅgava:| jṛmbhamāṇasya sahasā mama vaktrādajāyata||
translation: Jāmbavan, the foremost among bears, was created by me beforehand. Suddenly, he emerged from my face as I was expanding.

sloka: bhadraśca bhadraguptaśca bhadravindrastathaiva ca| saptabāhuśca vikhyātaḥ kanyā bhadrāvatī tathā| sambodhanī ca vikhyātā jñeyā jāmbavatīsutāḥ || ||
translation: Bhadra and Bhadragupta are well-known, as is Bhadravinda. Also famous is the seven-armed one, and the maiden named Avatí. The renowned Sambodhanī is known to be Jāmbavatī's daughter.

sloka: jāmbavān ṛkṣarājastu bherīśabdairmanojavaḥ | vijayaṃ dikṣu sarvāsu mahotsavamaghoṣayat || ||
translation: Jambavan, king of the bears, quickly made his presence known with loud roars at every sacred ceremony.

sloka: mayā mahābaleścaiva yajñe viṣṇussanātanaḥ| pradakṣiṇīkṛtaḥ pūrvaṃ kramamāṇastrivikramam||||
translation: By me and the eternal Viṣnu, both extremely powerful, a circumambulation of the three steps was performed in the past.

sloka: sa idānīmahaṃ vṛddhaḥ plavane mandavikramaḥ| yauvane ca tadā'sīnme balamapratimaṃ paraiḥ||||
translation: I, now advanced in age and with slow gait, once possessed strength unmatched by others in my youth.

sloka: nīla magnisutaṃ caiva hanumantaṃ ca vānaram| pitāmahasutaṃ caiva jāmbavantaṃ mahābalam||||
translation: Including Blue-born Hanuman and the mighty Jambavan, who are, respectively, the son of the wind god and the king of the bears.

sloka: ṛkṣavantaṃ girivaraṃ vindhyaṃ ca girimuttam| anveṣayan pariśrāntaḥ sa dadarśa mahāmanāḥ|| ||
translation: While searching tirelessly, a great-souled one saw the best mountain, Vindhya, which is like a lion among mountains, as well as another superior mountain.

sloka: vedānto nāmopaniṣatpramāṇaṃ tadanusārīṇi| śārīrakasūtrāṇi ca |
translation: The Upanishads, named Vedanta, are the ultimate means of right knowledge; the same applies to the physical aphorisms.

sloka: avidyādeḥ saṃsārabījasya viśaraṇād vināśanādityanena arthayogena vidyā upaniṣaducyate |
translation: The scripture Upaniṣad calls this understanding of the destruction of the seed of saṃsāra (cycle of rebirth) through the cessation of spiritual ignorance as "vidyā" (knowledge).

sloka: paraṃ brahma vā gamayatoti brahma gamayitṛtvena yogād vidyopaniṣad |
translation: Leading one to the supreme Brahman is the purpose of the teachings of the Upanishads through yoga.

sloka: garbhavāsajanmajarādyupadravavṛndasya lokāntarepaunapunyena pravṛttasya avasādapitṛtvena upaniṣadityucyate |
translation: In the teaching named Upanishad, it is said that the aggregate of adversities caused by being born from the womb, aging, and other such factors in a different world, due to past unrighteous deeds and downfall, belongs to the father.

sloka: mokṣalakṣaṇamityetatparaṃ rahasyam ityevaṃ | saiṣā śāṃbhavī vidyā kādividyeti vā hādividyeti vā sādividyeti vā rahasyam |
translation: This is the supreme secret of liberation's mark, called Para knowledge; it is also known as Shambhavi and by names such as Kaadi, Haadi, and Sadii.

sloka: īśakenakaṭhapraśnamuṇḍamāṇḍūkyatittiraḥ | aitareyaṃ ca chāndogyaṃ bṛhadāraṇyakaṃ tathā ||
translation: The Īśa, Kaṭha, Praśna, Muṇḍaka, and Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣads, as well as the Aitareya, Chāndogya, and Bṛhadāraṇyaka – all of these.

sloka: ekamevādvitīyam| sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma |
translation: The one alone, without a second, indeed, is everything that exists; this is the absolute reality.

sloka: sarve vedā yatpadamāmananti tapā~si sarvāṇi ca yadvadanti | yadicchanto brahmacaryaṃ caranti tatte pada~ saṃgraheṇa bravīmyomityetat || ||
translation: I will declare that to be the "Om" sound, which all the Vedas proclaim as the foundation and which those who desire to follow the path of Brahmacharya also tread.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: This indeed is the ultimate Brahman, known as Satyakama, as well as the sound 'Om' (pranava).

sloka: yo divi tiṣṭhandivo'ntaro yaṃ dyaurna veda yasya dyauḥ śarīraṃ yo divamantaro yamayaty eṣa ta ātmā'ntaryāmyamṛtaḥ || ||
translation: The one who inhabits the heaven and knows its innermost workings, whose body is the sky, who envelops the heaven; this self of his is the inner controller, immortal.

sloka: sa ya eṣo'ṇimaitadātmyamida~ sarvaṃ tatsatya~ sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly understands this self/identity of all as atman is the atman itself, O Shvetaketu; such is the truth.

sloka: sarvaṃ hyetad brahmāyamātmā brahma so'yamātmā catuṣpāt || ||
translation: "Indeed, this entire universe is Brahman, and this Self (Atma) is also Brahman. This very same Self is four-faced (Catushpada)."

sloka: hṛdayaṃ nirabhidyata hṛdayānmano manasaścandramā |
translation: The mind, situated in the heart, is revealed by the moon of the mind (i.e., the intellect).

sloka: tadaikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tattejo'sṛjata | tatteja aikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tadapo'sṛjata |
translation: Then , it contemplated that there should be many offspring . From that , it released the radiance . Then , it contemplated that there should be many offspring . From that , it released the water .

sloka: kṣaraṃ pradhānamamṛtākṣaraṃ haraḥ kṣarātmānāvīśate deva ekaḥ | tasyābhidhyānādyojanāttattvabhāvādbhūyaścānte viśvamāyānivṛttiḥ || ||
translation: The single deity, Hara, pervades both the transient and the immutable . Through meditation on him and other related practices, one can realize the ultimate truth. At the end, this leads to the cessation of the illusion of worldliness .

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The meters, sacrifices, and rituals that the Vedas proclaim are being created from this delusive energy. This universe is originating from it. Besides this, something yet to be is also encompassed by my delusive power. In this , another entity is restricted by my delusive power.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyāvayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: Understand the maya (illusion) as prakriti (primordial nature), and Maheshwara (the great lord) as the mayin (controller of illusion). This entire visible world is pervaded by its constituent parts.

sloka: idaṃ vai tanmadhu dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇo'śvibhyāmuvāca | tadetadṛṣiḥ paśyannavocat | rūparūpaṃ pratirūpo babhūva tadasya rūpaṃ praticakṣaṇāya | indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īyate yuktā hyasya harayaḥ śatā daśetiy ayaṃ vai harayo 'yaṃ vai daśa ca sahasraṇi bahūni cānantāni ca | tadetadbrahmāpūrvamanaparamanantaramabāhyam ayamātmā brahma sarvānubhūrityanuśāsanam || ||
translation:
This is indeed the madhu spoken by the  Atharvan to the twin Ashvins. The seer, having seen this, spoke of it. A form appeared akin to its form for clear understanding. Indra manifests himself in many forms through his illusions. His maruts are hundred, thousandfold, and countless. This very marut is also ten and a thousand.

Furthermore, this brahma is both the unmanifested beginning and end, infinite and beyond. This self (atman) is the experiencer of all. Thus, it is taught.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation: Just as from the navel of the cosmic being are created clay and herbs, and just as hair grows from the body of a living being, so too does this entire universe emerge from the imperishable.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception and testimony, being established through all means of validation, are the threefold valid proofs for establishing an object of knowledge.

sloka: tasmācca viparyāsāt siddhaṃ sākṣitvamasya puruṣasya | kaivalyaṃ mādhyasthyaṃ draṣṭṛtvamakartṛbhāvaśca || ||
translation: Therefore, due to the reversal of understanding, established is the self-evident witness-nature of the purusha (the individual soul), as well as its detachment, being the seer, and non-doership.

sloka: saṃghātaparārthatvāt triguṇādiviparyādadhiṣṭhānāt | puruṣo'sti bhoktṛbhāvāt kaivalyārthaṃ pravṛtteśca || ||
translation: The Purusha exists as the one who enjoys, becoming distinct from the three gunas and their dominance, for the sake of attaining Kaivalya (isolation).

sloka: adhyavasāyo buddhirdharmo jñānaṃ virāga aiśvaryam | sāttvikametadrūpaṃ tāmasamasmādviparyastam || ||
translation: Determination is the intellectual virtue, duty is the moral principle, knowledge is the wisdom, dispassion is the inner renunciation, and lordship is the sattvic form; turned away from this, tamasic, is what ignorance is.

sloka: abhimāno'haṃkāra: tasmādvividha: pravartate sarga: | ekādaśakaśca gaṇastanmātrapañcakaścaiva || ||
translation: Arrogance and egoism are the two sources from which diversity of creation arises, as well as groups of eleven and five.

sloka: ubhayātmakamatra mana: saṅkalpamindriyaṃ ca sādharmyāt | guṇapariṇāmaviśeṣānnānātvaṃ bāhyabhedāśca || ||
translation: The mind, which is two-fold in nature, and the sense organs are similar due to their sharing of the same characteristics; the distinct variations found externally and the unique transformation of qualities arise from them.

sloka: hetumadanityamavyāpi sakriyamanekamāśritaṃ liṃṅgam | sāvayavaṃ paratantraṃ vyaktaṃ viparītamavyaktam || ||triguṇamaviveki viṣaya: sāmānyamacetanaṃ prasavadharmi | vyaktaṃ tathā pradhānaṃ tadviparītastathā ca pumān || ||
translation: Rooted in cause, transient, all-pervading, active, and taking multiple forms, the tangible limb is dependent and manifest; its opposite, however, is invisible and independent. The three qualities are indistinguishable in objects that are uniform, inanimate, and governed by reproductive tendencies. Similarly, both the primal cause and its counterpart, the human being, exist.

sloka: vatsavivṛddhinimittaṃ kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttirajñasya | puruṣavimokṣanimittaṃ tathā pravṛtti: pradhānasya || ||
translation: Just as the churning of curds (cream) is a cause for the appearance of butter, so too is ignorance the cause for the functioning of the primary (pradhana).

sloka: tasmānna badhyate'ddhā na mucyate nāpi saṃsarati kañcit | saṃsarati badhyate mucyate ca nānāśrayā prakṛti: || ||
translation: Therefore, never is one bound permanently, never is one liberated or made to repeatedly transmigrate by a certain nature with multiple supports. One is bound, liberated, and made to transmigrate by a nature that has multiple supports.

sloka: raṅgastha ityupekṣaka eko dṛṣṭāhamityuparamatyanyā | sati saṃyoge'pi tayo: prayojanaṃ nāsti sargasya || ||
translation: The one indifferent spectator, who is seen as detached, has no purpose in the conjunction, even when it exists, for the creation.

sloka: tadabhāvavati tatprakārako'nubhavo'yathārthaḥ| yathā śuktāvidaṃ rajatamiti| saiva apramā ityucyate||
translation: Upon the absence of that , such an experience is inappropriate and not accurate, just like seeing silver in a shell . This misperception is called apramā.

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: Between the two options presented, one should choose the more beneficial; by doing so, one gains merit and avoids loss of purpose. If one chooses personal pleasure over this benefit, they are at a loss.

sloka: brahmacaryyācaraṇasya yaḥ śāstrabodhito'vadhiḥ | tāvadvedamupāsyāsamāptaveda evāśramāntaraṃ gato yaḥ sa vratasnātakaḥ |samāpya vratamasamāpya vedaṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vratasnātakaḥ
translation: For one who is engaged in the conduct of brahmacharya, what is the limit of learning from scriptures? As long as one has not realized this knowledge, and has not yet moved on to the next stage of life, they are considered a vrata snātaka. Having completed the vow, once they have returned, having studied the Vedas, they are considered a vrata snātaka.

sloka: vedamadhītyagurusannidhau vedābhyāsaṃ yaḥ karoti sa vidyāsnātakaḥ |samāpya vedamasamāpya vrataṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāsnātakaḥ
translation: The one who studies the Vedas in the presence of a guru is a knowledgable snātaka; similarly, the one who completes his vow after finishing the study of the Vedas is also a knowledgable snātaka.
