sloka: pālitasamyagvrataḥ prāptavedo yo dvitīyāśramaṃ gataḥ sa ubhayasnātakaḥ |ubhayaṃ samāpya yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāvratasnātaka iti
translation: The protector of the sacred pledge, who has acquired knowledge of the Vedas, having embarked on the second stage of life, becomes a twice-born. Having accomplished both (knowledge and renunciation), he returns as a knower of both the scholarly and monastic vows.

sloka: tadya itthaṃ viduḥ | ye ceme'raṇye śraddhā tapa ityupāsate te'rciṣamabhisambhavantyarciṣo'harahna āpūryamāṇapakṣamāpūryamāṇapakṣādyānṣaḍudaṅṅeti māsā~stān || ||
translation: Those who in this very moment are known to worship with faith and austerity, they indeed become the most radiant among their peers, growing in brilliance month after month.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: The worshipful deities are Agni by day and Surya at night; the bright one is superior to the other stars. The self, in its waking state, is Taijasa in the dreaming state, and Turiya in deep sleep. It is through union that this self becomes the object of worship for the devas. Becoming this self through regular practice, one attains tranquility and, established in the self, does not regress.

sloka: atha ya ime grāma iṣṭāpūrte dattamityupāsate te dhūmamabhisambhavanti dhūmādrātri~ rātreraparapakṣamaparapakṣādyānṣaḍdakṣiṇaiti māsā~stānnaite saṃvatsaramabhiprāpnuvanti || ||
translation: Then, who are those worshipers of these villages that have been fully offered and given, approaching [the deity]? They originate from smoke and reach out to other half-nights and other half-days, standing out in six directions throughout the months, thus attaining a year.

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: The subtle manifestations of substances, smoke is; night and waning moon are the decay; southward course is of the sun; corn and herbs are growth; semen and food are called the produce of the earth; O Lord of the field, again is the birth, each in its own order, becoming so here.

sloka: athaitayoḥ pathorna katareṇa ca na tānīmāni kṣudrāṇyasakṛdāvartīni bhūtāni bhavanti jāyasva mriyasvetyetattṛtīya~sthānaṃ tenāsau loko na sampūryate tasmājjugupseta tadeṣa ślokaḥ || ||
translation: Understand, through which of the two paths (of devas and pitrs) these transient beings, who are repeatedly born and die, do not become small and insignificant; procreate and decay. This is the third stance, by which this world is not completed. Therefore, one should detest this verse.

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: At the onset of its understanding, he delightfully engages in questioning and scrutinizing.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: In the eternal cycle of this world, the paths to the white and black (of life and death) are twofold: one way leads to irreversible progress, while the other causes repeated returns.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: Agni, bring here the gods' offerings, pleasing to the three birthplaces; be adorned and drink the ritual liquid.

sloka: ā vakṣi devā~ iha vipra yakṣi cośan hotarni ṣadā yoniṣu triṣu ||
translation: O sage, tell the gods indeed dwell in these three sources : fire , cows , and priests .

sloka: yajñasya ketuṃ prathamaṃ purohitamagniṃ narastriṣadhasthe samīdhire ||
translation: First, kindle the fire, the foremost sign of the sacrifice, as the priest.

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Indeed, the sacrificial fire called "dakshina" is recognized as the foremost. For, this one is the son of all fires - the gārhapatya, pautra, and āhavanīya; thus, one should properly maintain it.

sloka: gārhapatyena santya ṛtunā yajñanīrasi | devān devayate yaja ||
translation: With the Gharapatya fire, nourishing the ritual at the proper time, one should sacrifice, thus satisfying the gods.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These three worlds are indeed the three stages of life (ashramas), and these three are also the Vedas and the three fires (agnayah) that are mentioned.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Having done this warrior's duty, one should first welcome the guest; and in accordance with the rules, give alms to the wandering ascetic.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: In the prosperity of learning and penance, the priest, as the chief actor, performs the offering. Thus, it protects from small sins and even great transgressions, and keeps away suffering.

sloka: bhikṣāṃ apyudapātraṃ vā satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | vedatattvārthaviduṣe brāhmaṇāyopapādayet | | | |
translation: Even a begging bowl, when offered respectfully according to proper procedure to a knower of the true meaning of the Vedas, a brahmin, should be given.

sloka: yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī | | | |
translation: By donating a cow to the teacher according to sacred rites, one attains that religious merit; similarly, by giving alms to a twice-born person living in his house, one also acquires the same merit.

sloka: na mṛ॒tyu: āsīt amṛta॒ṃ na tarhi॒
translation: Death had not existed, nor immortality either.

sloka: ānī̭t avā॒taṃ sva॒dhayā॒ tat ekamtasmāddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa
translation: Having brought down the unblemished oblation with one's own effort, nothing else is superior to that.

sloka: tapasa॒: tatmahi॒naajāya॒taekam
translation: Through sustained tapas (deep meditation), we realize the single, unchanging reality.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: Indeed, the divine and immortal being, the person, is both within and beyond all. Unborn, without breathing, tranquil, resplendent, transcending the material realm – such is the supreme one.

sloka: sahasraśīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ sahasrapāt
translation: A thousand-headed being is the Purusha, possessing a thousand eyes and a thousand feet.

sloka: puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ yadbhūtaṃ yacca bhavyam
translation: The Purusha indeed is all that exists and will come into existence.

sloka: tasmādvirāl̤ajāyata virājo adhi pūruṣaḥsa jāto atyaricyata paścādbhūmimatho puraḥ
translation: From there emerged the radiant Viraj, then the primal Purusha expanded in all directions, beyond and before, covering the earth.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the bygone age, among the gods, one hundred were born at once; in the first age of the gods, one was born first, from whom afterwards cravings and desires (of living beings) began to be born.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The truth is one, but the learned speak of it in many ways.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: In the beginning, only the unreal existed. Then, from that arose the real. The very self, all by itself, carried out this creation. Therefore, it is called "the auspicious accomplishment." Indeed, that auspicious accomplishment is bliss itself.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: In the beginning, only the unmanifest existed. Then the seers of ancient times pondered, "What could have been before this unmanifest state?"

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: None indeed has ever resided here in the forefront, immune to death, nor will this world ever be concealed from death. Through the pursuit of religious rituals, one can only make the deity satisfied, and as a result, obtain the desired results.

sloka: sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam | taddhaika āhurasadevedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyaṃ tasmādasataḥ sajjāyata || || sattveva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam || ||
translation: Surely, in the beginning, somyaa, this was non-dual and singular, it is said by the wise; only one nature existed, that's why from that one, diversification arose.

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The treatise that reveals the extraordinary means to attain the desirable and ward off the undesirable is called Veda.

sloka: ekaviṃśatiśākhātmaka ṛk śataśākhātmaka yajuḥ sahasraśākhāmayasāma navaśākhāmayātharvva iti purāṇam api ca śrīmārkaṇḍeya uvāca |
translation: Here, "ekavimshati-shakhātmaka" means made up of 21 branches, "shatashakhātmaka" means made up of 100 branches, "sahasra-maya" means consisting of thousands, and "navashakha-mayah" means having nine branches. These are the descriptions of different Vedic texts: Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda.)

sloka: tebhyastaptebhyastrayo vedā ajāyanta | agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurvedaḥ sūryāt sāmavedaḥ |
translation: From the heated (taptā), these three Vedas were born: from Agni, the Ṛkveda; from Vāyu, the Yajurveda; and from Surya, the Sāmaveda.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, the Řigveda, Sama Veda, and Yajur Veda are the subjects of initiation (diksha).

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: Is this vast being's exhaled breath perhaps the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda?

sloka: upa tvāgne divedive doṣāvastardhiyā vayaṃ namo bharanta emasi
translation: Approaching you, O fire, we have become carriers of defects every day; we bow down.

sloka: vedaśāstrārthatattvajño yatra tatrāśrame vasan | ihaiva loke tiṣṭhansa brahmabhūyāya kalpate | | |
translation: The one who knows the meaning and purpose of the Vedas and shastras, by dwelling in that very ashram, is becoming eligible for Brahmanhood right here in this world.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The teachings that authentically reveal dharma and Brahman, as impersonal and authorless statements, make up Vedanta shastra.

sloka: sanātanaṃ niteyam | vedāpauruṣeyatvapakṣa eva manorabhimataḥ| pūrvakalpe ye vedāsta eva paramātmamūrterbrahmaṇaḥ sarvajñasya smṛtyārūḍhāḥ | tāneva kalpādau agnivāyuravibhya ācakarṣa|
translation: The eternal scripture , considered as having originated from divine sources , is the chosen preference of the mind . In the previous cycle of time , the Vedas, established as being the personification of the all-knowing Brahman , were installed by sages who had realized its divinity through their memory . Similarly, in this cycle , it is these very Vedas that establish the principles of Agni, Vayu, and the Sun.

sloka: yathā ca śrutiḥ agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurveda ādityātsāmaveda ||
translation: Likewise, the revelation of Agni is in the Ṛgveda, of Vāyu in the Yajurveda, and of Surya in the Sāmaveda.

sloka: anantā vai vedāḥ |
translation: The Vedas are indeed infinite.

sloka: pitṛdevamanuṣyāṇāṃ vedaścakṣuḥ sanātanam | aśakyaṃ cāprameyaṃ ca vedaśāstraṃ iti sthitiḥ | |
translation: The eternal eye of the people and their ancestors is the Veda; this is the established view regarding the Veda as something that is impossible to fully know and incomprehensible.

sloka: vedo'khilo dharmamūlaṃ smṛtiśīle ca tadvidām | ācāraścaiva sādhūnāṃ ātmanastuṣṭireva ca | | | |
translation: The Vedas are the root of all dharma, and for those who understand them, proper conduct and self-satisfaction are also important.

sloka: bibharti sarvabhūtāni vedaśāstraṃ sanātanam | tasmādetatparaṃ manye yajjantorasya sādhanam | | | |
translation: The one who sustains all beings and the eternal Veda shastras, I believe this to be the supreme means for the control of the senses.

sloka: ārṣaṃ dharmopadeśaṃ ca vedaśāstrāvirodhinā | yastarkeṇānusaṃdhatte sa dharmaṃ veda netaraḥ | | | |
translation: One who utilizes logical reasoning consistent with Vedic scriptures to establish and teach the ancient code of conduct (dharma), indeed understands dharma; others do not.

sloka: yānīhāgamaśāstrāṇi yāśca kāścitpravṛttayaḥ| tāni vedaṃ puraskṛtya pravṛttāni yathākramam||
translation: Composing one's actions according to the teachings of sacred texts and traditions that are appropriate should be done in a proper sequence, starting with understanding those very texts.

sloka: parābhidhyānātu tirohitaṃ tato hyasya bandhaviparyayau
translation: The hidden motive of others, however, becomes manifest in the case of this person.

sloka: ata eva copamā sūryakādivat
translation: Hence indeed , even a comparison to the sun and others .

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six ancillary sciences of the Vedas are: śikṣā , kalpa , vyākaraṇam , nirukta , chandas , and jyotiṣa .

sloka: atha śikṣāṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | varṇaḥ svaraḥ | mātrā balam | sāma santāna| ityuktaḥ śikṣādhyāyaḥ ||
translation: Now we will explain the chapter on Shiksha, which includes topics such as phonemes , intonation , length of utterance , and strength of sounds, as well as the concept of sāman and its lineage.

sloka: mantro hīnaḥ svarato varṇato vā mithyā prayukto na tamarthamāha | sa vāgvajro yajamānaṃ hinasti yathendraśatruḥ svarato'parādhāt ||
translation: If a mantra reciter is unskilled or incorrectly chants it due to misunderstanding of the tone or words, they do not achieve the intended result. Indeed, such speech becomes as powerful and destructive as a thunderbolt to the sacrificer, brought about by their own fault.

sloka: tattvaṣṭāhavanīyamupa prāvartayatsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti yadavartayattadvṛtrasya vṛtratvaṃ yadabravītsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti tasmādasyendraḥ śatrurabhavat
translation: By performing the ritual of Tattvasthali (establishing the essence) with the offering of "svaha," Indra grew in power and declared himself as the destroyer of Vritra. Therefore, he became known as the enemy of Vritra.

sloka: vyākriyante śabdāḥ anena iti vyākaraṇam | vyākriyante vyutpādyante sādhuśabdā asmin aneneti vā iti durgādāsaḥ
translation: The words are analyzed through this means, referred to as vyakarana (grammar); they are generated and modified through the use of proper words in this way, as stated by Durgadhipa.

sloka: indraścandraḥ kāśakṛtsnāpiśalī śākaṭāyanaḥ | pāṇinyamarajainendrāḥ jayantyaṣṭau ca śābdikāḥ ||
translation: Indra and Chandra, Kaashakritsna, Aapishali Shaakatayana, Panini, Amara, Jaina, and eight other grammar scholars named Indrani have been victorious (in their field).

sloka: arthāvabodhe nirapekṣatayā padajātaṃ yatroktaṃ tanniruktam |
translation: In the pursuit of understanding meanings, where [the word's] origin has been mentioned without partiality, that is its definition.

sloka: samāmnāyaḥ samāmnātaḥ sa vyākhyātavyaḥ | idamantareṇa mantreṣvarthapratyayo na vidyate iti |
translation: This sacred tradition, when proclaimed, must be explained in this way: there is no meaning of the word "artha" in the context of this mantra, except for what has been stated here.

sloka: udāharaṇasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ|| {hetulakṣaṇam} tathā vaidharmyāt|| {hetulakṣaṇam}
translation: The similarity between an example and what is to be inferred is the reason for a probans establishing a probandum . Likewise, the dissimilarity is also the reason.

sloka: udāharaṇena sāmānyātsādhyasya dharmasya sādhanaṃ prajñāpanaṃ hetuḥ | sādhye pratisaṃdhāya dharmamudāharaṇe ca pratisaṃdhāya tasya sādhanatāvacanaṃ hetuḥ utpattidharmakatvāditi | utpattidharmakamanityaṃ dṛṣṭamiti | udāharaṇavaidharmyācca sādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ | katham anityaḥ śabdaḥ utpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ yathā ātmādidravyaniti ||
translation: The means of establishing the general duty of something is explained through an example. When the duty is understood, mentioning the means to accomplish it serves as a reason. Similarly, giving an example of a different kind also serves as a reason for understanding that duty. But how can the term "anitya" (temporary) serve as a reason for something that is utpattidharmaka (arising from inherent nature), such as the self and other substances?

sloka: sādhyasādharmyāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta udāharaṇam || {udāharaṇalakṣaṇam} tadviparyayādvā viparītam||{udāharaṇalakṣaṇam}
translation: Demonstrating an example to illustrate how something contrary to the nature of the target becomes its nature due to similarity with it , is the definition of an example.

sloka: sādhyena sādharmyaṃ samānadharmatā sādhyasādharmyātkāraṇāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta iti | tasya dharmastaddharmaḥ | tasya sādhyasya | sādhyaṃ ca dvividhaṃ dharmiviśiṣṭo vā dharmaḥ śabdasyānityatvaṃ dharmaviśiṣṭo vā dharmī anityaḥ śabda iti| ihettaraṃ tadgrahaṇena gṛhyate|
translation: The similarity between the sought-after and the seeker is called samanadharmatā; its manifestation is through a common quality or through a distinct quality. The sought-after's qualities become his own in both cases. The dual nature of dharma is twofold: either it refers to the impermanent quality (anitya) or the eternal quality (anitya) associated with the word. This dual nature is grasped through the term "dharma".

sloka: udāharaṇāpekṣaḥ tathā iti upasaṃhāraḥ na tathā iti vā sādhyasya upanayaḥ || {upanayalakṣaṇam}
translation: An example is necessary for explanation, while itself can be the conclusion; or it can serve as the introduction of the probandum in the method.

sloka: sādhyāsādharmyayukte udāharaṇe sthālyādi dravyamutyatidharmakatvamupasaṃhriyate sādhyavaidarmyayukte punarudāharaṇe ātmādi dravyamanutpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ na ca tathā śabda iti anutpattidharmakatvasyopasaṃhārapratiṣedhena utpattidharmakatvamupasaṃhiyate |
translation: In the illustration of a comparable example joined with unrighteousness, the essential nature of the physical components such as a jar and others is condensed; but when the illustration is associated with a distinct nature, the eternal inherent nature of the self and other substances is always observed, except for the case of sound, where the manifestation of its essential nature is negated.

sloka: hetvapadeśātpratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ nigamanam||{nigamanalakṣaṇam}
translation: After making a proposition based on evidence, the concluding speech is the definition of a reliable source.

sloka: sādharmyokte vaidharmyokte vā yathodāharaṇamupasaṃhriyate tasmādutpattidharmakatvādanityaḥ śabda iti nigamanam |
translation: The term is identified as denoting 'uncommon' based on the examples given in both similar and dissimilar contexts; hence, it refers to a word that signifies a unique property of origin.

sloka: brahma vai mantraḥ | ḥ saptākṣaraṃ vai brahmargityekamakṣaraṃ yajuritidve sāmeti dve atha yadato'nyadbrahmaiva taddvyakṣaraṃ vai brahma tadetatsarvaṃsaptākṣaraṃ brahma |
translation: The Vedic hymn indeed is Brahman, consisting of seven syllables; the one-syllabled Brahman is also called the Ekakshara in the Yajur tradition. Among them, whatever is not Brahman is considered as a single syllable. Undoubtedly, that very Brahman is all this, the seven-syllabled Brahman.

sloka: mantrabrāhmaṇe yajñasya pramāṇam mantrabrāhmaṇayorvedanāmadheyam karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The authority of a yajña (sacrifice) is the mantra-brāhmaṇa. The mantra-brāhmaṇa duo is the denoted meaning of the Vedas. The brāhmaṇas impel (encourage) actions (karmas).

sloka: śeṣe brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ
translation: The word " Brahmana" is used in the context of the end of something.

sloka: dvividham brāhmaṇam vidhiḥ arthavādaśca
translation: The rule concerning the twofold Brahmanas involves both injunction and explanation.

sloka: heturnirvacanaṃ nindā praśaṃsā saṃśayo vidhiḥ| parakriyā purākalpo vyavadhāraṇakalpanā|| upamānaṃ daśaite tu vidhayo brāhmaṇasya tu| etadvai sarvavedeṣu niyataṃ vidhilakṣaṇam||
translation: The reasons, explanations, praise, criticism, and doubt are the characteristics of a rule; as well as the behavior towards others, past customs, and the determination of meaning. Comparison is one of the ten aspects of a Brahmin's duty, which is firmly established in all Vedas as the definition of a rule.

sloka: itthaṃ vākyaistadarthānusandhānaṃ śravaṇaṃ bhavet yuktyā saṃbhāvitatvānusaṃdhānaṃ mannantu tat
translation: Through statements, contemplation of their meanings should occur; listening is to be engaged through valid reasoning; understanding the underlying truth is to be cultivated.

sloka: yat saṃbaddhaṃ sat tadākārollekhi vijñānaṃ tat pratyakṣaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: That which is directly cognizable when connected to the object of awareness, that is called perceptual knowledge; (this is) a Sāṃkhya principle.

sloka: pratibandhadṛśaḥ pratibaddhajñānamanumānaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: Like the Sankhya aphorism states, a covered knowledge and inference are obstructed, that is, impeded by contrary evidence.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The instruction or teaching that is given by a reliable and authentic source is referred to as 'āptopadeśaḥ' in the Sāṃkhya Sūtra.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and verbal testimony are the three established means of valid knowledge for establishing the object's existence.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, and scriptural testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: āptena dṛṣṭo'numitaḥ vā arthaḥ paratra svabodhasaṅkrāntaye śabdenopadiśyate | śabdāttadarthaviṣayā vṛttiḥ śroturāgamaḥ | yasyāśraddheyārtho vaktā na dṛṣṭānumitārthaḥ sa āgamaḥ plavate |
translation: The meaning of an object is indicated by the word "śabda" when it is seen or heard from a reliable source . This kind of awareness-transmission through words is based on the use of that object in practice and is established by coming from the ear of the listener . If the speaker lacks faith in this demonstrated meaning and does not know the actual seen/heard meaning, then their speech "plavate" .

sloka: tadvacanādāmnāyasya prāmāṇyam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Based on the authority of the Vaiśeṣika school's teachings, the proof of its principles lies in that statement.

sloka: asyedaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃyogi virodhi samavāyi ceti laiṅgikam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This is the effect, cause, conjunction, disagreement, and inherence, according to the Lingi school of Vaisheshika philosophy.

sloka: asyedaṃ kārya kāraṇasambandhaścāvayavādbhavati | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This is the effect , composed of constituents , associated with its cause in the Vaiśeṣika system .

sloka: etena śābdaṃ vyākhyātam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: This term "shabdam" has been explained as "Vaisesika"; such is the exposition.

sloka: heturapadeśo liṅgaṃ pramāṇaṃ karaṇamityanarthāntaram | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Cause, indication, distinctive sign, means of knowledge, instrument are, in Vaisesika philosophy, different aspects having separate significance.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, and verbal testimony are the means of valid knowledge. (Pramāṇa-uddesa Sutra)

sloka: indriyārthasannikarṣotpannaṃ jñānaṃ avyapadeśyaṃ avyabhicāri vyavasāyātmakaṃ pratyakṣam|||| {pratyakṣalakṣaṇam} atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavatśeṣavatsāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca|||| {anumānalakṣaṇam} prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam |||| {upamānalakṣaṇam} āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ |||| {śabdalakṣaṇam}
translation: Knowledge arising from the contact of the senses with their objects is unteachable, uninterrupted, and determined in nature; it is direct perception . Prior to this, there exists threefold inference: inference based on preceding similarity , inference based on subsequent similarity , and inference based on analogy . Additionally, valid knowledge also comes from reliable testimony or verbal testimony .

sloka: satsaṃprayoge puruṣasyendriyāṇāṃ buddhijanma tatpratyakṣam
translation: At the coming together of a person's senses and intellect at birth, it is directly perceptible.

sloka: autpattikas tu śabdasyārthena saṃbandhas tasya jñānam upadeśo'vyatirekaś cārthe'nupalabdhe tatpramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt
translation: The connection of a word's inherent meaning is its understanding; in the absence of perceiving the meaning, the means of knowing it is independent of Badarayana's opinion.

sloka: api vā kartṛsāmānyāt pramāṇam anumānaṃ syāt
translation: Even conjecture could serve as a means of valid knowledge, considering the common characteristics of agents.

sloka: anumānaṃ jñātasambandhasyaikadeśadarśanādekadeśāntare'sannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhiḥ| tattu dvividhaṃ pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandham ca| pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā dhūmākṛtidarśanādagnyākṛtivijñānam| sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā devadattasya gatipūrvikāṃ deśāntaraprāptimupalabhyādityagatismaraṇam|
translation: The understanding (buddhiḥ) that there is a connection between something known and its indication, as when observing smoke reveals the presence of fire or inferring the arrival of Devadatta from his footprints, can be of two types - based on direct perception or inferred from similarities.

sloka: śāstraṃ śabdavijñānādasannikṛṣṭe'rthe vijñānam||
translation: Knowledge in the form of scriptures, associated with audio-visual knowledge in the immediate context.

sloka: upamānamapi sādṛśyam asannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhimutpādayati| yathā gavayadarśanaṃ gosmaraṇasya|
translation: Even the act of comparing (upamana) arises from a perceived similarity (sadrsam) in dissimilar things, just as the sighting of a gavaya (a type of antelope) gives rise to the memory of a cow.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā ||
translation: The means of gaining wealth, whether seen or heard about, cannot be unreasonably assumed to apply in a different context; just as the continued existence of Devadatta is mentally assumed based on the observation of his home's presence and not on the observation of its absence.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇābhāvo nāsti ityasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasya||
translation: Even the absence of proof is not unrelated to the meaning in question.

sloka: śabdād eva pramitaḥ |
translation: Derived solely from sound, it is established.

sloka: api saṃrādhanepratyakṣānumānābhyām |
translation: Even through perception and inference during a discussion.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: And indeed presented it as obvious inference.

sloka: phalamata upapatteḥ |
translation: The result indeed is appropriate.

sloka: athocyeta mā bhūtkarmānantaraṃ phalotpādaḥ karmakāryādapūrvātphalamutpatsyata iti tadapi nopapadyate apūrvasyācetanasya kāṣṭhaloṣṭasamasya cetanenāpravartitasya pravṛttyanupapatteḥ tadastitve eva pramāṇābhāvāt arthāpattiḥ pramāṇamiti cet na īśvarasiddherarthāpattikṣayāt||
translation: Therefore, can it be said that the emergence of a result is not subsequent to an action, since the inanimate and previously non-existent cannot have an inherent activity? Even if this were the case, the lack of any other means of knowledge would make it a reasonable conclusion (arthapatti). However, this reasoning cannot refute the existence of a creator due to the elimination of pramana-apatti (falsity of means of knowledge) through the establishment of Ishvara-siddhi (proof of a creator).

sloka: idānīmarthāpattirnirūpyate| tatropapadyajñānenopapādakakalpanamarthāpattiḥ| tatropapadyajñānaṃ karaṇam upapādakajñānaṃ phalam|
translation: The determination of what is relevant at present is being settled. In this regard, the cause of its emergence is ignorance, while knowledge is its effect.

sloka: samyagarthe ca saṃśabdo duṣprayoganivāraṇaḥ | prayoga indriyāṇāṃ ca vyāpāro'rtheṣu kaththate ||duṣṭatvācchuktikāyogo vāryate rajatekṣaṇāt | evaṃ satyanuvādatvaṃ lakṣaṇasyāpi saṃbhavet ||
translation: Properly using words is a remover of misuse; usage in relation to the senses' activities and their objects is also described as such. The combination of impurity and conch is prevented due to its being tainted with silver; similarly, truthful speech also arises from the establishment of the signifier.

sloka: pramāṇaṣaṭkavijñāto yatrā'rtho nā'nyathā bhavet | adṛṣṭaṃ kalpayedanyaṃ sā 'rthāpattirudāhṛtā ||
translation: Where the meaning is not otherwise but established based on the six means of knowledge, that should be considered as the correct meaning; one should not imagine something unseen for it.

sloka: ānumānikam apy ekeṣām iti cen na śarīrarūpakavinyastagṛhīterdarśayati ca |
translation: Even if some consider it to be insignificant , one who has established a detached view of the body does not reveal himself in this way.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Let the mother, father, teacher, and friend, who are devoted and engaged in helping others, considerately bestow their fullest efforts on those afflicted, disadvantaged, and superior beings.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: Offered to the ungrateful, flatterer, weak, deceitful, and crooked, the gift becomes fruitless.

sloka: ārūḍhapatite dattamanyāyopahṛtaṃ ca yat| vyarthaṃ tu patite dānaṃ brāhmaṇe taskare tathā||
translation: Given to a worthy recipient or taken unjustly, charity is not useless, but when given to an unworthy person or stolen by a brahmin, it is.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: From the unmanifest, all phenomena emerge in the day and dissolve back into it at night, in that designated as the unmanifest; separate from this, there exists another unmanifest reality, eternal, which pervades all beings and does not perish or decay. That unmanifest reality is called indestructible and is considered the supreme destination.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: Like how [one] speaks to a beloved woman.

sloka: sattvasaktamatiḥ kṛṣṇe dahyamano mahārogaiḥ na vivedātmano gatram tartatyalhada saṃstitaḥ
translation: With a mind focused on Krishna, not recognizing the distinction between self and body , being consumed by great afflictions , the sage remains steadfast , undisturbed .

sloka: pañcaiva mahāyajñāḥ| tānyeva mahāsattrāṇi bhūtayajño manuṣyayajñaḥ pitṛyajño devayajño brahmayajña iti
translation: The five great sacrifices, indeed, are the sacred rituals known as bhutayajna (for all creatures), manushyayajna (for humans), pitryajna (for ancestors), devayajna (for gods), and brahmayajna (for study of Vedas).

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: Five are the duties of a householder: sweeping, cleaning, making offerings, and taking care of the grinding stone and water pot, which are to be bound while transporting.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti
translation: Now, the five sacrificial offerings: the god-worshipping sacrifice, the creature-welfare sacrifice, the ancestor-offering sacrifice, the Brahman-worshipping sacrifice, and the human-welfare sacrifice.

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: Performs the fifth Great Sacrifice with attachment to its true purpose.

sloka: pitṛyajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatpitṛbhyaḥ svadhā karotyapyapastatpitṛyajñaḥ saṃtiṣṭhateiti | tatra piṇḍadānāsaṃbhave jalamātramapi pitṛbhyaḥ svadhā'stviti svadhāśabdena yaddadāti so'yaṃ pitṛyajñaḥ
translation: The definition of the pitr yajna sacrifice is described: that which offers oblations (svadha) to the pitrs, even if it is only water, is called a pitr yajna. This (ayam) is that pitr yajna, when there is no offering of a pindadaan, as stated by the term "svadha".

sloka: vaiśvadevānuṣṭhānādūrdhvaṃ bahirdeśe vāyasādibhyo bhūtebhyo yadbalipradānaṃ so'yaṃ bhūtayajña:
translation: The ritual of Vaishvadeva, when performed properly and exceeding it, is the worship of beings headed by Vayu (the god of wind) that occurs outside [of the home]; this is called the sacrifice to living beings.

sloka: yajñaḥ kasmāt | prakhyātaṃ yajatikarma iti nairuktāḥ | yācñaḥ bhavati iti vā | yajurunnaḥ bhavati iti vā | bahukṛṣṇājinaḥ iti aupamanyavaḥ | yajūṃṣi enaṃ nayanti iti vā |
translation: Why is a yajña (sacrifice) performed? According to the Nairuktas, it is known as "yajatikarma" (ritualistic act). Alternatively, according to the Yajurveda scholars, it becomes "yajuḥ-unnaḥ" (the recitation of Yajurveda). The Aupamanyava scholars consider it as a ritual performed by someone who is dressed in many black deer skins, and the Jaiminiya scholars bring the yajūṃṣi (Yajurveda) to this.

sloka: yajati codanādravyadevatākriyaṃ samudāye kṛtārthatvāt
translation: Performing the ritual, with all necessary components and directed towards the chosen deity, is efficacious.

sloka: yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ| yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ dravyaṃ devatā tyāgaḥ
translation: We will explain the ritual sacrifice ; it consists of physical components , divine entities , and offering .

sloka: yajñaḥ |
translation: Sacrifice or ritual.

sloka: suvṛttasya śarīrantu vyadhamanmukhavāyunā | svayameva jagatmraṣṭā dakṣiṇāgnistato'bhavat ||kanakasya śarīrantu dhmāpayāmāsa keśavaḥ | tato'bhūdgārhapatyāgniḥ pañcavaitānabhojanaḥ ||ghorasya tu vapuḥ śambhurdhmāpayāmāsa vai svayam | tata āhavanīyo'gnistatkṣaṇāt samajāyata ||etaistribhirjagat vyāptaṃ trimūlaṃ sakalaṃ jagat | etat yatra trayaṃ nityaṃ tiṣṭhati dbijasattamāḥ |
translation: The sustainer of the world became, in person, the purifier of the body of the virtuous. Then, Keśava manifested the domestic fire and the fivefold meal. Shambhu himself became the purifier of the terrible's form, and immediately the āhavanīya fire was born. With these three, the whole world is pervaded, the triple root of all worldly existence. Where the best of seeds always reside, there eternally abides the trimūla.

sloka: evaṃ yajñavarāhasya śarīraṃ yajñatāmagāt | yajñarūpeṇa sakalamāpyāyitumidaṃ jagat ||
translation: In this way, the whole universe is nourished by assuming the form of the sacrificial ritual, referring to the body of the best of sacrifices (i.e., Lord Vishvarupa).

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: The act of offering property through the designation of a deity as yajna is called homa, where the property is placed in the fire.

sloka: upaviṣṭahomā svāhākārapradānā juhotayaḥ
translation: Seated for the sacrificial ritual, offer oblations with the Svaha chant and accompanying gestures.

sloka: savaṣaṭkārāsu tiṣṭhandakṣiṇata udaṅprāṅ vaṣaṭkṛte
translation: In the sacrificial formulas of six kinds, standing (as the priest) to the south or facing north, uttering the vaṣaṭ call.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four ritual priests - the invoker , the overseer of the rituals , the Brahman priest , and the igniter of the fire - have roles in the new moon and full moon rituals, known as darśapūrṇamāsa.

sloka: pākayajñānyajennityaṃ haviryajñāṃśca nityaśaḥ | somāṃśca vidhipūrveṇa ya iccheddharmamavyayam|
translation: One who always performs the cooking sacrifices and other daily rituals with offerings should choose to establish the imperishable religious duty in accordance with the ancient ordinance, including the offering of soma.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛksāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The combination of fees, sacrificial ingredients (such as grains and vegetables), hymns from the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Sāmaveda for the priests is called a yajña.

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: This indeed is the unworthy one who sacrifices for his wife's sake.

sloka: vrīhīnyavānvā haviṣi
translation: A sacrifice with either barley or sesame seeds.

sloka: pāṇigrahaṇādiragnistamaupāsanamityācakṣate tasmingṛhyāṇi karmāṇi kriyante tasyaupāsanenāhitāgnitvaṃ
translation: The scripture states that the ritualistic worship, starting from grasping with the hand, is called upasana. The associated rituals are performed relying on the power of this upasana, leading to the absence of agni's (fire's) separateness.

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: Included in that are the seven domestic sacrifices: Aupasana, Homo, Vaisvadeva, Parvana, Masthaka, Maasi Shraddha, Sarpa Bali, and Rishabha Bali.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: Now, one should perform the five sacrificial offerings: the divine sacrifice is what is offered in the fire, the nourishment sacrifice is what is given in the form of food, the ancestral sacrifice is what is given to the ancestors, the brahminical sacrifice is what is studied and taught through the Vedas, and the human sacrifice is what is given to other humans. This is how one should carry out these various sacrifices.

sloka: vidārite varāhasya kāye bhargeṇa tatkṣaṇāt | brahmaviṣṇuśivā devāḥ sarvaiśca pramathaiḥ saha | ninyurjalāt samuddhṛtya tat śarīraṃ nabhaḥ prati | tadvibhejuḥ śarīrantu viṣṇoścakreṇa khaṇḍaśaḥ | tasyāṅga sandhito yajñājātāste vai pṛthakpṛthak | yasmād yasmācca ye yajñāstat śṛṇvantu maharṣayaḥ| bhrūnāsāsandhinā jāto jyotiṣṭomo mahādhvaraḥ | hanuśravaṇasandhyostu vahniṣṭomo vyajāyata | cakṣurbhruvoḥ sandhinā tu vrātyastomo vyajāyata | āyuḥ paugarbhavastomastasya potroṣṭha sandhinā | vṛddhastoma vṛhatstomau jihvāmūlādvyajāyata | atirātraṃ savairājamadhojihvāntarādabhūt | adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pidvayajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo valibhauto nṛyajño'tidhipajatam | snānaṃ tarpaṇaparvyantaṃ nityayajñāśca sāṃśaḥ | kaṇṭhasandheḥ samutpannā jihvāto vidhayastathā | yavājimedho mahāmedho naramedhastathaiva ca | prāṇihiṃsākarā ye'nye te kṣātāḥ pādasandhitaḥ | rājasūyo'tha kārīrī vājapeyastathaivaca | pṛṣṭhasandhau samutpannā grahayajñāstathaiva ca |
translation: In the immediate past, gods (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva and others) along with all the evil forces, took hold of the body of Varaha (boar incarnation of Lord Vishnu) from the water, part by part, each named after a specific deity or ritual. The parts of Varaha's body, connected to different rituals, were lifted out of the water and placed in their respective positions. Jyotishtoma is related to the forehead, Vahniṣṭoma to the ears, Vrātyastoma to the eyes and eyebrows. Ayushtoma is connected to the nose and mouth, while Atiratra has its origin from the middle of the tongue. The rituals Adhayajna and Pidvyajna are derived from different parts of the lower jaw. The ritual known as Nṛyajña was born from between the teeth and gums. Tarpanaparvani, Snāti, Nitya, and other daily rituals emerged from various parts of the throat. Grahayajña originated from the back. Yavājima, Mahāmedha, Naramedha and other great sacrifices are connected to different parts of the limbs. The remaining rituals arise from various other parts of the body.

sloka: evaṃ yaḥ sarvabhūtāni brāhmaṇo nityaṃ arcati | sa gacchati paraṃ sthānaṃ tejomūrtiḥ pathā rjunā | | | |
translation: In this way, the brahmin who constantly worships all beings goes to the abode of light.

sloka: agnau gurāvātmani ca sarvabhūteṣvadhokṣajam | bhūtaiḥ svadhāmabhiḥ paśyedapraviṣṭaṃ praviṣṭavat || || evaṃ vidho brahmacārī vānaprastho yatirgṛhī | caran viditavijñānaḥ paraṃ brahmādhigacchati || ||
translation: The brahmachari, vanaprasthi, and yati, who, in the fire and in themselves sees the imperceptible as present in all beings, discerns the inner self of beings through their inherent nature, understands the pervading consciousness that has entered or not entered - such a one with acquired knowledge attains the supreme Brahman.

sloka: ya॒masya̭ mā ya॒myaṃ kāma॒ āga̭ntsamā॒ne yonaṷ saha॒śeyyā̭ya | jā॒yeva॒ patyḙ ta॒nva̭ṃ riricyā॒ṃ vi ci̭dvṛheva॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: For the one who aspires to master yoga in this very life, it is necessary to join the battlefield of the body and engage in the yoga of action. This requires practicing self-control and discipline, just like preparing for a chariot race or warfare.

sloka: na ti̭ṣṭhanti॒ na ni mi̭ṣantye॒te de॒vānā॒ṃ spaśa̭ i॒ha ye cara̭nti | a॒nyena॒ madā̭hano yāhi॒ tūya॒ṃ tena॒ vi vṛ̭ha॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: Those who behave improperly in this world neither delight the gods nor do the gods favor them. Go to conquer them with your own power, increasing your prowess and valor as if going to battle.

sloka: ā ghā॒ tā ga̭cchā॒nutta̭rā yu॒gāni॒ yatra̭ jā॒maya̭: kṛ॒ṇava॒nnajā̭mi | upa̭ barbṛhi vṛṣa॒bhāya̭ bā॒huma॒nyami̭cchasva subhage॒ pati॒ṃ mat ||
translation: O fortunate one, approach the sacred yugas (ages) where the Creator dwells, like a mendicant approaching a patron. Seek to become the companion of the mighty Bull, the divine bringer of prosperity.

sloka: na vā ṷ te ta॒nvā̭ ta॒nvaṃ saṃ pa̭pṛcyāṃ pā॒pamā̭hu॒ryaḥ svasā̭raṃ ni॒gacchā̭t | a॒nyena॒ matpra॒muda̭: kalpayasva॒ na te॒ bhrātā̭ subhage vaṣṭye॒tat ||
translation: Need not your current enemy, approaching to cause harm, seek to attack your sister-in-law. With something else, mentally imagine a plan for yourself. Your brother, fortunate one, should not be harmed in this way.

sloka: ayane viṣuve caiva ṣaḍaśītimukheṣu ca| candrasūryoparāge ca dattamakṣayamucyate||
translation: At the beginning of both the solar and lunar halves of the month, as well as on the sixteenth day, a gift is said to be imperishable.

sloka: śatamindukṣaye dānaṃ sahasrantu dinakṣaye | viṣuve śatasahasraṃ vyatīpātetvantakam ||
translation: A hundred coins in the destruction of a small piece of moonstone, a thousand at the setting of the sun, ten times that amount in a universal deluge, and an infinite sum to avert catastrophe.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Having offered libations of sweet milk to the Kṛttikā stars, the most fortunate one should appease the worthy Brahmanas and only then can attain the highest goals.

sloka: āhāraṃ maithunaṃ nidrāṃ sandhyākāle tu varjjayet | karma cādhyayanañcaiva tathā dānapratigrahau |
translation: At dawn and dusk, one should avoid eating, sexual activities, and sleeping; similarly, studying and accepting/giving charity should also be abstained.

sloka: tato'bhūttrivṛdaoṃkāro yo'vyaktaprabhavaḥ svarāṭyattalliṅgaṃ bhagavato brahmaṇaḥ paramātmanaḥ ||
translation: The one who is the self-existent sound vibration (OM) that manifested before the creation of the three modes of material nature, and is the subtle form of the Lord's divine transcendental body.

sloka: svadhāmno brāhmaṇaḥ sākṣādvācakaḥ paramātmanaḥ sa sarvamantropaniṣadvedabījaṃ sanātanam ||
translation: The brahmin is the direct revealer of his own essential nature, the eternal seed of all mantras and Upanishads.

sloka: tenāsau caturo vedāṃścaturbhirvadanairvibhuḥ savyāhṛtikānsaoṃkārāṃścāturhotravivakṣayā || ||
translation: By that one, the four Vedas are fully known through the four mouths (of Brahma); the all-pervading (Brahma) has the subtle sounds of oṃkara for the purpose of performing fire rituals.

sloka: te paramparayā prāptāstattacchiṣyairdhṛtavrataiḥ caturyugeṣvatha vyastā dvāparādau maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: These ultimate teachings/precepts , having come in a continuous lineage, have been distributed by the great sages during the Dvāpara age , studied by their worthy disciples in each of the four ages .

sloka: parāśarātsatyavatyāmaṃśāṃśakalayā vibhuḥ avatīrṇo mahābhāga vedaṃ cakre caturvidham || asmin yuge kṛto vyāsaḥ pārāśaryaḥ parantapaḥ| dvaipāyana iti khyāto viṣṇoraṃśaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||
translation: In this age, the almighty and powerful Vyasa, who is a portion of Lord Vishnu, was born from Parashara and Satyavati. He has composed the fourfold Vedas. Previously known as Dvaipayana, he is celebrated for his severe austerities.

sloka: tatrargvedadharaḥ pailaḥ sāmago jaiminiḥ kaviḥ | vaiśaṃpāyana evaiko niṣṇāto yajuṣāmuta || || atharvāṅ‌girasāmāsīt sumanturdāruṇo muniḥ |
translation: In that place, Paila is the holder of the Rigveda, Jaimini the poet of the Sama Veda; Vaisampayana alone is proficient in the Yajur Veda; Sumantu Dāruṇi, the sage, has mastered both the Atharva and Angirasa Vedas.

sloka: pādenārthena copetā vṛttabaddhā mantrā ṛcaḥ| gītirūpā mantrāḥ sāmāni| vṛttagītivarjitatvena praśliṣṭapaṭhitā mantrā yajūṃṣi|
translation: Chanted with meaning, hymns and mantras are attached to their traditional procedures; songs and mantras resembling the form of a song are disconnected from the traditional procedures, except for the Yajuṣ mantras.

sloka: śabdātirikta śabdopajīvipramāṇātiriktaṃ ca yatpramāṇaṃ tajjanyapramitiviṣayānatiriktārthako yo yastadanyatve sati āmuṣmikasukhajanakoccāraṇakatve sati janyajñānājanyo yo pramāṇaśabdastattvaṃ vedatvam iti ca prācīnastallakṣaṇamuktam |
translation: The ancient definition states that the means of knowledge that is separate from words and their meanings, and is related to the origination of knowledge from its objects, is called "veda" . When this is distinct from other things, it leads to self-knowledge and the creation of happiness and dispelling of sorrow. This is the definition given by the ancients.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: You, who nourishes the ṛcas (Vedic hymns), are praised by the growing (learned) ones in the assemblies of Śakvarī. Brahmā speaks to you of the true knowledge, and you have measured out the measure of the yajña.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda ātharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśirdaivo
translation: The name is Rigveda for the first, Yajurveda for the second, Sama Veda for the third and Atharvana for the fourth; the fifth is called Itihasa-Purana, while the ancients knew it as the knowledge of lineage and gods.

sloka: purāṇaṃ pañcamo veda iti brahmānuśāsanam
translation: The fifth Veda is known as the Purana, as declared by Brahma.

sloka: ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvākhyā vedāścatvāra uddhṛtāḥ | itihāsapurāṇaṃ ca pañcamo veda ucyate || ||
translation: The four Vedas, namely Rig, Yajur, Sama, and Atharva, are known as extracted; the fifth is called Veda, encompassing itihasa and purana.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca | taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭamaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇam | viṣīdantamidaṃ vākyamuvāca madhusūdanaḥ || ||
translation: Sanjaya, with pity filling his eyes with tears, spoke to him in that very state. Madhusudana said these words to the downcast one.

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | kutastvā kaśmalamidaṃ viṣame samupasthitam | anāryajuṣṭamasvargyamakīrtikaramarjuna || ||
translation: The Blessed One said: Whence has this impurity befallen you, O Arjuna, in this critical situation? It is unbefitting of a noble person and leads to ill fame.

sloka: kla‍aibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate | kṣudraṃ hṛdayadaurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa || ||
translation: Don't indulge in cowardice, O Partha, this doesn't fit you. Cast aside this small-hearted weakness and rise, scorcher of foes.

sloka: arjuna uvāca | kathaṃ bhīṣmamahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ prati yotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana || ||
translation: Arjuna said, "How should I fight against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of worship in battle, with arrows, O Madhusudana?"

sloka: gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyamapīha loke | hatvārthakāmāṃstu gurūnihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhirapradigdhān || ||
translation: To attain great prosperity, should one harm the venerable teachers, they themselves can enjoy worldly pleasures stained with blood? Or is it to beg and partake in the good fortune of the teachers that leads to greater benefit?

sloka: na caitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo yadvā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ || ||
translation: We do not know which is superior; whether we will win or they will conquer us. If we were to kill them, we would not wish to live. So, the Dhartarastras stand in front of us, resolute.

sloka: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ | yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṃ brūhi tanme śiṣyaste'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam || ||
translation: I, confused about duty and with a nature overtaken by miserliness, ask you - please tell me decisively what is the best course of action for me, for I am your student and have taken refuge in you.

sloka: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyādya cchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāvasapatnamṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇāmapi cādhipatyam || ||
translation: I truly do not see anyone who could destroy my pleasure and pain of the senses right now. Even after attaining a prosperous and unrivaled kingdom on earth, (I do not see) one who could rule over even the gods.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca evamuktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa | na yotsya iti govindamuktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha || ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Speaking thus to Hrishikesa, the subduer of the senses, and to Gudakesha, the destroyer of afflictions, "I will not fight," he became silent, O Govinda.

sloka: tamuvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasanniva bhārata | senayorubhayormadhye viṣīdantamidaṃ vacaḥ || ||
translation: The Lord Hrishikesha, looking amused, spoke to the downhearted commander positioned between both armies.

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | aśocyānanvaśocastvaṃ prajñāvādāṃśca bhāṣase | gatāsūnagatāsūṃśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ || ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: Why do you lament for what is unworthy of grief? You speak words of wisdom. Those who are truly wise do not grieve for the departed or for those who are yet to be born.

sloka: na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param || ||
translation: Surely I did not exist before, nor did you, nor any of these rulers of people. And none of us will exist after this.

sloka: dehino'sminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā | tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati || ||
translation: The embodied being in this body experiences childhood, youth, and old age; similarly, upon leaving one body, it attains another - the wise are not confused by this.

sloka: mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ | āgamāpāyino'nityāstāṃstitikṣasva bhārata || ||
translation: Endure, O Kaunteya, the contact of the senses with objects, which are sources of cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as they are transient and ephemeral, O Bharata.

sloka: yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha | samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so'mṛtatvāya kalpate || ||
translation: The one who is not troubled by these (experiences of) happiness and suffering, steadfast, O best among men – such a person is deemed to be immortal.

sloka: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayorapi dṛṣṭo'ntastvanayostattvadarśibhiḥ || ||
translation: For those who truly perceive reality, it is undeniable that being does not arise from non-being, nor does non-being arise from being. This truth is revealed to those who carefully examine both.

sloka: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino'prameyasya tasmādyudhyasva bhārata || ||
translation: These bodies are temporary, but the one who dwells within is eternal. Since the imperishable consciousness is unchanging and infinite, strive to realize it, O Bharata.

sloka: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate || ||
translation: The one who recognizes the killer in this [referring to the soul or a living being], and the one who considers it killed - both of them do not understand. This [soul] does not kill, nor is it killed.

sloka: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācinnāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato'yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre || ||
translation: Never is this undecaying, eternal, imperishable, and ancient one born or dies. Even when the body is slain, it does not perish.

sloka: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam |kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam || ||
translation: How, O Partha, can a person harm/destroy that which is indestructible and eternal - the Vedas' knowledge , which is being sustained forever and is destructible neither by anyone ?

sloka: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇānyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī || ||
translation: Just as a person discards old clothes and accepts new ones, similarly the embodied soul casts off old bodies and enters into new ones.

sloka: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṃ kledayantyāpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ || || acchedyo'yamadāhyo'yamakledyo'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo'yaṃ sanātanaḥ || ||
translation: This cannot be cut by weapons, burned by fire, wetted by water, or dried by wind. It is impervious, eatable, cannot be wetted, dried, or withered. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, and immovable, and ancient.

sloka: avyakto'yamacintyo'yamavikāryo'yamucyate | tasmādevaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitumarhasi || ||
translation: "This indescribable and unchanging entity is referred to as the 'avyakta'. Since it is incomprehensible, you should not grieve upon understanding it."

sloka: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyurdhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmādaparihārye'rthe na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: For the one who has taken birth, death is certain; and for the one who has died, birth is certain again. Therefore, you should not mourn over something that is unavoidable.

sloka: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata | avyaktanidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā || ||
translation: What is the cause for lamentation, O Bharata, that the physical phenomena, which arise from the unmanifest and merge back into it, are manifest in the middle phase?

sloka: āścaryavatpaśyati kaścidena māścaryavadvadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścaryavaccainamanyaḥ śa‍ṛṇoti śrutvāpyenaṃ veda na caiva kaścit || ||
translation: Some see the wondrous as common, while another describes it thus; yet others hear of it as astonishing, but none truly understand and know it.

sloka: dehī nityamavadhyo'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata| tasmātsarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: The indestructible conscious entity within this body , which is eternal and invulnerable, O Bharata , should not be caused for sadness . All beings therefore, should not grieve over it .

sloka: svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi | dharmyāddhi yuddhācchreyo'nyatkṣatriyasya na vidyate || ||
translation: Even after considering your own duty, you should not hesitate. For a warrior, there is nothing more auspicious than righteous warfare.

sloka: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddhamīdṛśam || ||
translation: A battle of this kind is obtained by chance, obstructing the heavenly path, and Kshatriyas, O Partha, attain happiness by it.

sloka: atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: If you do not initiate this righteous battle, then abandoning your own duty and reputation, you will incur sin.

sloka: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtirmaraṇādatiricyate || ||
translation: Even the beings will speak of (one's) uncelebrated deeds, but the fame of a deserving person is rarely diminished, even after death.

sloka: bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ | yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam || ||
translation: Fearing battle, the mighty charioteers will think of you as frightened. Having become greatly valued by them, you will set out lightly.

sloka: avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantastava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim || ||
translation: Even many will speak inappropriate words about you, and they will criticize your capabilities. What could be more miserable than this?

sloka: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmāduttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ || ||
translation: Even if defeated, you will attain heaven; victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, O Kaunteya, resolutely decide to engage in battle.

sloka: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, and victory and defeat as equal, prepare yourself for battle. In this way, you will not incur sin.

sloka: eṣā te'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi || ||
translation: This is the discriminative wisdom spoken of in the Sankhya system, O Partha; hear of the wisdom that, when engaged with, will allow you to cast off the bondage of actions.

sloka: nehābhikramanāśo'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpamapyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt || ||
translation: Here, there is no downfall of efforts nor is there any setback; a slight observance of this duty saves one from great fear.

sloka: vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana | bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo'vyavasāyinām || ||
translation: In this world, oh Kurunandana, the intellect of some is firmly determined, while others have many-branched and endless thoughts that are indecisive.

sloka: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām | kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati || || bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate || ||
translation: For those self-motivated by desires and focused on heaven, who grant the results of actions as the means of birth; who are attached to and influenced by abundant enjoyments and power, their resolute intellect does not become established in samadhi.

sloka: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān || || yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake | tāvānsarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ || || karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karmaphalaheturbhūrmā te saṅgo'stvakarmaṇi || ||
translation:
To the seeker who understands the meaning, the Vedas discuss the three gunas. You can become transcendent to these gunas, O Arjuna. Being without duality, ever established in pure consciousness, free from concern for gain and loss, such a self-disciplined person sees inaction in action and action in inaction.

Just as a fire, when it is surrounded by fuel on all sides, blazes up, so does knowledge of all the Vedas arise in the Brahmin who knows the meaning.

As for your duty, perform it without attachment to its fruits, never letting the desire for reward drive you. Seeking no fruit, unburdened by possessions, do your duty and avoid becoming attached to it.

sloka: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim‌ || ||
translation: Arjuna said: "How does the self-controlled one speak, O Keshava, and how does he sit in meditation? How does he move around, and how does he remain stable, O Lord of steadiness?"

sloka: bhagavañjāyate tīvraṃ cintayānasya suvrata || karmapākaphalaṃ yasminmānuṣairupabhujyate|||| ñāē īṁ ā || āṁ āṣē||||
translation: The blessed one is born through deep contemplation, O vows-keeper; the result of actions that can be enjoyed by humans is experienced in him.

sloka: ṛṣiruddālakirdīkṣāmupagamya tataḥ sutam| tvaṃ māmupacarasveti nāciketamabhāṣata||
translation: Having approached me after completing the fire ritual taught by Uddalaka, the sage then said to his son Nachiketa: "You should serve me."

sloka: tadā kṣamasveti prārthayamānasyaiva tasya nāciketasya deho gatasatvo bhūmau nyapatat patitaṃ sutaṃ dṛṣṭvā pitāpi kiṃ mayānuṣṭhitaṃ pāpeneti bruvan bhūmau nipapāta
translation: Then, as Naciketas's body and soul fell to the ground, his father, seeing him lying there, lamented, "What have I done through my ignorance!"

sloka: na dṛṣyate mānuṣaṃ te vapuḥ
translation: Your human form is not to be seen (by me).

sloka: yasminvṛkṣe supalāśe devaiḥ sampibate yamaḥ | atrā no viśpati: pitā purāṇā~ anu venati ||
translation: In which sacred fig tree, Supalaśa, Yama offers oblations to the gods; there, our ancient Lord and Father, reverently pays his respects.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: Who, then, is the enemy (vṛtraḥ) referred to as "megha" by the grammarian tradition and as "Twashtri" in mythological stories? The fusion of water and light gives rise to the rain-bringing function. In this context, the colors of the battle are determined by a comparison with that particular deed.

sloka: jaṭādhīstīvratapā brahmavādisabhāpatiḥ aṅkīkṛtya sriyaṃ cāste gatahrīḥ prākṛte yathā prāyaśaḥ prākṛtāścāpi sriyaṃ rahasi bibhrati | ayaṃ mahāvratadharo bibhrarti sadasi sriyam
translation: The lord of the assembly of Brahma and others, who is extremely ascetic with matted hair, after adorning himself with his own natural splendor, typically carries it in private. This upholder of great vows displays his splendor in public.

sloka: nāyamarhati vaikuṇṭha pādamūlopasarpaṇam sambhāvitamatiḥ stabdhaḥ sādhubhiḥ paryupāsitam ataḥ pāpīyasīṃ yonimāsurīṃ yāhi durmate yatheha bhūyo na kartā putra kilbiṣamjajñe tvaṣṭurdakṣiṇādnau dānavīṃ yonimāśritaḥ vṛtra ityabhivikhyāto jñānavijñānasaṃyutaḥ
translation: A steadfast mind, endowed with good qualities, does not consider themselves worthy of attaining the abode of Vaikuntha, nor approaching its threshold. Therefore, O wicked one, go to the demoniac womb of Tvashtra, born from the sinful creation, who, after being named Vritra, became known for his knowledge and wisdom.

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Perceiving the still expanse of the sky, Indra causes it to rain gently upon the seven points of the compass, as if with his thunderbolt, but in a subtler form.

sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: Supreme among bodies of water, purifiers dwelling in the middle of salilas (fluids or waters), may Indra, the thunderbolt-wielding bull, roar for us. May those waters, the divine goddess, be present here and protect me.

sloka: i॒damasmi॒ tatte॒ pra dāsyā॒mīti॒ tvī
translation: I am present here, ready to give you (this).

sloka: āhāranidrābhayamaithunaṃ ca samānametatpaśubhirnarāṇām | dharmo hi teṣāmadhiko viśeṣo dharmeṇa hīnāḥ paśubhiḥ samānāḥ ||
translation: The equal behaviors of eating, sleeping, fearing, and mating are shared by both humans and animals. However, the quality that distinguishes humans from animals is their adherence to dharma. Those lacking in dharma are comparable to animals.

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, cleanliness, and sense-restraint; these, Manu declared, constitute the integrated conduct (dharma) for the four social classes.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten characteristics of dharma are: steadfastness, forgiveness, self-control, honesty, cleanliness, sense restraint, intelligence, knowledge, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: na rājyaṃ na rājā'sīnna daṇḍayo na ca dāṇḍika: dharmeṇaiva prajāssarvā rakṣanti sma parasparam
translation: Not by ruling a kingdom nor by being a king, nor through punishments or by being an executioner, do all subjects protect each other; but only through righteousness.

sloka: prajanārthaṃ striyaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ saṃtānārthaṃ ca mānavaḥ | tasmātsādhāraṇo dharmaḥ śrutau patnyā sahoditaḥ | | | |
translation: Created for the welfare of offspring, women have been fashioned; for the continuation of lineage, humans exist. Therefore, a common duty (dharma) for both husband and wife, as heard in the scriptures, has been laid down.

sloka: dharme cārthe ca kāme ca nāticaritavyā tvayeyam |
translation: In duty, (and) in prosperity, and in desire, this should not be transgressed by you.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Self-control, restraint, austerity, purification, forgiveness, honesty, and indeed, knowledge, understanding, faith – these are the inherent qualities of Brahman's actions.

sloka: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Valor, brilliance, steadiness, and tactical expertise in battle, as well as generosity and the innate nature of rulership – these are the natural duties of a kshatriya.

sloka: kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Farming, cattle rearing, and trade are the inherent duties of a vaishya, while service is the inherent duty of a shudra.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucaṃ indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyaṃ akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten characteristics of dharma are: steadfastness, forgiveness, self-control, honesty, purity, sense restraint, intelligence, knowledge, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: īśā vāsyamidaṃ sarvaṃ yatkiṃ ca jagatyāṃ jagat | tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam || ||
translation: Let one enjoy this entire world, which is owned by the Lord, through renunciation, and let one not have greed for another's wealth.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation: Trees bear fruit for the benefit of others, rivers flow for the benefit of others, and cows yield milk for the benefit of others. This body too is meant for serving others' welfare. Speak the truth, follow dharma, do not be negligent in your studies, and don't be remiss in attending to your teacher. Do not squander wealth that has been given to you for the maintenance of your family. Never be negligent in speaking the truth, following dharma, pursuing what is auspicious, or protecting wealth. Never be neglectful in your studies and teachings.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: One must not be negligent toward the duties of the gods and ancestors. Consider them as your mother, father, teacher, and guest. Perform only those actions that are blameless. Do not neglect knowledge for the pursuit of pleasure, nor should one who seeks pleasure abandon knowledge. Those actions of ours that are pure should be devoted to; nothing else should be pursued. For the seeker of happiness, where is there learning? And for the learner, where is happiness? The seeker of happiness should give up learning; the learner should give up happiness.

sloka: vivītasthalakedāraṣaṇḍakhalaveśmavāhanakoṣṭhānāṃ pūrvaṃpūrvaṃ ābādhaṃ saheta || || samāhartṛvannāgariko nagaraṃ cintayet || || daśakulīṃ gopo viṃśatikulīṃ catvāriṃśatkulīṃ vā || || sa tasyāṃ strīpuruṣāṇāṃ jātigotranāmakarmabhiḥ jaṅghaagraṃ āyavyayau ca vidyāt || || evaṃ durgacaturbhāgaṃ sthānikaścintayet || ||
translation: The superintendent of the treasury, while regularly examining the deposits in various categories of coins, should carefully take note of any damage from the beginning. Similarly, he should ponder over the city with its public and private buildings, considering them as divided into ten, twenty, or thirty wards. In this context, he should be aware of the caste, lineage, name, and occupation of the men and women at the head of each ward. Likewise, he should examine the fortress, dividing it into four parts.

sloka: bhūtapūrvaṃ abhūtapūrvaṃ vā janapadaṃ paradeśaapavāhanena svadeśaabhiṣyandavamanena vā niveśayet || ||
translation: Whether by conquering or by befriending a people of a foreign land, one should establish themselves there, either for the first time or having done so before.

sloka: anyonyaārakṣaṃ niveśayet || ||
translation: Set up mutual protection with each other.

sloka: aṣṭaśatagrāmyā madhye sthānīyam | catuhśatagrāmyā droṇamukham | dviśatagrāmyāḥ kārvaṭikam | daśagrāmīsaṃgraheṇa saṃgrahaṃ sthāpayet || ||
translation: In a group of 800, the central location should be designated; in a group of 400, Droṇa's face (i.e. the front); in a group of 200, Kārvaṭa; and through the combination of ten villages, an assembly should be established.

sloka: niveśasamakālaṃ yathāāgatakaṃ vā parihāraṃ dadyāt || ||
translation: At the time of settling, one should give back whatever was received, or more, as assistance.

sloka: hradasya vā aviśoṣasyāṅke |
translation: Of the water-reservoir, indeed, it is the un-dried edge.

sloka: vṛttaṃ dīrghaṃ caturaśraṃ vā
translation: A square-shaped enclosure, long in use , or a long and rectangular one can also be considered.

sloka: ṣaḍdaṇḍaucchritaṃ avaruddhaṃ taddviguṇaviṣkambham |
translation: Supported by six strong pillars, twice as high is that which has been constructed.

sloka: tasya parikhāstisro daṇḍaantarāḥ kārayetcaturdaśa dvādaśa daśaiti daṇḍānvistīrṇāḥ |
translation: His outer fence has three rods/posts that are each fourteen cubits long, and twelve more rods/posts, each ten cubits long.

sloka: trayaḥ prācīnā rājamārgāstraya udīcīnā iti vāstuvibhāgaḥ || ||
translation: Three royal roads are the eastern ones, and three others are the northern ones; such is the division of locations.

sloka: daśakulīvāṭaṃ kūpasthānaṃ || ||
translation: A toilet located at the intersection of ten families.

sloka: pitṝṇāṃ māsikaṃ śrāddhaṃ anvāhāryaṃ vidurbudhāḥ || ||
translation: Monthly commemorative rites for ancestors are to be performed by the learned and intelligent.

sloka: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā bhūtānyatithayastathā | āśāsate kuṭumbibhyastebhyaḥ kāryaṃ vijānatā || ||
translation: The rishis (sages), fathers, and gods, as well as guests, all expect appropriate actions from the family members who know their duties.

sloka: daivakāryāddvijātīnāṃ pitṛkāryaṃ viśiṣyate | daivaṃ hi pitṛkāryasya pūrvaṃ āpyāyanaṃ smṛtam
translation: The primary duty for a dvija is divine action; the duty to the ancestors is considered its preliminary nourishment. (Literally: "For dvijas, divine-action, of them ancillary one, ancestor-duty is remembered as earlier fulfillment.")

sloka: pitṛyajñaṃ tu nirvartya vipraścandrakṣaye'gnimān | piṇḍānvāhāryakaṃ śrāddhaṃ kuryānmāsānumāsikam || ||
translation: After performing the pitṛyajña ritual, a brahmin should maintain the sacred fire until the next new moon; he should offer oblations of rice balls and water to the ancestors during the fortnightly rituals.

sloka: kṛṣṇapakṣe daśamyādau varjayitvā caturdaśīm | śrāddhe praśastāstithayo yathaitā na tathetarāḥ
translation: On the dark fortnight's tenth day, having excluded the fourteenth day, the rites of Sraddha are performed by those who are well-versed in their observances; not so with others.

sloka: yukṣu kurvandinarkṣeṣu sarvānkāmānsamaśnute | ayukṣu tu pitṝnsarvānprajāṃ prāpnoti puṣkalām
translation: Able to act, one enjoys all desires among the constellations (i.e., in this lifetime); but without that ability, one's ancestors obtain abundant offspring after death.

sloka: yathā caivāparaḥ pakṣaḥ pūrvapakṣādviśiṣyate | tathā śrāddhasya pūrvāhṇādaparāhṇo viśiṣyate
translation: Just as one side prevails over the other in a debate, similarly, the pre-and post-offerings are what distinguish the rite of shraddha (Hindu ritual for deceased ancestors).

sloka: rātrau śrāddhaṃ na kurvīta rākṣasī kīrtitā hi sā | sandhyayorubhayoścaiva sūrye caivācirodite
translation: One should not perform the śrāddha ritual at night, for it is declared to be demonic. This applies to both sandhyas and in the presence of the rising sun.

sloka: anena vidhinā śrāddhaṃ trirabdasyeha nirvapet | hemantagrīṣmavarṣāsu pāñcayajñikamanvaham
translation: With this procedure, one should perform the śrāddha sacrifice three times in a day, as well as during the months of Hemanta and Grīṣma, along with the five daily yajña rituals.

sloka: kuryād āparapakṣīyaṃ māsi prauṣṭhapade dvijaḥ | śrāddhaṃ pitroryathāvittaṃ tad‍bandhūnāṃ ca vittavān || ||
translation: A twice-born (dvija) should perform additional duties in the prauṣṭha pada month, as well as offer shraddha rituals to pitrs with appropriate wealth, and share his wealth with his relatives.

sloka: saṃskārakālo jāyāyā apatyasyātmanastathā | pretasaṃsthā mṛtāhaśca karmaṇyabhyudaye nṛpa || ||
translation: At the time of a woman's delivery, as well as for the child's purification ceremonies and at death, the king should ensure proper rituals are performed.

sloka: kuryādaharahaḥ śrāddhaṃ annādyenodakena vā | payomūlaphalairvāpi pitṛbhyaḥ prītimāvahan || ||
translation: Perform the daily shraddha ceremony for the ancestors, using either food, water, or a mixture of payasam (a sweet made from milk and rice), fruit, and roots. May this bring them pleasure.

sloka: tilairvrīhiyavairmāṣairadbhirmūlaphalena vā | dattena māsaṃ tṛpyanti vidhivatpitaro nṛnām
translation: With sesame seeds, barley, rice, beans, water, roots, and fruits, given as prescribed, parents of people are satisfied in a month.

sloka: yadeva tarpayatyadbhiḥ pitṝnsnātvā dvijottamaḥ | tenaiva kṛtsnaṃ āpnoti pitṛyajñakriyāphalam rājatairbhājanaireṣāṃ atho vā rajatānvitaiḥ | vāryapi śraddhayā dattaṃ akṣayāyopakalpate
translation: When a person of great learning (dvija uttama) satisfies the ancestors with ablutions, etc., then through that very act, he obtains all the results of the ancestral rites. Even if offered only a small amount with faith, it becomes infinite in effect for those who are endowed with silver or adorned with silver.

sloka: aparāhṇastathā darbhā vāstusaṃpādanaṃ tilāḥ | sṛṣṭirmṛṣṭirdvijāścāgryāḥ śrāddhakarmasu saṃpadaḥ
translation: At dusk, also the offering of darbha grass and preparation of the ritual site with rice grains; the best among the twice-born ones excel in performing Sraddha rituals.

sloka: api naḥ sa kule bhūyādyo no dadyāttrayodaśīm | pāyasaṃ madhusarpirbhyāṃ prākchāye kuñjarasya ca yatkiṃ cinmadhunā miśraṃ pradadyāttu trayodaśīm | tadapyakṣayaṃ eva syādvarṣāsu ca maghāsu ca
translation: Even if someone from our lineage were to arise and offer us a payasam (sweet rice pudding) or madhu-sarpirbhyam (honey and curd) mixed with madhu (honey) on the eleventh day,

sloka: yadyaddadāti vidhivatsamyakśraddhāsamanvitaḥ | tattatpitṝṇāṃ bhavati paratrānantamakṣayam
translation: When one gives according to proper procedure and complete devotion, that becomes an endless and infinite gift to the ancestors in the other world.

sloka: teṣāmārakṣabhūtaṃ tu pūrvaṃ daivaṃ niyojayet | rakṣāṃsi hi vipralumpanti śrāddhamārakṣavarjitam daivādyantaṃ tadīheta pitrādyantaṃ na tadbhavet | pitrādyantaṃ tvīhamānaḥ kṣipraṃ naśyati sānvayaḥ
translation: For those beings, previously a divinely ordained protector should be appointed; for without the performance of śrāddha, harmful entities cause decay. If one neglects the rituals for ancestral offerings, the lineage will quickly perish.

sloka: śuciṃ deśaṃ viviktaṃ ca gomayenopalepayet | dakṣināpravaṇaṃ caiva prayatnenopapādayet avakāśeṣu cokṣeṣu jalatīreṣu caiva hi | vivikteṣu ca tuṣyanti dattena pitaraḥ sadā
translation: Should purify a secluded location with cow dung and carefully establish south-facing water sources in all available open spaces; for, fathers are always pleased with gifts given in such solitary settings.

sloka: āsaneṣūpaklpteṣu barhiṣmatsu pṛthakpṛthak | upaspṛṣṭodakānsamyagviprāṃstānupaveśayet upaveśya tu tānviprānāsaneṣvajugupsitān | gandhamālyaiḥ surabhibhirarcayeddaivapūrvakam
translation: In the uneven seats, separately place the well-purified Brahmins along with their assigned waters, and worship them with fragrant garlands preceding a divine ritual, but never seat them in repugnant seats.

sloka: yeṣāmudakamānīya sapavitrāṃstilānapi | agnau kuryādanujñāto brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaiḥ saha
translation: The brahmin, authorized by other brahmins, should perform the agnihotra ritual using water from sacrificial tanks belonging to those who have controlled their senses and desires.

sloka: agneḥ somayamābhyāṃ ca kṛtvāpyāyanamāditaḥ | havirdānena vidhivatpaścātsaṃtarpayetpitṝn agnyabhāve tu viprasya pāṇāvevopapādayet | yo hyagniḥ sa dvijo viprairmantradarśibhirucyate na paitṛyajñiyo homo laukike'gnau vidhīyate | na darśena vinā śrāddhamāhitāgnerdvijanmanaḥ
translation: Having performed the offering to Agni and Soma, one should offer oblations with water and feed the ancestors; after that, the priest should make them consume (the offerings) with a sacred utterance. In the absence of a fire ritual, the life of a priest is given significance by the seers who recognize Agni as a dvija (twice-born). The domestic fire ritual is not performed in the ordinary fire; it is not prescribed for the Shraddha ceremony without Darsha (a type of grass) and the presence of a dvija.

sloka: apasavyamagnau kṛtvā sarvamāvṛtya vikramam | apasavyena hastena nirvapedudakaṃ bhuvi trīṃstu tasmāddhaviḥśeṣātpiṇḍānkṛtvā samāhitaḥ | audakenaiva vidhinā nirvapeddakṣiṇāmukhaḥ
translation: Having turned to the left, performed the ritual fire sacrifice, and covered all grounds of valor, with the left-hand scrape up water from the ground three times; then, having made offerings of the remaining rice grains, become focused. Only then, with full concentration, should one pour oblations with the right hand, facing south, as prescribed by the scriptural rule.

sloka: nyupya piṇḍāṃstatastāṃstu prayato vidhipūrvakam | teṣu darbheṣu taṃ hastaṃ nirmṛjyāllepabhāginām
translation: Having placed the ball-like offering there, and being fully focused, one should properly follow the prescribed practice. The hand is to be cleaned of remnants of ritual materials while placing it on those blades of darbha grass.
