sloka: ācamyodakparāvṛtya trirāyamya śanairasūn | ṣaḍṛtūṃśca namaskuryātpitṝneva ca mantravat
translation: Having sipped water and with controlled movements, one should pay respects to the six seasons and the ancestors as if reciting mantras.

sloka: udakaṃ ninayeccheṣaṃ śanaiḥ piṇḍāntike punaḥ | avajighrecca tānpiṇḍānyathānyuptānsamāhitaḥ piṇḍebhyastvalpikāṃ mātrāṃ samādāyānupūrvaśaḥ | tāneva viprānāsīnānvidhivatpūrvamāśayet
translation: Desiring to filter water, one should carefully, in a steady manner, remove the larger particles near the end of the process, adding back only the finer particles, following the traditional method; thus, the learned Brahmins should always follow this procedure.

sloka: dhriyamāṇe tu pitari pūrveṣāṃ eva nirvapet | vipravadvāpi taṃ śrāddhe svakaṃ pitaramāśayet pitā yasya nivṛttaḥ syājjīveccāpi pitāmahaḥ | pituḥ sa nāma saṅkīrtya kīrtayetprapitāmaham pitāmaho vā tacchrāddhaṃ bhuñjītetyabravīnmanuḥ | kāmaṃ vā samanujñātaḥ svayaṃ eva samācaret
translation: While the father is still alive, the eldest son should perform the ritual of offering food to the ancestors. If he desires, he himself may partake in it after offering it to his father, who has retired from worldly life, and also to his grandfather. The son should offer the oblations while pronouncing the names of his ancestors, starting with "father" and "grandfather." Manu said, "He may perform the ritual as he deems fit, after securing permission from them."

sloka: teṣāṃ dattvā tu hasteṣu sapavitraṃ tilodakam | tatpiṇḍāgraṃ prayaccheta svadhaiṣāmastviti bruvan
translation: Having given the sesame seed water as an offering in their hands , one should also offer the tip of the rice ball to them, saying "May your ancestral offerings be established " while they are still pure .

sloka: pāṇibhyāṃ tūpasaṃgṛhya svayamannasya vardhitam | viprāntike pitṝndhyāyanśanakairupanikṣipet ubhayorhastayormuktaṃ yadannamupanīyate | tadvipralumpantyasurāḥ sahasā duṣṭacetasaḥ
translation: After personally receiving the offered meal with his own hands and placing it before him, a brahmin, while performing the twilight rituals, should set down both [his own and the deity's] plates. If this is not done, asura beings with impure consciousness will instantly snatch away that food.

sloka: guṇāṃśca sūpaśākādyānpayo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu | vinyasetprayataḥ pūrvaṃ bhūmāveva samāhitaḥ
translation: Establishing first, in a concentrated state, milk, yogurt, ghee, and honey, in the proper order, beginning with supa and including other similar items, as well as those that possess qualities.

sloka: upanīya tu tatsarvaṃ śanakaiḥ susamāhitaḥ | pariveṣayeta prayato guṇānsarvānpracodayan
translation: Having taken that entire collection carefully prepared , one should diligently arrange to stimulate all qualities .

sloka: nāsramāpātayejjātu na kupyennānṛtaṃ vadet | na pādena spṛśedannaṃ na caitadavadhūnayet asraṃ gamayati pretānkopo'rīnanṛtaṃ śunaḥ | pādasparśastu rakṣāṃsi duṣkṛtīnavadhūnanam
translation: Never should one causing destruction to the hermitage ever. Nor should one get angry or speak untruth. One should not touch food with unwashed feet, nor cause harm to the water. The anger of the departed souls is not to be invited, nor should one trample upon sacred formulations. On the other hand, a mere touch by foot ensures protection against evil deeds and sinful activities.

sloka: yadyadroceta viprebhyastattaddadyādamatsaraḥ | brahmodyāśca kathāḥ kuryātpitṝṇāṃ etadīpsitam svādhyāyaṃ śrāvayetpitrye dharmaśāstrāṇi caiva hi | ākhyānānītihāsāṃśca purāṇāni khilāni ca harṣayedbrāhmaṇāṃstuṣṭo bhojayecca śanaiḥśanaiḥ | annādyenāsakṛccaitānguṇaiśca paricodayet
translation: Whatever the brahmins revere and choose to teach, let him first hear that and then make it his own. This is the desire of the ancestors. Let him also recite the scriptures related to dharma. By delighting and feeding the brāhmaṇas with delicious food and gradually with other items, let him uplift their qualities and inspire them with tales, stories, and even frivolous narratives.

sloka: vratasthamapi dauhitraṃ śrāddhe yatnena bhojayet | kutapaṃ cāsanaṃ dadyāttilaiśca vikirenmahīm trīṇi śrāddhe pavitrāṇi dauhitraḥ kutapastilāḥ | trīṇi cātra praśaṃsanti śaucamakrodhamatvarām
translation: Even the one who is firm in his vows, should carefully feed the son of his daughter during the shraddha ceremony. What a surprise it would be if he also offers a seat and water to her! The son of the daughter, the tilā, and the cleanliness that comes from self-control and absence of anger are praised as the three purifying elements in this shraddha ceremony.

sloka: brāhmaṇaṃ bhikṣukaṃ vāpi bhojanārthamupasthitam | brāhmaṇairabhyanujñātaḥ śaktitaḥ pratipūjayet
translation: A mendicant or a brahmin who has come for food should be respectfully received and offered hospitality by the brahmins , if he is capable and with their permission .

sloka: sārvavarṇikamannādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā | samutsṛjedbhuktavatāmagrato vikiranbhuvi
translation: Spreading out on the ground in front, it removes the water that has soaked into the universal form's every pore.

sloka: āsapiṇḍakriyākarma dvijāteḥ saṃsthitasya tu | adaivaṃ bhojayecchrāddhaṃ piṇḍam ekaṃ ca nirvapet sahapiṇḍakriyāyāṃ tu kṛtāyāmasya dharmataḥ | anayaivāvṛtā kāryaṃ piṇḍanirvapanaṃ sutaiḥ
translation: Even a twice-born who is established in performing the five great sacrifices must offer food and water at the time of their performance . Such is the established duty for one who has undertaken the vow . Only this is the obligation to perform the piṇḍanirvapanam for their ancestors .

sloka: pṛṣṭvā svaditam ityevaṃ tṛptānācāmayettataḥ | ācāntāṃścānujānīyādabhito ramyatam iti
translation: Having asked him to taste [the food], and hearing his approval, one should then permit the satisfied guest, with appropriate politeness, to partake of the remaining portions.

sloka: svadhāstvityeva taṃ brūyurbrāhmaṇāstadanantaram | svadhākāraḥ parā hyāṣīḥ sarveṣu pitṛkarmasu
translation: The brāhmaṇas should declare for him that [funerary offering) called svadhā; then comes the ritual [with] the svadhā-shape, which is supreme among all ancestral rites.

sloka: tato bhuktavatāṃ teṣāmannaśeṣaṃ nivedayet | yathā brūyustathā kuryādanujñātastato dvijaiḥ
translation: Once the distinguished ones among them have finished eating, they should present the remaining food as instructed, following precisely what has been said.

sloka: pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi
translation: In the context of ancestral rites, "svaditam" should be spoken of as "that which is sweet." In the context of a public gathering, "sushritam" is popular. At a religious ceremony, something "sampannam" (complete or perfect) is considered acceptable. And once again in the context of ancestral rites, "svaditam" should be spoken of as "that which is sweet."

sloka: visṛjya brāhmaṇāṃstāṃstu niyato vāgyataḥ śuciḥ | dakṣiṇāṃ diśamākāṅkṣanyācetemānvarānpitṝn dātāro no'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatireva ca | śraddhā ca no mā vyagamadbahudeyaṃ ca no'stviti
translation: Having abandoned the brahmanas who are those very ones , being self-controlled and pure , longing for the southern direction , let the givers of wealth to them increase ; indeed, may the Vedas endure eternally . And let our faith not be shaken , and let bountifulness come to us .

sloka: evaṃ nirvapaṇaṃ kṛtvā piṇḍāṃstāṃstadanantaram | gāṃ vipramajamagniṃ vā prāśayedapsu vā kṣipet piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ ke citparastādeva kurvate | vayobhiḥ khādayantyanye prakṣipantyanale'psu vā
translation: In this way, after settling the rice ball, one should offer it to a Brahmana or a cow, or throw it in the fire; some perform the offering of food to the departed ancestors at that time. Others feed the guests, while yet others throw the rice balls in the fire.

sloka: pativratā dharmapatnī pitṛpūjanatatparā | madhyamaṃ tu tataḥ piṇḍamadyātsamyaksutārthinī āyuṣmantaṃ sutaṃ sūte yaśomedhāsamanvitam | dhanavantaṃ prajāvantaṃ sāttvikaṃ dhārmikaṃ tathā prakṣālya hastāvācāmya jñātiprāyaṃ prakalpayet | jñātibhyaḥ satkṛtaṃ dattvā bāndhavānapi bhojayet
translation: The chaste wife, devoted to her husband, being ever engaged in the worship of her ancestors, should first offer them the prescribed portion of food, then offer food to her children and grandchildren, endowed with good qualities, fame, and intelligence. She should also offer food to her relatives and treat them with due respect.

sloka: uccheṣaṇaṃ tu tattiṣṭhedyāvadviprā visarjitāḥ | tato gṛhabaliṃ kuryāditi dharmo vyavasthitaḥ
translation: After offering the sacred grass (to a guest), one should make the guest rise; this is the established duty. Then, one should offer him the sacrificial food; such is the fixed dharma.

sloka: prācīnāvītinā samyagapasavyamatandriṇā | pitryam ā nidhanātkāryaṃ vidhivaddarbhapāṇinā
translation: Having properly and intensely reflected with a clear mind, one should perform the duty to the father that is due at the end of his life, in accordance with proper procedure, using sacred grass.

sloka: dvau daive pitṛkārye trīnekaikamubhayatra vā | bhojayetsusamṛddho'pi na prasajjeta vistare || || satkriyāṃ deśakālau ca śaucaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃpadaḥ | pañcaitānvistaro hanti tasmānneheta vistaram || ||
translation: Two for divine rites, three or one for ancestral duties, in both ways should a wealthy person feed (guests) and should not decline; six acts of duty, cleanliness, and the Brahminical conduct are the five that if neglected will cause harm. Therefore, one should not neglect these.

sloka: ekamapyāśayedvipraṃ pitrarthe pāñcayajñike || ||
translation: Even a single Brahmin hosting for the five daily fire-sacrifices should be considered worthy for the father's sake .

sloka: atyuṣṇaṃ sarvamannaṃ syādbhuñjīraṃste ca vāgyatāḥ | na ca dvijātayo brūyurdātrā pṛṣṭā havirguṇān yāvaduṣmā bhavatyannaṃ yāvadaśnanti vāgyatāḥ | pitarastāvadaśnanti yāvannoktā havirguṇāḥ yadveṣṭitaśirā bhuṅkte yadbhuṅkte dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ | sopānatkaśca yadbhuṅkte tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate | | | |
translation: Let the eager ones who are desirous of partaking, consume thoroughly all food that is extremely hot. And let not the Brahmins reveal the qualities of the food to those who ask . Let them consume until it becomes tepid . And let fathers consume until the qualities of the offerings are declared . Let one who is angry eat , let one who faces south eat, and let one who sits down to eat partake of the remnants .

sloka: jñānotkṛṣṭāya deyāni kavyāni ca havīṃṣi ca || || sahasraṃ hi sahasrāṇāmanṛcāṃ yatra bhuñjate | ekastānmantravitprītaḥ sarvānarhati dharmataḥ || || yatnena bhojayecchrāddhe bahvṛcaṃ vedapāragam | śākhāntagamathādhvaryuṃ chandogaṃ tu samāptikam || || eṣāmanyatamo yasya bhuñjīta śrāddhamarcitaḥ | pitṝṇāṃ tasya tṛptiḥ syācchāśvatī sāptapauruṣī || ||
translation:
Knowledge and poetry, along with oblations, should be offered to the one who is superior in knowledge. A thousand Rigvedic verses are enjoyed there where a single learned person, delighted in reciting the hymns, partakes. With diligent effort, one should feed and offer abundant sacrificial offerings to the one well-versed in the Vedas, having reached the end of the branch, the hotar, and the Samavedic chants.

The fruition of that person is indeed immortal and sevenfold, for whom the ancestral offering is consumed with respect and the ancestors' satisfaction becomes eternal.

sloka: mātāmahaṃ mātulaṃ ca svasrīyaṃ śvaśuraṃ gurum | dauhitraṃ viṭpatiṃ bandhuṃ ṛtvigyājyau ca bhojayet || ||
translation: I should honor my mother, maternal uncle, sisters, father-in-law, teacher, son-in-law, relative, the officiating priest and recipient of the ritual fee at the ritual.

sloka: jñānaniṣṭhā dvijāḥ ke cittaponiṣṭhāstathāpare | tapaḥsvādhyāyaniṣṭhāśca karmaniṣṭhāstathāpare || || jñānaniṣṭheṣu kavyāni pratiṣṭhāpyāni yatnataḥ | havyāni tu yathānyāyaṃ sarveṣveva caturṣvapi || || dūrādeva parīkṣeta brāhmaṇaṃ vedapāragam | tīrthaṃ taddhavyakavyānāṃ pradāne so'tithiḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation:
Among the twice-born, who are established in knowledge and those who are established in meditation, as well as those who are established in austerity and recitation of sacred texts, and those who are established in action; one should carefully establish works of literature for those devoted to knowledge. Sacrifices should be properly performed in all four orders without exception.

A brahmin who is advanced in the Vedas, ought to be examined from a distance, O far-seeing one. The gifting of tirtha and other sacred duties is considered as a day's hospitality (atithi).

sloka: na brāhmaṇaṃ parīkṣeta daive karmaṇi dharmavit | pitrye karmaṇi tu prāpte parīkṣeta prayatnataḥ || || aśrotriyaḥ pitā yasya putraḥ syādvedapāragaḥ | aśrotriyo vā putraḥ syātpitā syādvedapāragaḥ || || jyāyāṃsamanayorvidyādyasya syācchrotriyaḥ pitā | mantrasaṃpūjanārthaṃ tu satkāram itaro'rhati || ||
translation: In sacrificial duties a Dharma-knower should not examine a Brahmin; but in ancestral duties , he must carefully examine. If a father is illiterate , and his son is versed in the Vedas , then the father becomes literate . Alternatively, if the son is illiterate , even then the father becomes responsible for becoming learned . Among those of equal knowledge , a preceptor is superior for performing Vedic rituals . Others should be respectable .

sloka: na śrāddhe bhojayenmitraṃ dhanaiḥ kāryo'sya saṃgrahaḥ | nāriṃ na mitraṃ yaṃ vidyāttaṃ śrāddhe bhojayeddvijam || || yasya mitrapradhānāni śrāddhāni ca havīṃṣi ca | tasya pretya phalaṃ nāsti śrāddheṣu ca haviḥṣu ca || || yaḥ saṃgatāni kurute mohācchrāddhena mānavaḥ | sa svargāccyavate lokācchrāddhamitro dvijādhamaḥ || || saṃbhojāni sābhihitā paiśācī dakṣiṇā dvijaiḥ | ihaivāste tu sā loke gaurandhevaikaveśmani || ||
translation: One should not feed one's friends at a funeral ceremony with wealth; this is the proper course of action. Nor should one who knows, feed a Brahmin, either a woman or a friend, at a funeral ceremony. For, the fruits of his rites and sacrifices do not exist in the next world for the one who assigns to a Brahmin, as his main consideration, friends and offerings at a funeral ceremony. A foolish human who conducts such an improperly performed funeral ceremony falls from heaven. The friend, the Brahmin, is lowly, who partakes of a funeral feast in this world. Offerings given to lowly persons, even if given by Brahmins, are impure and remain only in this world, like cattle penned within a small enclosure.

sloka: etānvigarhitācārānapāṅkteyāndvijādhamān | dvijātipravaro vidvānubhayatra vivarjayet brāhmaṇo tvanadhīyānastṛṇāgniriva śāmyati | tasmai havyaṃ na dātavyaṃ na hi bhasmani hūyate
translation: The learned brahmin should avoid these improper conducts of the lowly dvijas and keep himself separate in both places. One should not give an offering to such a person who is controllable like grass and fire, for no oblation is made into ashes.

sloka: avratairyaddvijairbhuktaṃ parivetrādibhistathā | apāṅkteyairyadanyaiśca tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate
translation: Consumed by irreligious twice-born ones and those in the surrounding, as well as by others, what is enjoyed is protected by guards.

sloka: somavikrayiṇe viṣṭhā bhiṣaje pūyaśoṇitam | naṣṭaṃ devalake dattamapratiṣṭhaṃ tu vārdhuṣau
translation: In the moon's sale , reside in the physician ; pure blood is lost in the devalaka, neither is the support found.

sloka: yattu vāṇijake dattaṃ neha nāmutra tadbhavet |
translation: That which is given in trade does not become ones own here or there.

sloka: prathitā pretakṛtyaiṣā pitryaṃ nāma vidhukṣaye | tasminyuktasyaiti nityaṃ pretakṛtyaiva laukikī || ||
translation: This funeral ritual for the deceased, known as pitrya, is always, in a routine sense, just that when performed for someone who has passed away.

sloka: śrotriyāyaiva deyāni havyakavyāni dātṛbhiḥ | arhattamāya viprāya tasmai dattaṃ mahāphalam || || ekaikamapi vidvāṃsaṃ daive pitrye ca bhojayet | puṣkalaṃ phalamapnoti nāmantrajñānbahūnapi || || yatheriṇe bījamuptvā na vaptā labhate phalam | tathānṛce havirdattvā na dātā labhate phalam || || dātṝnpratigrahītṝṃśca kurute phalabhāginaḥ | viduṣe dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā vidhivatpretya ceha ca || ||
translation: To the deserving teacher, offerings of sacrificial rituals and hymns are to be made. The most worthy Brahmin shall receive great fruit (of this offering). Even if a single learned person is fed modestly in the divine or ancestral rites, they reap abundant fruit, not just those who recite mantras without understanding. Just as a seed, when sown, does not produce fruit unless it sprouts, so too the giver of the sacrifice does not gain fruit if offered to an undeserving recipient. Both the giver and receiver of the offering become partakers of the fruit if given to a deserving scholar according to proper procedure in this life and hereafter.

sloka: kāmaṃ śrāddhe'rcayenmitraṃ nābhirūpamapi tvarim | dviṣatā hi havirbhuktaṃ bhavati pretya niṣphalam || ||
translation: One should offer funeral cake to a friend, neither excessively nor unpleasingly; for, eaten by an enemy after one's death, the oblation becomes fruitless.

sloka: ta ete śreyasaḥ kālā nṝṇāṃ śreyovivardhanāḥ | kuryāt sarvātmanaiteṣu śreyo'moghaṃ tadāyuṣaḥ || || eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram || ||
translation: These auspicious moments for people , conducive to their well-being , should be utilized by one who desires the ultimate benefit . This way, one's lifespan becomes fruitful. Among these means of prosperity are: bathing , recitation , fire sacrifice , vows , and worship of gods, twice-born beings , as well as offerings made to ancestors and various living beings . The fruits of these actions become firmly established when performed with sincerity.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: By truth and immortality should one live, whether with the mortal or the immortal; never by falsehood. The pure truth is to be sought, the impure falsehood to be avoided. Mortal sustenance is obtained by begging, while immortal wealth comes from hard work. Trade is a mixture of both. One should live through service, not through begging. Therefore, one must reject that (begging) and embrace the other (service).

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: A brahmin and a king should always reject that which is hated. A brahmin is one who is imbued with all the Vedas, and a king is one who is imbued with all the gods.

sloka: vṛttiḥ saṅkarajātīnāṃ tattatkulakṛtā bhavet | acaurāṇāmapāpānāmantyajāntevasāyinām || ||
translation: The livelihood of those born from mixed-castes is determined by their own actions; the sinful and unstealable actions of such abandoners can never be abandoned.

sloka: vṛttyā svabhāvakṛtayā vartamānaḥ svakarmakṛt | hitvā svabhāvajaṃ karma śanairnirguṇatāmiyāt || ||
translation: Living and acting in accordance with one's inherent nature, and having given up naturally ordained duties, gradually attains the state of being free from qualities.

sloka: jaghanyo nottamāṃ vṛttimanāpadi bhajennaraḥ | ṛte rājanyamāpatsu sarveṣāmapi sarvaśaḥ || ||
translation: Except in dire royal emergencies, a person should not adopt a lowly occupation, even if it is the only option left for him.

sloka: kuśūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyām ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati
translation: Can one be a giver of Kusha grass or grains, or solely a pot-giver; or maybe just a day-to-day worldly person? Indeed, among these four household Brahmins, one should be established, steadfast. Of all six duties, the one that leads to victory in the world is considered superior and is known as Dharma. For them, five acts are prescribed: three common ones and another unique act, while some may live with Brahman through meditation.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ
translation: A brahmin should not ask for food within his own clan, as it is declared by the wise to be unworthy behavior equivalent to gluttony.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam
translation: A brahmin, by engaging in appropriate actions, should establish a livelihood that is easy for all beings to access and has minimal conflict; with no afflictions, they should accumulate wealth through their own efforts, aiming solely for the means of sustenance.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ
translation: Devoted to the agnihotra ritual, which is carried out with śilā and uñchā, is there anyone who only performs the prescribed iṣṭīs, without following the ways of the world? How could one, who desires happiness, lead a restrained life, embracing pure brahminical existence, living simply, being content as the ultimate goal, not seeking anything more. Indeed, contentment is the root of happiness, while its opposite is suffering.

sloka: edhodakaṃ mūlaphalaṃ annaṃ abhyudyataṃ ca yat | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānmadhvathābhayadakṣiṇām āhṛtābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastādapracoditām | mene prajāpatirgrāhyāṃ api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ nāśnanti pitarastasya daśavarṣāṇi pañca ca | na ca havyaṃ vahatyagniryastāṃ abhyavamanyate
translation: Offer first, at the beginning, the food prepared from root ingredients and water, received from all sides, along with a sweetener and a fee, to a worthy and fearless beggar who has set out (on alms round). For, Prajapati considers it fit for even an evildoer to partake of such an offering; the father considers it auspicious for his son for ten and five years; fire accepts it as its share.

sloka: śayyāṃ gṛhānkuśāngandhānapaḥ puṣpaṃ maṇīndadhi | dhānā matsyānpayo māṃsaṃ śākaṃ caiva na nirṇudet
translation: The mattress, household articles, and Kush grass infused with fragrance, water, flowers, gems, rice, fish, payasam (sweet rice pudding), vegetables – let nothing be excluded (from a Brahmin's diet).

sloka: gurūnbhṛtyāṃścojjihīrṣannarciṣyandevatātithīn | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānna tu tṛpyetsvayaṃ tataḥ guruṣu tvabhyatīteṣu vinā vā tairgṛhe vasan | ātmano vṛttiṃ anvicchangṛhṇīyātsādhutaḥ sadā
translation: Eager to serve the gurus, one should not seek to retreat. One should receive and honor the guests, gods, and teachers from all directions. But once they have left, one should not become complacent; instead, one should always strive to uphold their own conduct and duties diligently, even while residing in others' homes. A true ascetic constantly pursues this path.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I have proclaimed this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan, Vivasvan taught it to Manu, and Manu passed it on to Ikshvaku.

sloka: bhagavo kasmin vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati
translation: By understanding which divine being, everything in this world becomes known.

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: The wise perceive as ever-present, all-pervading, subtle, unswayable, antecedent to origin, that which is not visible or graspable, without taste, color, or form, and is beyond the reach of eyes and ears, and encompasses the limbs of action and perception.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: By which the unheard is made heard, the heard is recognized as unheard, the unknown is known, and the known is regarded as unknown.

sloka: yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syātvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam”
translation: Just as, O Somya, by knowing a single lump of clay, everything made of clay becomes known; the initial effort (of knowing) is transformation, and "clay" is the true designation.

sloka: annamayaṃ hi mana āpomayaḥ prāṇaḥ tejomayī vāk
translation: The mind is indeed made of food, while the speech is made of radiance. The sense of "I" (prāṇa) is based on vital air.

sloka: svaṃ apīto bhavati tasmāt enamsva pitītyācakṣate
translation: "Therefore, one should refer to him as 'father' who behaves like a true father to oneself."

sloka: sa ya eṣoഽṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly knows this self of this tiny thing - that is, its essential nature - indeed knows the truth . That self is what you are , O Svetaketu.

sloka: ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyad bhavanti tadābhavanti’
translation: Here, whether a tiger, lion, wolf, boar, worm, winged creature, or fly - whatever beings exist, all of them also arise and exist.

sloka: śṛṇu nāmāni lokānāṃ mātṝṇāṃ śaṅkarāṇi ca || atha kaśyapapatnīnāṃ yatprasūtamidaṃ jagat | aditirditirdanuḥ kāṣṭhā ariṣṭā surasā ilā || muniḥ krodhavaśā tāmrā surabhiḥ saramā timiḥ | timeryādogaṇā āsanśvāpadāḥ saramāsutāḥ
translation: Listen to the names of the mothers in the world and Shankaras. Now, the progeny of Kashyapa's wives - this world has emerged from Aditi, Diti, Danu, Kshthaa, Arishta, Sursa, and Ila. The sage (Muni) was under the control of anger; Tamra, Surabhi, Sarama, and Timi are the wives of Kashyapa, and their sons are Timeryadogana, Asvanpadah, and Saramasutah.

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: The wise and discerning brāhmaṇas understand these four words as the means to a higher end, hidden in a cave-like refuge, transcending ordinary speech; it is what humans refer to as the fourth level of speech.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, comparison, and verbal testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: indriyasyārthena sannikarṣād utpadyate yat jñānaṃ tat pratyakṣam ||
translation: Knowledge arising from the direct contact between a sense organ and its object is called sensory perception.

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation: By observing the distinguishing signs (of objects), one understands their connection. By directly perceiving a distinguishing sign, one becomes established in its memory. By remembering a distinguishing sign, an unperceived object is inferred.

sloka: pūrvavaditi yatra kāraṇena kāryyamanumīyate| yathā medhonnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Where, as previously understood, an effect is recognized by its cause, just as a future rain shower will be recognized from the rising of water vapor.

sloka: athavā pūrvavaditi yatra yathā pūrvvaṃ pratyakṣabhūtayoḥ anyataradarśanena anyatarasya apratyakṣasya anumānam | yathā dhūmenāgniriti |
translation: Or, like in the past, when one thing is directly perceived, inference of another unperceived thing can be made, as in "there's fire because there's smoke".

sloka: śeṣavat yatra kāryyeṇa kāraṇamanumīyate | pūrvvodakaviparītamudakaṃ nadyāḥ pūrṇatvamaṃ śīdhratvañca dṛṣṭvā srotaso'numīyate bhūtā vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Where, in the case of a task, the cause is understood to be residual (dependent on something else to fulfill the task), just as one can infer the previous flow of rivers (upstream) from observing their current state (fullness or lack thereof), and similarly infer rainfall from observing the condition of the earth.

sloka: śeṣavat nāma pariśeṣaḥ sa ca prasaktapratiṣedhe'nyatra aprasāṅgāt śiṣyamāṇe sampratyayaḥ | yathā sadanityamityevamādinā dravyaguṇakarmaṇāmaviśeṣeṇa sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyebhyo vibhaktasya śabdasya tasmin dravyakarmaguṇasaṃśaye na dravyamekadravyatvāt na karma śabdāntarahetutvāt yastu śiṣyate so'yamiti śabdasya guṇatvapratipattiḥ |
translation: The named remainder is the leftover portion referred to as such because it is set apart from the rest by denial . It applies not only to physical entities , qualities , and actions , but also in a general sense to any similar distinctions . When analyzing the word that indicates this remainder, it does not refer to one single physical entity , nor is its meaning based on another word . The one who learns about this quality recognizes it as such. This is established due to the absence of attachment and in contrast to those who deny it.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ vrajyāpūrvakam anyatra dṛṣṭasya anyatra darśanamiti tathā cā''dityasya | tasmāt asti apratyakṣā api āpyādityasya vrajyeti|
translation: "It is seen generally in the case of the moving objects (like the sun) that what was seen before is not seen now; similarly, there is an invisible presence of the sun even when it is not seen. Hence, it moves."

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ nāma yatrāpratyakṣe liṅgaliṅginoḥ sambandhe kenacidarthena liṅgasya sāmānyādapratyakṣo liṅgī gamyate | yathecchādibhirātmā | icchādayo guṇāḥ | guṇāśca dravyasaṃsthānāḥ | tadyadeṣāṃ sthānaṃ sa ātmeti |
translation: The named attribute, which is commonly observed in the relationship between a signifier and signified, can be understood through a certain reason, not immediately perceptible. The qualities, such as desire, arise from the existence of dravya-sthana (substance-location). Therefore, that very locus of these qualities is the self.

sloka: prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam || || {upamānalakṣaṇam}
translation: The characteristic that is widely accepted as a standard for comparing and evaluating something is called its measure.

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: The definition of the common attribute of something is its definition through a comparative example. For instance, when one understands the similar quality of a cow in a group of cows, it becomes immediately clear and meaningful. This has been said to be the establishment of the relationship between the name and the object, which is called 'samākhyā-sambandha'. Similarly, when one understands the comparative example of a cow, the word 'cow' indicates that similar quality, and in this way, it brings the medicinal herb to use. Likewise, any object that is compared in the world should be desired.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ||||{śabdalakṣaṇam} saḥ dvividhaḥ dṛṣṭādṛṣṭārthatvāt||||{śabdabhedaḥ}
translation: Instruction and word are twofold, based on their meaning being directly or indirectly expressed; the distinction in word is also twofold. (Translation based on the individual meanings of the words: āpta - instructed, upadeśaḥ - instruction, śabdaḥ - word, sah - that, dvividhaḥ - twofold, dṛṣṭa - directly, adṛṣṭa - indirectly, arthatvāt - based on meaning, śabdabhedaḥ - distinction in word)

sloka: yasyāmutra pratīyate so'dṛṣṭārthaḥ | evamṛṣi laukikavākyānāṃ vibhāga iti |
translation: Of such [a matter] that is perceived in the future, that is the evident meaning; this is the division of mundane statements according to the sage, so it is said.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: tayā ca sarveṣāṃ vyavahārāḥ pravartanta iti | evamebhiḥ pramāṇairdevamanuṣyatiraśca vyavahārāḥ prakalpante nāto'nyatheti| arthāpattiḥ apramāṇaṃ anaikāntikatvāt ||||{arthāpattiprāmāṇyaparīkṣā}
translation: Through her, all forms of conduct occur; thus, the conduct of both divine and human beings is established through such means of evidence. There is no other (means), except for arthāpatti (a type of inference). (This is) because of the unestablished nature of anumāna (another type of inference). {On the examination of arthāpatti as a means of knowledge}

sloka: autpattikastu śabdasyārthena sambandhastasya jñānamupadeśo'vyatirekaścārthe'nupalabdhe tat pramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt sū
translation: Knowledge of the inherent connection of a word's meaning is the means of instruction, and in the absence of that meaning, inference is the means of establishing it. This is stated by Badarayana without dependence on other sources.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā||
translation: The means of obtaining wealth is also seen or heard; it cannot be assumed to be otherwise. For instance, just as Devadatta continues to live, externally appearing devoid of a home, but in reality, he is supported by unseen wealth.

sloka: arthāpattilakṣaṇam| vinā kalpanayā'rthena dṛṣṭenā'nupapannatām| nayatā'dṛṣṭamarthaṃ yā sā'rthāpattistu kalpanā || | dṛṣṭenā'rthenā'dṛṣṭasyā'rthasyā'rthāntarakalpanāyāmasatyāmanupapattimāpādayatā yā'rthāntarakalpanā sā'rthāpatti:| yathā jīvato devadattasya gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyā'dṛṣṭasya kalpanā|
translation: The definition of the arising of an object's true nature is when, without the help of mental constructs, it is seen to be unestablished. This arising of a conception leads to the misperception of something unseen as having a different nature. For example, the conception of Devadatta being outside his home while he is still alive, based on seeing his house empty, is an incorrect apprehension.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇabhāvo nāstītyasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasyeti|
translation: Even the seeming absence of proof is not absent in its being closely related to that [concept].

sloka: pramāṇapañcakaṃ yatra vasturūpe na jāyate| vastusattāvabodhārthaṃ tatrābhāvapramāṇatā|||| vasttvasaṅkarasiddhiśca tatprāmāṇyasamāśrayā|
translation: The knowledge of the five means of valid cognition is necessary for understanding the true nature and existence of a thing, as well as for establishing the reality of composite objects; it is based on this principle that such knowledge rests.

sloka: kṣīre dadhyādi yannāsti prāgabhāvassa ucyate||||
translation: That which does not exist in milk, curds, etc., before their origin is called past nonexistence.

sloka: nāstitā payaso dadhni pradhvaṃsābhāva iṣyate| ||||
translation: The churning of nonexistent butterfat is considered equivalent to its destruction.

sloka: gavi yo'śvādyabhāvastu so'nyonyābhāva ucyate||||
translation: The one that is the non-existence of a horse in relation to a cow (and vice versa) is called "anyonyabhava".

sloka: śiraso'vayavā ninmā vṛddhikāṭhinyavarjitāḥ| śaśaśrṛṅgādirūpeṇa so'tyantābhāva ucyate||||
translation: Those adorned with all limbs, free from decay and resembling a deer with antlers are said to be completely non-existent (in the physical sense).

sloka: śaraṇāgatasya kartavyamātithyaṃ hi prayatnataḥ| pañcayajñapravṛttena gṛhasthena viśeṣataḥ|| pañcayajñāṃstu yo mohānna karoti gṛhāśrame| tasya nāyaṃ na ca paro loko bhavati dharmataḥ||
translation: The special duty of a householder toward a person who has sought refuge is to provide hospitality, and this should be done attentively and consistently. Specifically, one should carry out the five great sacrifices. However, one who is deluded and does not perform these sacrifices while residing in his home will not partake in either this world or the next according to dharma.

sloka: sa tu śītahatairgātrairna jagāma na tasthivān| dadarśa patitāṃ bhūmau kapotīṃ śītavihvalām||
translation: He, however, with his chilled body, did not go near or stay [there]; he saw a quail lying helpless on the ground, overcome by the cold.

sloka: dharmārthakāmakāleṣu bhāryā puṃsaḥ sahāyinī| videśagamane cāsya saiva viśvāsakārikā|| nāsti bhāryāsamo bandhurnāsti bhāryāsamā gatiḥ| nāsti bhāryāsamo loke sahāyo dharmasaṅgrahe|| yasya bhāryā gṛhe nāsti sādhvī ca priyavādinī| araṇyaṃ tena gantavyaṃ yathāraṇyaṃ tathā gṛham||
translation: In matters of dharma, artha, and kama, a wife is a helpmate to her husband; she is his trusted companion during travel abroad. There is no friend like a wife, no partner comparable, no one so steady in this world. For one whose wife is devoted and agreeable, renunciation and the householder's life are equally suitable.

sloka: arāvapyucitaṃ kāryamātithyaṃ gṛhamāgate| chettumapyāgate chāyāṃ nopasaṃharate drumaḥ||
translation: Even a suitable task, accepted (by the tree), such as hosting a guest, should the tree not neglect when someone arrives or departs, nor should it ever abandon its shade.

sloka: niścitā khalu me buddhiratithipratipūjayane|| tataḥ kṛtapratijño vai sa pakṣī prahasanniva| tamagniṃ triḥparikramya praviveśa mahāmatiḥ||
translation: Undoubtedly, my resolve has been firmly established to worship the revered throne. Then, with the appearance of a laughing bird, he [the king] made three circumambulations around the fire and entered [the palace].

sloka: mitaṃ dadāti hi pitā mitaṃ bhrātā mitaṃ sutaḥ|| amitasya hi dātāraṃ bhartāraṃ kā na pūjayet| nāsti bhartṛsamo nātho nāsti bhartṛsamaṃ sukham||
translation: Indeed, a father, brother, and son give limited gifts; but who would not honor the giver and protector of those who cannot give? There is no equivalent to a protector, nor any happiness comparable to him.

sloka: tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti |
translation: There, the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda are known as the branches of knowledge; also included are Śikṣā (phonetics), Kalpa (ritual), Vyākaraṇam (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Chando (prosody), and Jyotiṣa (astronomy).

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: Consisting of six ancillary branches, they are the Vedas: śikṣā (phonetics), kalpa (ritual), vyākaraṇa (grammar), nirukta (etymology), chandas (prosody), and jyotiṣa (astronomy).

sloka: chandaḥ pādau tu vedasya hastau kalpo'tha ucyate | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ cakṣurniruktaṃ śrotramucyate || śikṣā ghrāṇaṃ tu vedasya mukhaṃ vyākaraṇaṃ smṛtam | tasmāt sāṅgamadhītyaiva brahmaloke mahīyate ||
translation: The meter is considered the feet of the Vedas , while the tradition is called its hands. The portion related to light is said to be its eyes, and the unspoken is its ears. The oral tradition is its nose, and the grammar is its mouth. Therefore, by knowing all these parts , one becomes great in the world of Brahma .

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstraṃ caturthaṃ tu vidyā hyaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharva Veda, with the fourth being Arthaśāstra; these sixteen include the branch of knowledge (vidyā).

sloka: aṣṭādaśa purāṇāni purāṇajñāḥ pracakṣate| brāhmaṃ pādmaṃ vaiṣṇavañca śaivaṃ bhāgavataṃ tathā|
translation: The eighteen Puranas are classified as Brahma, Padma, Vaishnava, and Shaiva, according to those knowledgeable in Purana.

sloka: varṇādidharmasmaraṇaṃ yatra vedāvirodhakam | kīrtanaṃ cārthaśāstrāṇāṃ smṛtiḥ sā ca prakīrtitā |
translation: Where remembrance of the fundamental duties associated with caste is in accordance with the Vedas, and proclaiming the meaning of the sacred scriptures is recognized.

sloka: manvatriviṣṇuhārīta yājñavalkyośano'ṅgirāḥ | yamāpastambasaṃvartāḥ kātyāyanabṛhaspatī | | | |
translation: Manu, Atri, Viṣṇu, Hārī, Angiras, and USanas, as well as Yama, Apastamba, Saṃvartaka, Kātyāyana, and Bṛhaspati. (This appears to be a list of names, possibly of sages or scholars.)

sloka: vitathasya sutān manyoḥ bṛhatkṣatro jayastataḥ | mahāvīryo naro gargaḥ saṅkṛtistu narātmajaḥ || ||guruśca rantidevaśca saṅ‌kṛteḥ pāṇḍunandana |
translation: The sons of the unwise, rejoice, a great conqueror has been born; Gargah, the man of great heroism, and Rantideva's offspring, are both established (in power).

sloka: yasya dviśatasāhasrā āsansūdā mahātmanaḥ|| gṛhānabhyāgatānviprānatithīnpariveṣakāḥ| pakvāpakvaṃ divārātraṃ aparyāptaṃ dhanaṃ tadā[varānnamamṛtopamam|| nyāyenādhigataṃ vittaṃ brāhmaṇebhyo hyamanyata| vedānadhītya dharmeṇa yaścakre dviṣato vaśe||
translation: Of the magnanimous soul whose dwelling places are ornamented with two thousand seats, and who has acquired wealth through fair means, which is inexhaustible and equal to nectar; who, having studied the Vedas, has made a distribution of it to the Brahmins according to justice - how did such a one come under the control of an enemy?

sloka: vyatīyuḥ aṣṭacatvāriṃśat ahani apibataḥ kila | ghṛtapāyasasaṃyāvaṃ toyaṃ prātarupasthitam || ||
translation: Twenty-eight days have passed since they tapped (the sap); surely, in the morning, clarified butter and sweet milk are present.

sloka: na kāmaye'haṃ gatimīśvarātparāṃ aṣṭarddhiyuktāmapunarbhavaṃ vā | ārtiṃ prapadye'khiladehabhājāṃ antaḥsthito yena bhavantyaduḥkhāḥ || ||
translation: I do not desire a higher destiny than the Lord's or one adorned with eight types of supernatural powers; I seek refuge in Him who resides within all bodies, through whose grace all afflictions of living beings are removed.

sloka: puruṣabahutvaṃ vyavasthātaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nādvaitamātmano liṅgāt tadbhedapratīteḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nānātmāpi pratyakṣabādhāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | nobhābhyāṃ tenaiva | sāṃkhyasūtra | anyaparatvamavivekānāṃ tatra | sāṃkhyasūtra | nātmāvidyā nobhayaṃ jagadupādānakāraṇaṃ nissaṅgatvāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | naikasyānandacidrūpatve dvayorbhedāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | duḥkhanivṛttergauṇaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | vimuktipraśaṃsā mandānāṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra | jananamaraṇakaraṇānāṃ pratiniyamādayugapatpravṛtteśca | puruṣabahutvaṃ siddhaṃ traiguṇyaviparyayāccaiva || ||
translation:
The multiplicity of purushas (conscious beings) is established based on the sankhya system. There is no duality in the self, which can be inferred from its distinct characteristics. Different selves are proven by direct perception. It is not due to the combination of two things; rather, it arises from that alone. The indiscernibility between the self and not-self results in incorrect understanding.

The self, characterized by bliss, consciousness, and individuality, does not have a dual nature. Suffering, a quality associated with conditioned existence, is separate from pure consciousness. Praise for liberation is meant for those who are slow to understand. The principles of birth, death, and causation operate simultaneously according to their specific natures.

Established is the multiplicity of purushas, along with the permutations of the three gunas (qualities).

sloka: kleśakarmavipākāśayairaparāmṛṣṭaḥ puruṣaviśeṣa īśvaraḥ ||
translation: The supreme Purusha, the Lord Ishwara, is untouched by afflictions, actions, their fruits, and inherent tendencies.

sloka: niratiśayaṃ tatra sarvajñatvabījam ||
translation: The seed of omniscience is unsurpassed there.

sloka: sa pūrveṣāmapi guruḥ kālenānavacchedāta||
translation: Even the former teacher, through lack of distinction of time.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam||
translation: The self, body, senses, objects of sense, intellect, and mind, along with their activities, faults, past and future fruits, suffering, and liberation – these are to be examined.

sloka: tatrā''tmā sarvasya draṣṭā sarvasya bhoktā sarvajñaḥ sarvānubhavakaḥ | tasya bhogā''yatanaṃ śarīram | bhogasādhanānīndriyāṇi |
translation: The self is the observer of all and the consumer of all; it is all-knowing and the experiencer of everything. Its enjoyment base is the body, while the senses are the means for its enjoyment.

sloka: jagaduvyāpāravarjam prakaraṇāt asannihitatvācca ||
translation: Excluding universal pervasiveness, due to its not being separate from the context.

sloka: jaṭā mālā śikhā lekhā dhvajo daṇḍo ratho ghanaḥ aṣṭau vikṛtayaḥ proktā kramapūrvā manīṣibhiḥ
translation: Eight distinct emblems have been declared by the sages in sequence: the tuft , garland , topknot , mark , banner , staff , chariot , and cloud .

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ | saṃ | vadante | somena | saha | rājñā | yasmai | kṛṇoti | brāhmaṇaḥ | taṃ | rājan | pārayāmasi ||
translation: We, O king, are causing the plants to be united with the royal Soma for the Brahmin who makes use of them.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ | saṃ vadante | vadante somena | somena saha | saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti | kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ | brāhmaṇastaṃ | taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation: Plants are called by the name "soma" along with "rajan" (an honorific title) when a brahmin dedicates them to someone. We shall also dedicate them.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ sam | saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante | vadante somena somena vadante vadante somena | somena saha saha somena somena saha| saha rājñā rājñā saha saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti kṛṇoti yasmai yasmai kṛṇoti| kṛṇoti brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaḥ kṛṇoti kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ| brāhmaṇastaṃ taṃ brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇastam | taṃ rājan rājaṃstaṃ taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi pārayāmasi rājan rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation: Herbs are called by the name "herbs" and also by the name "associated with herbs." They are called "herbs" when associated with Soma and "Soma" when associated with herbs. They are called "associated with Soma" when associated with a king and "king" when associated with herbs. The one to whom the brahmana dedicates, that is what he dedicates; he dedicates it to the brahmana, and the brahmana calls it "belonging to the brahmana." He calls it "belonging to the king" when dedicating it to the king; he says "I shall make him cross over" again and again, whether it be to the king or to something else.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ saṃ vadante| saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante somena|
translation: Herbs are called "oşadhayaḥ" and also those that are "sam-oşadhayaḥ", and they are called "saṃ vadante" with the accompaniment of "somena".

sloka: brahmakṣatriyaviṭśūdrā varṇāstvādyāstrayo dvijāḥ | niṣekādyāḥ śmaśānāntāsteṣāṃ vai mantrataḥ kriyāḥ || ||
translation: The primary duties for the three upper varnas (brahmana, kshatriya, vaishya) are specified in the early vedic texts, while the last rites and other secondary duties are assigned to the sudra varna.

sloka: saṃskārā yadavicchinnāḥ sa dvijo'jo jagāda yam |
translation: The twice-born (dvija) Aja, having not abandoned (avicchinnah) the sacred vows (samskaras), declared this.

sloka: viprasyādhyayanādīni ṣaḍanyasyāpratigrahaḥ |
translation: Without accepting gifts from others, a brahmin's study and other six duties should not be accepted.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva dānaṃ pātre pratigrahaḥ| adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgṛjuḥ||
translation: Sacrifice, its facilitation, donation, acceptance in a vessel, and teaching and learning are the six duties that constitute religious observance.

sloka: satyaṃ dānaṃ kṣamā śīlamānṛśaṃsyaṃ tapo ghṛṇā | dṛśyante yatranāgendrasa brāhmaṇa iti smṛtaḥ ||
translation: Recognized as a Brahmin is one who consistently displays truthfulness, charity, forgiveness, calmness, non-condescension, and austerity, with compassion, in this world.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ santoṣaḥ kṣāntirārjavam | jñānaṃ dayācyutātmatvaṃ satyaṃ ca brahmalakṣaṇam || ||
translation: Self-control, restraint, austerity, purification, contentment, forbearance, honesty, knowledge, compassion, descent of the divine, selfhood, and truth are the marks of Brahman.

sloka: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat || ||
translation: Prescribe for Brahmins the tasks of teaching , studying , performing sacrifices , officiating in sacrifices , giving , and accepting .

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca | tasmādasminsadā yukto nityaṃ syādātmavāndvijaḥ || ||
translation: Proper conduct is the supreme religious duty, as stated in scripture, both spoken and written. Therefore, a twice-born (dvija) person should always be established in this, constantly being self-aware.

sloka: idaṃ śāstram adhīyāno brāhmaṇaḥ śaṃsitavrataḥ | manovāggehajairnityaṃ karmadoṣairna lipyate || || ācārādvicyuto vipro na vedaphalam aśnute | ācāreṇa tu saṃyuktaḥ sampūrṇaphalabhāgbhavet || ||
translation: A brahmana, who is intent on learning this scripture and has taken a sacred vow, remains untainted by daily bodily and vocal actions' faults. A priest, who is detached from prescribed behavior, does not partake of the fruit of the Vedas; only when associated with proper conduct does he stand to gain complete fruition.

sloka: ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam || || satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet || ||
translation: That which is truthful, coarse-grained and worthy of knowing, immortal and unchanging, sought as alms and known as the ultimate goal – such is the food for the wise. The trade of truth and falsehood is what sustains one's life. Service and the lowly occupation of a dog are designated by the same term; therefore, one should avoid the latter.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: A brahmin and a king should always reject that which is condemned. A brahmin is one who is devoted to all the Vedas, and a king is one who is devoted to all deities.

sloka: kusūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā || || caturṇāṃ api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ || || ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyāṃ ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati || ||
translation: Is one a collector of Kusula fruits or a gatherer of Kumbhi grains, or perhaps an ascetic who has taken to traveling? Among these four householders who are also Brahmins, who is superior, most worthy of knowing, and the greatest promoter of righteousness in the world? Out of six duties that they have, only one is performed by them, another two are shared with others, while the fourth one is carried out through meditation on Brahman.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi || ||
translation: Living alone, with minimal harm or even without causing any harm to beings, is the conduct that a virtuous person should adopt for a prosperous life.

sloka: yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam || ||
translation: To gain fame through a journey, one should skillfully and without harm accumulate wealth using their own actions.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ || ||
translation: A brahmin should not offer food with selfish intent even within his own clan, for the wise call such behavior as causing animosity and discord.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā || || na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām || || saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: Performing the agnihotra rituals daily with devotion, who should offer only the pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ iṣṭīs, without following the ways of the world. Living a pure and simple brāhmaṇa life, one must strive to become contented, for contentment is the root of happiness while its opposite leads to misery.

sloka: dāti dāśati dāsati rāti rāsati pṛṇakṣi pṛṇāti śikṣati tuñjata maṃhate iti dānakarmāṇaḥ| |
translation: Giving, allowing to serve, causing to serve, enjoying, relishing, causing to sprout, causing to nourish, teaching, being proud, and boasting - these are the various actions related to giving.

sloka: devabrāhmaṇādisampradānakadravyamocanam tatparyyāyaḥ tyāgaḥ vihāpitam utsarjanam visarjanam viśrāṇanam vitaraṇam sparśanam pratipādanam prādeśanam nirvvapaṇam apavarjanam aṃhatiḥ ityamaraḥ
translation: The release of goods received from devas, brahmanas and others, with the intention of giving; renunciation is known as abandoning, casting away, letting go, handing over, touching, explaining, designating, laying down, discarding, or destroying it.

sloka: nākasya pṛṣṭhe adhi tiṣṭhati śrito yaḥ pṛṇāti sa ha deveṣu gacchati | tasmā āpo ghṛtamarṣanti sindhavastasmā iyaṃ dakṣiṇā pinvate sadā ||
translation: The one who sustains life on the summit of the sky, that one indeed goes to the gods after pouring rain. Therefore, rivers always swell with water and ghee; hence this southern offering (of oblation) is forever fruitful.

sloka: tapaḥ paraṃ kṛtayuge tretāyāṃ jñānaṃ ucyate | dvāpare yajñaṃ evāhurdānaṃ ekaṃ kalau yuge || ||
translation: In the Satya Yuga, penance was supreme; in the Treta Yuga, knowledge was declared superior; in the Dvapara Yuga, sacrifice was considered essential; but in the current Kali Yuga, charity is said to be the one most important duty.

sloka: sa tu dānasya tattvārthī tepe varṣagaṇānbahūn|| || ā āī ēē ṣṇāū|| || tatastaṃ prāha khe vāṇī ślokamekaṃ nṛpa śrṛṇu|| dvihetu ṣaḍadhiṣṭhānaṃ ṣaḍaṃgaṃ ca dvipākayuk|| || catuḥprakāraṃ trividhaṃ trināśaṃ dānamucyate||
translation: That truth-seeker, after performing abundant rain-giving charity for a long time, then spoke these words in the sky, O king, listen to this one sloka. The rain-giving charity has six causes and six components, and is threefold in its results; it is described as being of four kinds and threefold in its destruction.

sloka: śraddhā śaktiśca dānānāṃ vṛddhyakṣayakarehi te|| ||
translation: Faith and strength are, for gifts, the causes of growth or decline.

sloka: dharmamarthaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca vrīḍāharṣabhayāni ca|| adhiṣṭhānāni dānānāṃ ṣaḍetāni pracakṣate|| ||
translation: The six bases (adhisthanaani) of charitable gifts (danasam), namely dharma (righteousness), artha (wealth), kama (desire), vridaa (shame), harsha (delight), and bhayani (fear), are proclaimed.

sloka: dātā pratigrahītā ca śuddhirdeyaṃ ca dharmayuk|| || deśakālau ca dānānāmaṃgānyetāni ṣaḍviduḥ|| ||
translation: The giver and the receiver, purity and that which is to be given, all are appropriate in terms of righteousness; these six aspects relate to giving, depending on time and place.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva tathā dānapratigrahau| adhyāpanaṃ cādhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgdvijaḥ||
translation: A twice-born should perform rituals , accept invitations to sacrifice , give and receive gifts , as well as teach and study . These are the six duties of a person established in righteousness .

sloka: sadbhyo yaddīyate kiṃcittatparatropatiṣṭhati|| asatsu dīyate kiṃcittaddānamiha bhujyate|| ||
translation: From what is given to the virtuous, a portion is set aside, and what is left over is given to the unworthy; here that gift is enjoyed.

sloka: dhruvamāhustrikaṃ kāmyaṃ naimittikamiti kramāt|| || vaidiko dānamārgo'yaṃ caturdhā varṇyate dvijaiḥ||
translation: "Undoubtedly, it is declared as fixed for a twig or an object of desire , the occasional ceremonial gift is classified in four ways by the twice-born ."

sloka: upānacchatrapātrādidadhimadhvāsanāni ca|| || āāāāā || || dīpakāṣṭhopalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam|| iti kānīyasānyāhurdānanāśatrayaṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: Learn about the three types of generous gifts, starting from water pots and continuing up to grand umbrellas, as well as lamps, wood, and various other items, for many years.

sloka: yaccākruśya dadātyaṃga dattvā vākrośati dvijam|| paiśācaṃ tadvṛthā dānaṃdānanāśāstrayastvamī|| ||
translation: That which, when urged, one gives with their body and then regrets or urges a twice-born , that gift is a false gift ; such a gift, along with the three kinds of sacrificial gifts , leads to ruin .

sloka: ye ke cāsmacchreyā~so brāhmaṇāḥ teṣāṃ tvayā''sanena praśvasitavyam | śraddhayā deyam | aśraddhayā'deyam | śriyā deyam | hriyā deyam | bhiyā deyam | saṃvidā deyam | atha yadi te karmavicikitsā vā vṛttavicikitsā vā syāt || ||
translation: Those who are truly virtuous among our Brahmins, towards them you should be respectful in breath, speech, and action. Offer them faith, wealth, fame, modesty, knowledge, fear, and respect, if however you have any doubt about their conduct or character.

sloka: gṛhe daśaguṇaṃ dānaṃ goṣṭhe caiva śatādhikam | puṇyatīrtheṣu sāhasramanantaṃ śivasannidhau ||
translation: At home, charity worth ten times more [than usual], and in the cattle pen, [charity of] hundred [times more]. At holy places, countless [charitable acts], and near Shiva, a thousand.

sloka: devīpurāṇe sarve śivāśramāḥ puṇyāḥ sarvā nadyaḥ śubhapradāḥ |
translation: In the Purana of the Goddess, all hermitages are auspicious and holy; all rivers there bestow prosperity.

sloka: na hīyate yatra dharmmaścatuṣpāt sakalo dvija! | sa deśaḥ paramo nityaṃ sarvapuṇyatamo mataḥ |
translation: No loss ever occurs in that place where the four-pillared dharma always prevails; indeed, it is considered the supreme and most virtuous location.

sloka: gaṅgādvāre prayāge ca avimukte ca puṣkare | nagare cāṭṭahāse ca gaṅgāsāgarasaṅgame | kurukṣetre gayāyāñca tīrthe vā'marakaṇṭake | evamādiṣu tīrtheṣu dattamakṣayatāmiyāt | sarvatīrthamayī gaṅgā tatra dattaṃ mahāphalam |
translation: At the confluence of the Ganges, Prayaga, and unobstructed Pushkara, in the city's laughter, at the Ganga's shore, Amarakantaka, as well as other holy sites - offerings made without expectation of reward lead to the annihilation of sins. The all-holy Ganga, when given there, yields great fruit.

sloka: kuṭumbabhaktavasanād deyaṃ yadatiricyate | anyathā dīyate yaddhi na tad dānaṃ phalapradam ||
translation: Charity given, motivated by familial love and worn out as a cloak, is considered worthy. But if given otherwise, without such motivation, it does not bear fruit.

sloka: na taddānaṃ praśaṃsanti yena vṛttirvipadyate | dānaṃ yajñastapaḥ karma loke vṛttimato yataḥ || ||
translation: Not is that gift praised, through which one's conduct deviates. A gift, sacrifice, austerity, and action, in the world, are the causes of one's conduct.

sloka: brahmaṇāstapasā yuktā yathāśakti pradāyinaḥ | sahasraśaktiśca śataṃ śataśaktirdaśāpi ca || dadyādpaśca yaḥ śaktyā sarve tulyaphalāḥ smṛtāḥ | rantidevo hi nṛpatirapaḥ prādādakiñcanaḥ ||
translation: United with self-control and engaged in the study of Brahman, giving according to their ability, whether it be a thousand, hundred, or ten units of power, and also one who gives with whatever remaining power they have, all such givers are considered equal in fruit, as did King Rantideva, who gave even when he had nothing.

sloka: dharmāya yaśase'rthāya kāmāya svajanāya ca | pañcadhā vibhajan vittaṃ ihāmutra ca modate || ||
translation: For the sake of righteousness, fame, purpose, desire, and relatives, one derives pleasure here and hereafter by properly dividing wealth into five parts.

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā|| sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: Faith in beings is of three kinds and is inherent by nature: goodness-oriented, passion-oriented, and darkness-oriented. Listen to their descriptions.

sloka: dātavyamiti yaddānaṃ dīyate'nupakāriṇe | deśe kāle ca pātre ca taddānaṃ sātvikaṃ smṛtam || yattu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalamuddiśya vā punaḥ | dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṃ taddānaṃ rājasaṃ smṛtam ||
translation: Giving that is to be done refers to what is given to the ungrateful; it is considered righteous (sātvika) in terms of place, time, and recipient. However, giving with the expectation of fruit or with difficulty is considered passionate (rājasa).

sloka: adeśakāle yaddānamapātrebhyaśca dīyate | asatkṛtamavajñātaṃ tattāmasamudāhṛtam || dānaṃ trividhamityetatkaniṣṭhajyeṣṭhamadhyamam || tatra naiśreyasaṃ jyeṣṭhaṃ kaniṣṭhaṃ svārthasiddhaye || || kāruṇyātsarvabhūteṣu saṃvibhāgastu madhyamaḥ ||
translation: The gift given at the wrong time to undeserving persons and not recognized is called tāmasa; this classification of giving is the lowest. The gift given out of compassion for all beings is considered madhyama. The most excellent form of giving is that which leads to spiritual liberation (naiśreyasaṃ), while the gift given with selfish motivation is the lowest form (kaniṣṭham).

sloka: nityaṃ naimittikaṃ kāmyaṃ trividhaṃ dānamucyate | caturthaṃ vimalaṃ proktaṃ sarvadānottamottamam ||
translation: Regular, occasional, and desired are the three types of charity described; the fourth is pure, always considered superior.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ yācitaṃ nyāsamādhirdārāśca darśanam|| anvāhitaṃ ca nikṣepaḥ sarvasvaṃ cānvaye sati|| || āpatsvapi na deyāni navavastūni paṃḍitaiḥ|| yo dadāti sa mūḍhātmā prāyāścittīyate naraḥ|| ||
translation: Seeking the common is requested as a practice , along with seeing and making an offering . Relinquishing should be done only when it pertains to all one's own belongings . The wise must not give away newly acquired possessions . One who gives such things is considered foolish , and they incur the consequence of atonement .

sloka: jīvanmukto nāma svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmajñānena tadajñānabādhanadvārā svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmaṇi sākṣātkṛte ajñāna tatkārya sañcitakarma saṃśaya viparyayādīnāmapi bādhitatvāt akhilabandharahito brahmaniṣṭhaḥ || ||
translation: A liberated soul, named Svasvarupakhandabrahmajnana, is freed from all bonds in the Supreme Brahman, having destroyed ignorance through direct realization. All accumulated karma arising from doubt, misconception, etc., are eradicated in the Self-realized being established in Brahman.

sloka: evaṃ ca vedāntavākyaiḥ sadgurūpadeśena ca sarveṣvapi bhūteṣu yeṣāṃ brahmabuddhirutpannā te jīvanmuktāḥ ityarthaḥ |
translation: Thus, those whose understanding of Brahman has arisen through the teachings of a true guru and the Upanishadic texts are known as liberated while alive, in all beings.

sloka: sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim || ||
translation: What is the speech of one established in wisdom and focused in samadhi, O Kesava? What should one with steady mindset say or do, or where should they go?

sloka: rāgadveṣavimuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran | ātmavaśyairvidheyātmā prasādamadhigacchati || ||
translation: Free from attachment and aversion, with the senses under control, and by focusing on objects of sense with a balanced mind, one attains peace.

sloka: nanu jīvanmuktaḥ kaḥ ? yathā deho'haṃ puruṣo'haṃ brāhmaṇo'haṃ śūdro'hamasmīti dṛḍhaniścayastathā nāhaṃ brāhmaṇaḥ na śūdraḥ na puruṣaḥ kintu asaṃgaḥ saccidānanda svarūpaḥ prakāśarūpaḥ sarvāntaryāmī cidākāśarūpo'smīti dṛḍhaniścayarūpo'parokṣajñānavān jīvanmuktaḥ ||
translation: Indeed, who is a liberated soul ? As firmly established as I am this body, a purusha, a brahmana, a shudra, so too am I neither a brahmana nor a shudra nor a purusha. Rather, I am detached, the very embodiment of existence-consciousness-bliss , manifest , all-pervading , and of the nature of pure consciousness with a firm conviction of being so, and an unmediated self-knower .

sloka: jñātibhirvā nopajan~ smarannida~ śarīra~ sa yathā prayogya ācaraṇe yukta evamevāyamasmiñcharīre prāṇo yuktaḥ || ||
translation: Just as the vital breath is properly engaged in the physical activities when remembered by the cognizant beings, similarly I am properly engaged in this body.

sloka: dehaṃ ca naśvaramavasthitamutthitaṃ vā | siddho na paśyati yato'dhyagamat svarūpam | daivādapetamatha daivavaśād upetaṃ | vāso yathā parikṛtaṃ madirāmadāndhaḥ|| ||
translation: One who is established in the eternal soul does not see the body as either permanent or transient. Whether one is deprived of divine grace or receives it due to fate, they understand and fulfill their duties appropriately, just like a person intoxicated with alcohol is unaware of their surroundings.

sloka: jñānabhūmiḥ śubhecchākhyā prathamā samudāhṛtā| vicāraṇā dvitīyā tu tṛtīyā tanumānasā|| satvāpattiścaturthī syāttato'saṃsaktināmikā| padārthābhāvanī ṣaṣṭhī saptamī turyagā smṛtā||
translation: The first aspect revealed is the ground of knowledge, known as "subhecchā" (auspicious desire); the second is reflection, the third is the attainment of sattva (purity), then comes the detachment for those not overly attached; the sixth is the manifestation of the true meaning, and the seventh is known as turīya (the transcendental state) for the one who remembers.

sloka: yaṃ pravrajantamanupetamapetakṛtyaṃ dvaipāyano virahakātara ājuhāva | putreti tanmayatayā taravo'bhineduḥ taṃ sarvabhūtahṛdayaṃ munimānato'smi || || yaḥ svānubhāvamakhila śrutisāramekaṃ adhyātmadīpaṃ atititīrṣatāṃ tamo'ndham | saṃsāriṇāṃ karuṇayā''ha purāṇaguhyaṃ taṃ vyāsasūnumupayāmi guruṃ munīnām || ||
translation: The one who has set out on the path of renunciation, abandoning all duties, Dvaipayana (Vyasa) approached as a son, yearning with heartfelt love; I prostrate before that sage, who is the essence of all scriptures, the ultimate reality, and the light dispeller for those seeking to cross the ocean of transmigration, out of compassion for those bound by samsara.

sloka: aho kaṣṭaṃ bhraṣṭo'hamātmavatāmanupathādyadvimuktasamastasaṅgasya viviktapuṇyāraṇyaśaraṇasyātmavata ātmani sarveṣāmātmanāṃ bhagavati vāsudeve tadanuśravaṇamananasaṅkīrtanārādhanānusmaraṇābhiyogenāśūnyasakalayāmena kālena samāveśitaṃ samāhitaṃ kārtsnyena manastattu punarmamābudhasyārānmṛgasutamanu parisusrāva
translation: Alas, how difficult it is to have fallen away from being self-controlled, I, myself, am now struggling, having been liberated from all associations with worldly things, taking shelter in the secluded and pure forest of self-control. Through constant hearing, chanting, and remembering the glorious Lord Vāsudeva, my mind has become fully absorbed and engaged in him, except for a small part that still remains deluded and infatuated with worldly pleasures.

sloka: tatrāpi svajanasaṅgācca bhṛśamudvijamāno bhagavataḥ karmabandhavidhvaṃsanaśravaṇasmaraṇaguṇavivaraṇacaraṇāravindayugalaṃ manasā vidadhadātmanaḥ pratighātamāśaṅkamāno bhagavadanugraheṇānusmṛtasvapūrvajanmāvalirātmānamunmattajaḍāndhabadhirasvarūpeṇa darśayāmāsa lokasya
translation: Even there, being greatly agitated due to attachment to his own people, contemplating in his mind to obstruct the dissolution of bondage through hearing and remembering the glories of the Lord's actions, the deluded and ignorant bestower of himself, became manifest in his true form, due to the grace of the Supreme Person, to the world.

sloka: tanoti vipulānarthān tatvamantrasamanvitān trāṇaṃ ca kurute yasmāt tantramityabhidhīyate
translation: That which expands vast meanings while being associated with true mantras and provides protection is called a tantric system.

sloka: yujyante saṅklpyante sambadhyante parasparamarthāḥ samyaktayā prākaraṇike'bhimate'rthe virodhavyāghātādidoṣamapāsyānayā iti yuktiḥ yuj yojane tasmin yaktiriti rūpaṃ bhavati
translation: The arrangement of elements that are compatible, interconnected, and properly aligned in the correct context, devoid of any contradiction or conflict, becomes a system through the process of bringing together and integrating with each other, facilitated by the renunciation of inherent flaws – this is the meaning of 'yukti' (logic) in 'yuj' (uniting) those elements.

sloka: yathā'mbujavanasyārkaḥ pradīpo veśmano yathā || prabodha prakāśārthāstathā tantrasya yuktayaḥ | ekasminnapi yasyeha śāstre labdāspadā matiḥ|| sa śāstramanyadapyāśu yuktijñatvāt prabudhyate |
translation: Just as the sun is the lamp for the lotus and the light in a house, so too are the principles of a scripture the illumination of understanding within a person. When one finds the meaning of a scripture in just one place, they quickly become knowledgeable about its other principles due to this understanding.

sloka: dharmamūlaṃ vedamāhuḥ grantharāśimakṛtrimam| tadvidāṃ smṛtiśīle ca sādhvācāraṃ manaḥpriyam ||
translation: The root of dharma is declared to be the Vedas, abundant in collections of texts and otherwise. It is also pleasing to the mind of those who follow the path of righteousness and virtue.

sloka: śrautastretāgnisaṃbandhāt smārttaḥ pūrvaṃ mayoditaḥ | śreyaskaratamaḥ śrautastasmācchrautaṃ samācaret ||
translation: One who is established in traditional conduct and has been instructed before, should perform the non-Vedic (Smarta) rituals, having remembered them from the connectedness with the Vedic (Shrauta) fire, for this is the most auspicious of all dutiful actions.

sloka: ubhāvabhihitau dharmau vedavedaviniḥsṛtau | śiṣṭācārastṛtīyaḥ syācchratismṛtyoralābhataḥ ||
translation: The two dharmas (righteousness and religious duty) publicly declared in the Vedas and the act of leaving home for ascetic practices must be followed by a pious man as his secondary duty, apart from his primary conduct. This should be practiced until the attainment or loss of life.

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇāḥ proktā nityamātmaguṇānvitāḥ ||
translation: Those Brahmins who have attained, through dharma (righteousness), a complete understanding of the Vedas are constantly said to be endowed with their own noble qualities.

sloka: teṣāmabhimato yaḥ syāccetasā nityameva hi | sa dharmaḥ kathitaḥ sadbhirnānyeṣāmiti dhāraṇā ||
translation: The principle that is consistently and unanimously considered the choice of those minds is called Dharma.

sloka: śiṣṭāḥ khalu vigatamatsarā nirahaṃkārāḥ kumbhīdhānyā alolupā dambhadarpalobhamohakrodhavivarjitāḥ || dharmeṇādhigato yeṣāṃ vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | śiṣṭās tadanumānajñāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ || iti ||
translation: The upright ones, who are free from envy, pride, greed, delusion, and anger, who have acquired the Vedas through learning and perception, they are truly learned scholars, established in dharma.

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇā jñeyāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ | | |
translation: Those Brahmins who have attained, through dharma, a full understanding of the Vedas are to be considered virtuous; they are proven by scripture and direct perception.

sloka: dṛṣṭo dharmavyatikramaḥ sāhasaṃ ca mahatāṃ || ̥ṣṭō ḥ āṁ āṁ || iti| sāhasaṃ paraśurāmādeḥ mātuḥ śirachedādi|
translation: Observed as one who oversteps the bounds of dharma, and with a great sword has Parashurama, the son of his mother, beheaded.

sloka: kuśalācaritenaiṣāṃ iha svārtho na vidyate | viparyayeṇa vānartho nirahaṅkāriṇāṃ prabho || ||
translation: For these selfless ones, no personal benefit is found in proper conduct here; instead, harm results from the opposite.

sloka: dharmajñasamayaḥ pramāṇaṃ vedāśca| vedāśca
translation: The authority in matters of religious duty is the sacred texts at the appointed time , and the sacred texts again.

sloka: anānmāteṣu dharmeṣu kathaṃ syāditi cedbhavet | yaṃ śiṣṭā brāhṇā bhrūyuḥ sa dharmassyādaśāṅketaḥ|| | |
translation: How could virtue exist in actions lacking truthfulness, if the virtuous brahmins did not proclaim that as the established norm?

sloka: tadabhāve daśāvarā pariṣat|
translation: In the absence of that, the assembly consists of inferior members.

sloka: catvāro vedadharmajñāḥ pariṣatraividyameva vā| sā brūte yaṃ sa dharmassyādeko vā'dhyātmavittamaḥ||
translation: The four experts in Vedic duty, wandering or resting, speak of that one supreme self-realized individual who is the foremost authority on dharma.

sloka: vedāḥ pramāṇaṃ smṛtayaḥ pramāṇaṃ dharmārthayuktaṃ vacanaṃ pramāṇam| yasya pramāṇaṃ na bhavetpramāṇaṃ na tasya kuryādvacanaṃ pramāṇam||
translation: The Vedas and Smritis are the means of correct knowledge when it comes to dharma and artha. A statement is considered as a means of correct knowledge only if it aligns with the Vedas and Smritis; otherwise, it does not hold such a status.

sloka: tathā sampradāyo'pi kacitpramāṇamityāha manuḥ| svakulaparamparāyāta ācāraḥ sampradāyaḥ| so'pi śāstravipratipattau draṣṭavyaḥ|
translation: Thus, Manu declares that even traditional practices must be examined for consistency with scriptural principles . For, tradition , which is transmitted through family lineages , may or may not provide valid proof in determining proper conduct.

sloka: na me'nyatra kṣatriyāyā mano jātu pravartate| ṛṣiputrīṣu cānyāsu nāvarāsu parāsu ca||
translation: My mind never turns away from the kshatriya (woman) to others. Nor does it turn towards the daughters of sages or any other women, including those of lower status and wealth.

sloka: tasmātpraṇihitātmānaṃ viddi māṃ kalabhāṣiṇi| yasyāṃ me tvayi bhāvo'sti kṣatriyā hyasi kā vadā||
translation: Understand me, who has taken refuge in me, as your very self, O quick-witted one! In whom does my nature exist? You are, after all, a ksatriya – but which one, tell me.

sloka: smṛtiḥ pratyakṣamaitihyam | anumānaścatuṣṭayam |
translation: Consisting of sixfold [means of] knowing: memory, perception, historical testimony, and inference.

sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā | sa yenārthaṃ pramiṇoti tatpramāṇaṃ | yo'rthaḥ pratīyate tatprameyaṃ | yadarthavijñānaṃ sā pramitiḥ | catasṛṣu caivaṃvidhāsvārthatatvaṃ parisamāpyate |
translation: There, the volitional activity of one whose desire-driven speech is absent is the knower; that by which something is known is the means of knowledge. That which appears as an object is the determinable; knowledge of an object is determination; this is completed in four ways related to objects and their inherent nature.

sloka: yathā rajate idaṃ rajatamiti jñānam| saiva pramecyute ||||
translation: Just as this silver is considered (by some) to be shining, so is that knowledge proclaimed (to be true).

sloka: pramāṇamanubhūtiḥ sā smṛteranyā na sā smṛtiḥ | na pramāṇaṃ smṛtiḥ pūrvapratipattivyapekṣaṇāt|
translation: This experience that is a means of knowledge is called a type of memory distinct from another memory, which is not a means of knowledge because it depends on prior established practices.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects, intellect, mind, natural tendencies, faults, ending of existence, fruits of actions, and suffering - these are the subjects of inquiry. (This is a sutra from the Dvaita philosophy, which describes the various aspects of the individual self that one should investigate to gain knowledge and liberation.)

sloka: pramāṇato'rthapratipattau pravṛttisāmarththadarthavat pramāṇam | tasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya samīhā pravṛttirityucyate | dvayorekatarasya cāpi asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ pramā tatsādhakatamaṃ yattattrividhaṃ pramāṇaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The means of comprehending the true meaning, i.e., a valid proof, is that which has the capacity to lead to the understanding of the object in question, as expressed by pravṛttisāmarthadarthavat. This means of comprehension is referred to as pramāṇam. If someone is devoid of their own expression (ājihāsa) and instead relies on the words of another, then such a reliance on hearsay is called samīhā and is considered a type of valid proof. Additionally, even for one of two similar things, when there is a clear differentiation, it is also considered a form of valid proof known as asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ. These three forms, namely direct perception, inference, and valid testimony, are recognized as the three types of valid proofs according to Sāṃkhya sūtra.

sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā |
translation: Where the actions of someone, who is not influenced by their own desires and laughter, are those of a knower of truth.

sloka: agne samidhamāhārṣaṃ bṛhate jātavedase | sa me śraddhāṃ ca medhāṃ ca jātavedāḥ pra yacchatu ||
translation: I offer sacred fuel to Agni, the all-knowing. May he who is born as Jātavedas grant me faith and intelligence.

sloka: atha sapta pālāśīḥ samidha ārdrā apracchinnāgrāḥ prādeśamātrā ghṛtāktā abhyādhāpayati |
translation: Now seven palm-length wooden pieces , properly prepared with dried bark removed, split at one end , of specified length , smeared with ghee , are arranged .

sloka: agniṃ parisamūhya brahmacārī tūṣṇīṃ samidhamādadhyāt tūṣṇīṃ vai prājāpatyaṃ prājāpatyo brahmacārī bhavatīti vijñāyate
translation: Having gathered firewood in silence, the celibate student is understood to become a follower of the order of Prajapati through silently offering the oblation to the sacrificial fire.

sloka: sa idbhojo yo gṛhave dadātyannakāmāya carate kṛśāya | aramasmai bhavati yāmahūtā utāparīṣu kṛṇute sakhāyam || balaṃ balavato naśyedannahīnasya dehinaḥ| tasmādannaṃ viśeṣeṇa śraddhayāśraddhayāpi vā|| ādatte hi rasaṃ sarvamādityaḥ svagabhastibhiḥ| vāyustasmātsamādāya rasaṃ megheṣu dhārayet|| tattu meghagataṃ bhūmau śakro varṣati tādṛśam| tena digdhā bhaveddevī mahī prītā ca bhārata|| tasyāṃ sasyāni rohanti yairjīvantyakhilāḥ prajāḥ| māṃsamedo'sthimajjānāṃ sambhavastebhya eva hi||
translation: The householder who gives food to the desireless and the thin, to the appropriate recipient at the right time, and also prepares a feast for friends; strength does not decline for the strong person who gives food with faith, whether abundant or meager. Indeed, the sun extracts its juices from all plants with its rays, then the wind carries these juices into the clouds. When those cloud-borne juices rain down on this earth, the entire world, including plants and animals such as flesh, fat, bones, and marrow, is produced. Thus, O Bhārata, everything becomes nourished from that [food] offered with faith.

sloka: nīrajātaśca bhagavānsomo grahagaṇeśvaraḥ| amṛtaṃ ca sudhā caiva svāhā caiva svadhā tathā|| annauṣadhyo mahārāja vīrudhaśca jalodbhavāḥ| yataḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ prāṇāḥ sambhavanti viśāmpate|| devānāmamṛtaṃ hyannaṃ nāgānāṃ ca sudhā tathā| pitṝṇāṃ ca svadhā proktā paśūnāṃ cāpi vīrudhaḥ||
translation: The blessed Lord Soma, the ruler of planets, is born from water. There are also nectar and svadha, as well as the sacred syllables svaha and svadha. Great king, there are herbs and grains born from water, from which living entities' lives originate, including those of devas, who partake in nectar; nagas, who enjoy sudha; ancestors, who receive offerings with the word "svadha"; and animals, who consume vegetation.

sloka: tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ | ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī | pṛthivyā oṣadhayaḥ | oṣadhībhyo'nnam | annātpuruṣaḥ |
