translation: Therefore, from this self, space was born; from space, air; from air, fire; from fire, water; from water, earth; from earth, plants; from plants, food; and from food, the embodied being.

sloka: sa vā eṣa puruṣo'nnarasamayaḥ | tasyedameva śiraḥ | ayaṃ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamuttaraḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamātmā | idaṃ pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā | tadapyeṣa śloko bhavati ||
translation: Indeed, this person is of a unique kind, composed entirely of food. This very thing is his head; this one is his right wing; this other one is his left wing; this one is his self. This is his tail, the support of his bodily form. And yet, this verse describes him.

sloka: ahamasmi prathamajā ṛtasya | pūrvaṃ devebhyo amṛtasya nābhiḥ | yo mā dadāti sa ideva mā''vāḥ | ahamannamannamadantamadmi |
translation: I am the firstborn of truth and was before the gods, from me flows immortality. The one who gives (me) is indeed the god to be worshipped. I am the eater of food, the consumer of offerings.

sloka: annaṃ prāṇamannamapānamāhuḥ | annaṃ mṛtyuṃ tamu jīvātumāhuḥ | annaṃ brahmāṇo jarasaṃ vadanti | annamāhuḥ prajananaṃ prajānām |
translation: They call it "anna" (food) - the sustainer of life, the overcomer of death; "anna" is what the learned ones refer to as the very essence of creation, and the source of procreation for living beings.

sloka: bhojayecchvabhyaḥ śvapacebhyaśca vayobhyaścāvapedbhūmāviti nānavattamaśnīyānnaiko na pūrvaṃ | tadapyetadṛcoktaṃ moghamannaṃ vindate apracetā iti
translation: Should one feed only the dogs and outcastes along with the cows, or should one give alms to the young and elderly too? Neither is it the highest duty to partake in eating oneself, nor did the sage declare such ignorant consumption of food as not being in vain.

sloka: moghamannaṃ vindate apracetāḥ satyaṃ bravīmi vadha itsa tasya | nāryamaṇaṃ puṣyati no sakhāyaṃ kevalāgho bhavati kevalādī ||
translation: The unintelligent one attains only false nourishment, I declare the destruction of such a one; (for) they neither flourish as a friend nor become exclusively a source of harm.

sloka: abhyāgato jñātapūrvo hyajñāto'tithirucyate|
translation: The previous one is known as a guest who has come before, but the unknown one is called a guest who has yet to arrive.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | |
translation: The sun sets in the evening at the designated time, either at the appointed hour or any time thereafter; one should not remain without eating in the home at such a time.

sloka: sarveṣvevājasrā agnayaḥ syuḥ agnipūjā ca nityā yathā gṛhamedhe āvasathe śrotriyāvarārdhyānatithīnvāsayet teṣāṃ yathāguṇamāvasathāḥ śayyānnapānaṃ ca videyam
translation: Let all household fires always be kindled as prescribed, and also the daily worship of fire. Just as during the ritual called Gṛhamedha, one who is learned in the Vedas should honor guests, officials, and occasions with fitting hospitality, providing them with lodging, meals, and drink according to their merits.

sloka: abhṛtānāṃ bhavedbhartā bhṛtānāmanvavekṣakaḥ|
translation: Becoming the sustainer of the displaced and observer of those who support.

sloka: saṃvibhāgo hi bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāmeva dṛśyate| tathaivāpacamānebhyaḥ pradeyaṃ gṛhamedhinā||
translation: The distribution of all visible beings is certainly observed. Similarly, alms should be given to those who have not eaten (apacamanebhyah) by the householder.

sloka: dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ yudhiṣṭhira ||
translation: Offer protection to the helpless, Yudhishthira.

sloka: yanna prāpyaṃ tadaprāpyaṃ vidyayā pauruṣeṇa vā | satyo lokapravādo'yaṃ nādattamupatiṣṭhati ||
translation: Except for the truthful declaration of the world, nothing can be attained without knowledge, effort, or otherwise; it does not establish itself.

sloka: annaṃ dehi sadā rājan sarvakālasukhāvaham || annena caiva dattena kiṃ na dattaṃ mahītale |||| sarveṣāmeva dānānāmannadānaṃ viśiṣyate || annādbhavanti bhūtāni annenaiva ca varddhate ||||
translation: O king, always give food , for what is not given through this gift of food in this world ? Among all gifts, the giving of food is the most excellent . From food living beings arise, and it is also by food that they are nourished .

sloka: na kañcana vasatau pratyācakṣīta | tadvratam | tasmādyayā kayā ca vidhayā bahvannaṃ prāpnuyāt | arādhyasmā annamityācakṣate | | edadvā antato'nna~rāddham | antato'smā anna~rādhyate || ||
translation: One should never turn away an invitee seeking shelter, for such is the vow. If one fails to keep this vow, they will not acquire wealth, respect, or even food; for food is revered and worshipped from within.

sloka: na tasmātparamaṃ dānaṃ kiñcidastīti me manaḥ| annātprāṇabhṛtastāta pravardhante hi sarvaśaḥ|| tasmādannaṃ paraṃ loke sarvalokeṣu kathyate| annādbalaṃ ca tejaśca prāṇināṃ vardhate sadā||
translation: "In my opinion, there is no gift superior to food. Indeed, all aspects of life-force grow from it. Therefore, in all worlds, food is declared the ultimate. Food also becomes the strength and luster of living beings."

sloka: annena dhāryate sarvaṃ jagadetaccarācaram| annātprabhavati prāṇaḥ pratyakṣaṃ nāsti saṃśayaḥ||
translation: The entire moving and non-moving universe is sustained by this . There is no doubt that life originates from it .

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstra caturthantu vidyā hmaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharva Veda, with the fourth being Artha Shastra, and then there are sixteen branches of knowledge.

sloka: iha khalvāyurvedaṃ nāmopāṅgamatharvavedasyānutpādyaivaprajāḥ ślokaśata sahasramadhyāyasahasraṃ ca kṛtavān svayambhūḥ tato'lpāyuṣṭvamalpamedha stvaṃ cālokya narāṇāṃ bhūyo'ṣṭadhā praṇītavān vidhātātharvvasarvasvamāyurvedaṃ prakāśayan| svanāmnā saṃhitāṃ cakre lakṣaślokamayīmṛjum” iti bhāvaprakāśokteḥ |
translation: Here, in this world, the creator Self, without being prompted, brought into existence

sloka: caraṇavyūhamate ṛgvedasyopavedaḥ āyurvedaḥ
translation: The Upaveda of the Rigveda, associated with the arrangement of movements, is Ayurveda.

sloka: kimicchantī saramā predamānaḍdūre hyadhvā jaguriḥ parācaiḥ | kāsmehitiḥ kā paritakmyāsītkathaṃ rasāyā ataraḥ payāṃsi ||
translation: What is it that Sarma desires, standing so close and yet keeping a distance from me, even while I am facing away from her? What could be the reason for this strange behavior of hers, and why does she appear to be so distant even as she is near?

sloka: kīdṛṅṅindraḥ sarame kā dṛśīkā yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraḥ parākāt | ā ca gacchānmitramenā dadhāmāthā gavāṃ gopatirno bhavāti || nāhaṃ taṃ veda dabhyaṃ dabhatsa yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraṃ parākāt | na taṃ gūhanti sravato gabhīrā hatā indreṇa paṇayaḥ śayadhve ||
translation: Who, I wonder, is this Indra in whose service this spy (message-bearer) has come from afar, and who cannot be concealed even by the deepest councils of the enemy? For I do not know him, nor does he approach me as a friend; he is the protector of cows, but is no ordinary protector. The gods do not protect one who despises them, and those who are protected by the strong are not easily conquered.

sloka: imā gāvaḥ sarame yā aicchaḥ pari divo antānsubhage patantī | kasta enā ava sṛjādayudhvyutāsmākamāyudhā santi tigmā || asenyā vaḥ paṇayo vacāṃsyaniṣavyāstanvaḥ santu pāpīḥ | adhṛṣṭo va etavā astu panthā bṛhaspatirva ubhayā na mṛl̤āt ||
translation: These cows, longed for by the serpent, are falling towards the edge of the sky in this world. What strength could drive them away from our weapons? Let your messengers be free from sinful tendencies and let no harm come to them. May there be a path that is not overbearing, as Brihaspati is on both sides and not cruel.

sloka: ayaṃ nidhiḥ sarame adribudhno gobhiraśvebhirvasubhirnyṛṣṭaḥ | rakṣanti taṃ paṇayo ye sugopā reku padamalakamā jagantha || eha gamannṛṣayaḥ somaśitā ayāsyo aṅgiraso navagvāḥ | ta etamūrvaṃ vi bhajanta gonāmathaitadvacaḥ paṇayo vamannit || evā ca tvaṃ sarama ājagantha prabādhitā sahasā daivyena | svasāraṃ tvā kṛṇavai mā punargā apa te gavāṃ subhage bhajāma || nāhaṃ veda bhrātṛtvaṃ no svasṛtvamindro viduraṅgirasaśca ghorāḥ | gokāmā me acchadayanyadāyamapāta ita paṇayo varīyaḥ || dūramita paṇayo varīya udgāvo yantu minatīrṛtena | bṛhaspatiryā avindannigūl̤hāḥ somo grāvāṇa ṛṣayaśca viprāḥ ||
translation:
This treasure, lying on the peak of the mountain and scattered with the help of cows, goats, and other animals, is protected by those who are skilled in guarding. Who among them, possessing excellent qualities and good conduct, always protects this? Approach these noblekeepers who are always intoxicated with the nectar of Soma. Let us worship this new offering from the Angirasa seers. In this manner, you too have now come to protect it, oh auspicious one, struck down suddenly by a divine force. I will create a bond between you and this treasure, oh Sarama, so that you may never abandon these fortunate cows again.

I do not know if there is any relationship of brotherhood or consanguinity between us, Indra, Viduraṅgirasa, or the terrifying seers who desire the cows. May those worthy keepers, stationed far away, come here with proper rituals. Bṛhaspati, Soma, and the Ṛṣi seers will not recognize them.

sloka: asurāḥ paṇayo nāma rasāpāranivāsinaḥ | piveyaṃ tu payastāsāṃ gavāṃ yāstā niguhatha | asurāstāṃ tathetyuktvā tadājahuḥ payastataḥ sā svabhāvācca laulyācca pātvā tat paya āsuram |
translation: The named cooks, called "asuras," who reside near the liquor, when this (liquor) is drunk by them, they forcibly steal the cows of the people. Then, uttering the word "asuri," they drink the liquid themselves, driven by their nature and greed.

sloka: tāṃ jaghāna tadā kruddha udgirantau payastataḥ jagāma sā bhayodvignā punareva paṇān prati
translation: Then, enraged, he struck her there. She, filled with fear, went to the cowshed once again.

sloka: atha ha vai paṇayo nāmāsurā devānāṃ gorakṣā āsuḥ| tābhir ahāpātasthuḥ| tā ha rasāyāṃ nirudhya valenāpidadhuḥ| te devā aliklavam ūcus suparṇemā no gā anviccheti| te saramām abruvan sarama imā nas tvaṃ gā anviccheti|
translation: Now indeed, the keepers named Asuras served as protectors of the gods' cattle. With them, a dispute arose regarding a particular water source. After obstructing it with a dam, they challenged both Garuda and Sarama, saying "Who will drink this (water) first?"

sloka: aitareyabrāhmaṇe'sti kāṇḍamāraṇyakābhidham | araṇya aiva pāṭhyatvādāraṇyakamitīryate || satraprakaraṇe'nuktiraraṇyādhyayanāya hi | mahāvratasya tasyātra hautra karma vivicyate ||
translation: The Book known as the Āraṇyaka is contained within the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa. It is called Āraṇyaka because it is meant to be studied in the forest. In the Satarudriya section, instructions for its study in the forest are given. Here, the specific ritual duties of the great vow (Mahāvrata) are detailed.

sloka: araṇyādhyayanādetad āraṇyakamitīryate | araṇaye tadadhīyītetyevaṃ vākyaṃ pracakṣyate ||
translation: This saying is proclaimed: "Because of studying in the forest, this (text) is called Āraṇyaka." Indeed, it should be learned in the forest.

sloka: tasyā bharturabhicāra uktaṃ prāyaścittaṃ rahasyeṣu
translation: The prescribed expiation for her husband's secret adultery was spoken (to her).

sloka: eṣa vai somo rājā devānāmannaṃ yaccandramāḥ|
translation: This is indeed the king Soma for the gods, that which is the nourishment of the moon.

sloka: yat idaṃ asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharoഽsmin antarākāśaḥ tasmin yadantaḥ tadanveṣṭavyaṃ tad vāva vijijñāsitavym … …
translation: In this city of Brahman, the small and lotus-like dwelling, seek within that inner space what is contained there; that indeed is worth knowing.

sloka: śataṃ caikā hṛdasya nāḍyaḥ tāsāṃ mūrdhānamabhiniḥsṛtaikā tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti viṣvaṅṅanyā utkramaṇe bhavanti
translation: A hundred and one are the channels of the heart . Among them, the one that arises from the top leads to immortality during the upward journey . The others , upon departure , become part of the surrounding area.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmin is to be known by birth; a dvija, through sacred rites. By learning, one becomes a vipra. The marks of a triple-vedic student are characterized as the ability to distinguish between proper and improper penances.

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate || ||
translation: The one who performs rituals such as agnihotra, new and full moon sacrifices, starting with agniṣṭoma, is considered the priest of that household.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation: Just as from the navel of the cosmic being are created clay and herbs, and just as from his hair and body grow trees and plants, so too does this entire universe emerge from the imperishable.

sloka: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavidyasya jñānamayaṃ tāpaḥ | tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyāte || ||
translation: The one who is all-knowing and consists of knowledge of all sciences, from him arises the heat (tapah) of spiritual practice. Therefore, this Brahman is named as that form and food.

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The meters, sacrifices, and rituals, as well as what has been and will be, the Vedas declare; from me arises this whole moving and non-moving world; but another is enveloped by my māyā and lies immersed in ignorance.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyavayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: Regarding maya (illusion), it is just prakriti (primordial nature), and the one who manipulates it, the Maheshvara (the great lord), is mayin. This entire world is pervaded by its constituent parts.

sloka: mayā'dhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram|
translation: Under my supervision, nature (prakriti) produces both moving and non-moving entities (sacara-acaram).

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ| nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam||||
translation: The three qualities born of Prakriti - Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas - bind the imperishable self within the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: mūlaprakṛtiravikṛtirmahadādyā: prakṛtivikṛtaya: sapta | ṣoḍaśakastu vikāro na prakṛtirna vikṛti: puruṣa: || ||
translation: The original, unchanging primal nature and its transformed forms constitute the seven; the sixteen transformations are neither the original nor the transformed, but the Purusha.

sloka: tasmātprakṛtirutpannā puruṣeṇa samanvitā || tābhyāntapaḥ kṛtaṃ tatra mūlasthe ca jale sudhīḥ || ||
translation: Arising from prakriti, endowed with purusha, from them originates the cleansing action and, in the root and in water, the intelligence.

sloka: saṃbhāvya māyayā yuktastatra supto harissa vai || nārāyaṇeti vikhyātaḥ prakṛtirnārāyaṇī matā || ||
translation: Presumed to be united with his divine power, the Lord sleeps there. That Narayana is well-known as the primal nature.

sloka: parātmanastathā śaktestayoraikyaṃ sadaiva hi | abhinnaṃ tadvapurjñātvā mucyate sarvadoṣataḥ || ||
translation: Realizing the unity of the supreme self and power, which eternally exists, one is freed from all faults.

sloka: tasya cecchāsmyahaṃ daitya sṛjāmi sakalaṃ jagat | sa māṃ paśyati viśvātmā tasyāhaṃ prakṛtiḥ śivā || ||
translation: If he thinks of me, I myself create the entire universe for him. He, the cosmic self, sees me as his auspicious nature.

sloka: rāma māyā dvidhā bhāti vidyā'vidyeti te sadā |
translation: Invariably, Rama's maya appears twofold: as knowledge and ignorance.

sloka: dvividhā tu khalu tadvidyasaṃbhāṣā bhavati sandhāyasaṃbhāṣā vigṛhyasaṃbhāṣā ca |
translation: Indeed, the speech of the knowers of the Truth is of two kinds - one is smooth and acceptable, while the other is harsh and unacceptable.

sloka: prāgeva ca jalpājjalpāntaraṃ parāvarāntaraṃ pariṣadviśeṣāṃśca samyak parīkṣet parīkṣamāṇastu khalu parāvarāntaramimān jalpakaguṇān śreyaskarān doṣavataśca parīkṣeta samyak
translation: Previously and even now, one who is scrutinizing should thoroughly examine the qualities of those who are in power or influential positions, as well as their own abilities. Indeed, they should accurately assess the meritorious and faulty speech-related qualities of those who engage in disputes.

sloka: tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninastattvadarśinaḥ ||
translation: By approaching, inquiring, and serving, the wise ones who have realized the truth will teach you knowledge.

sloka: jñānagrahaṇābhyāsastadvidyaiśca saha saṃvādaḥ || ||| taṃ śiṣyagurusabrahmacāriviśiṣṭaśreyo'rthibhiranasūyubhirabhyupeyāt || || pratipakṣahīnamapi vā prayojanārthamarthitve || ||
translation: The practice of acquiring knowledge through discussion with experienced teachers is to be pursued by a worthy disciple, who is free from envy and should be engaged in for its own sake, as well as for counteracting opposing forces, if necessary.

sloka: jñāyate'neneti jñānamātmavidyāśāstram | tasya grahaṇamadhyayanadhāraṇe abhyāsaḥ satatakriyā'dhyayanaśravaṇacintanāni tadvidyaiśca | saha saṃvāda iti prajñāparipākārthe paripākastu saṃśayacchedanamavijñātārthabodho'dhyavasitābhyanujñānamiti | samāpavādaḥ saṃvādaḥ | vābhā |
translation: Knowledge is said to arise from the inquiry of 'what is this?' The scripture concerned with self-knowledge is acquired through repeated study, reflection, and contemplation. Accompanied by discussion with knowledgeable individuals, it leads to the clarification of doubts, understanding of unknown meaning, and obtaining permission from the teacher for further learning. This is the complete maturation of wisdom. Additionally, there can be dialogue or debate for better comprehension.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||||
translation: Debate is the adoption of five limbs (avayava) - proofs (pramana), reasoning (tarka), means of attaining goals (sadhana), support (upalambha) for a position that is free from contradiction (siddhanta-aviruddha) and encompasses the acceptance (parigraha) of one's own position (paksha) and refutation (pratipaksa) of opposing views.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ
translation: As explained, that which is described as insincere, arising from deceitful nature, reliant on supporting arguments for establishing one's own position - such a debate is called jalpa.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyotkarṣāpakarṣavarṇyāvarṇyavikalpasādhyaprāptyaprāptiprasaṅgapratidṛṣṭāntānutpattisaṃśayaprakaraṇahetvarthāpattyaviśeṣopapattyupalabdhyanupalabdhinityānityakāryasamāḥ || ||
translation: Resolution of doubts regarding the establishment and non-establishment of harmony, difference, superiority, inferiority, distinction, contradiction, examples, origination, uncertainty, context, cause, effect, specialty, acquisition, perception, and non-perception of sādharmya, vaidharmya, kārya, and akārya.

sloka: pratijñāhāniḥ pratijñāntaraṃ pratijñāvirodhaḥ pratijñāsaṃnyāso hetvantaramarthāntaraṃ nirarthakamavijñātārthamapārthakamaprāptakālaṃ nyūnamadhikaṃ punaruktamananubhāṣaṇamajñānamapratibhā vikṣepo matānujñā paryanuyojyopekṣaṇaṃ niranuyojyānuyogo'pasiddhānto hetvābhāsāśca nigrahasthānāni || ||
translation: Abandonment of a promise, inconsistency in promises, contradiction of a promise, giving up on making a decision, another's property as an alternative, irrelevant or misunderstood meaning, unrelated purpose, inappropriate time, excessively explained, previously explained, unconscious utterance or distraction, intentionally ignored, accepted against one's will, established principles, illusory aspects, and the means to control them.

sloka: aviśeṣābhihite arthe vaktuḥ abhiprāyātarthāntarakalpanā vākchalam ||||
translation: The speaker, in referring to an implied topic, is capable of intending a meaning other than the literal one.

sloka: sambhavataḥ arthasya atisāmānyayogātasambhūtārthakalpanā sāmānyacchalam ||||
translation: Given the origin of the meaning, due to the rare combination of extraordinary circumstances, it is inappropriate to form a general concept of that meaning.

sloka: dharmavikalpanirdeśe arthasadbhāvapratiṣedhaḥ upacāracchalam ||||
translation: In the exposition of dharma's (righteousness) alternatives being prohibited, the unsteadiness of deceitful conduct.

sloka: yadā vādī parasya sādhanaṃ sādhviti manyate lābhapūjākhyātikāmaśca bhavati tadā jātiṃ prayuṅkte kadācidayaṃ jātyuttareṇākulīkṛto nottaraṃ pratipadyate uttarāpratipattyā ca nigṛhyate | anabhidhāne ca jātirekāntajayaḥ parasyetyaikāntikātparājayādvaramastu saṃdeha iti yukto jāteḥ prayogaḥ || nyāvā ||
translation: When one considers the means to success of another to be righteous and is motivated by fame and honor, then they seek to join a higher caste. If, due to mingling with a different caste, they are not accepted in their own caste, they may try to regain their status through subsequent actions. However, if their caste is not clearly defined, victory or defeat in relation to their caste becomes uncertain and debatable. This is the argument regarding the use of caste. || nyāvā ||

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||||
translation: He who has not established counter measures and does not engage in harsh words.

sloka: svapakṣarāgeṇa caike nyāyamativartante taca | tattvādhyavasāyasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ jalpavitaṇḍe bījaprarohasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ kaṇṭakaśākhāvaraṇavat || ||
translation: Some, adhering to their own sect, deviate from justice. To protect the established truth and nurture the seed of right knowledge, like a thorny branch protecting a growing plant.

sloka: vidyānirvedādibhiśca pareṇāvajñāyamānasya | tābhyāṃ vigṛhya kathanam || || vigṛhyeti vijigīṣayā na tattvabubhutsayeti | tadetadvidyāpālanārthaṃ na lābhapūjākhyātyarthamiti |
translation: Undertaking the discussion of vidya and nirveda, etc., while disregarding those greater than oneself, implies a desire to conquer rather than understand the true nature of these subjects. This is not for the purpose of gaining fame or wealth, but for the sake of preserving knowledge.

sloka: budhajanairvādaḥ parityajyatām || ||
translation: Reject the debate (vādaḥ), that is being held by the wise (budha janaiḥ).

sloka: pakṣābhyāṃ ca mayā gupto jaṭāyurna pradahyate| pramādāttatra nirdagdhaḥ patanvāyupathādaham||||
translation: Even though my dreadlocked hair is protected by both sides (of the fire), it is not to be burned due to carelessness; I (who am) destroyed by falling from the path of wind (i.e., sky).

sloka: purā vṛtravadhe vṛtte parasparajayaiṣiṇau| ādityamupayātau svo jvalantaṃ raśmimālinam||||
translation: In the past, engaged in the battle of Vritra's destruction, they approached (each other), the radiant Aditya, adorned with blazing rays.

sloka: taṃ māmevaṃ gataṃ putrassupārśvonāma nāmataḥ| āhāreṇa yathākālaṃ bibharti patatāṃ varaḥ||||
translation: The excellent son supports me, who has come to me in this way, using the name "Suparsva" at the appropriate times.

sloka: sampātirnāma nāmnā tu cirañjīvī vihaṅgamaḥ| bhrātā jaṭāyuṣaḥ śrīmānvikhyātabalapauruṣaḥ||||
translation: Sampati is named the long-lived bird, the brother of Jatayus, known for his strength and valor.

sloka: ahaṃ tāta yathākālamāmiṣārthī khamāplutaḥ| mahendrasya girerdvāramāvṛtya susamāsthitaḥ|||| eva muktastato'haṃ taissiddhai: paramaśobhanaiḥ| sa ca me rāvaṇo rājā rakṣasāṃ prativeditaḥ|||| harandāśaratherbhāryāṃ rāmasya janakātmajām| bhraṣṭābharaṇakauśeyāṃ śokavegaparājitām|||| rāmalakṣmaṇayornāma krośantīṃ muktamūrdhajām|
translation: "Father, just as I have always been a pursuer of desires, floating in the sky, steadily positioned above the peak of Mount Mahendra, so too have I been freed from these supremely radiant accomplishments. Now, King Ravana of the rakshasas is known to be my adversary. The daughter of Janaka, wife of Rama, who was adorned but has now lost her ornaments and been overwhelmed by the force of grief, with disheveled hair, calls out the names of Rama and Lakshmana."

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yannu ma iyaṃ bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te jīvitaṃ syāt amṛtatvasya tu nā''śā'sti vitteneti
translation: Maitreyi asked, "How can this whole earth be filled with wealth and make me immortal?" Yajnavalkya replied, "Just as the life of material objects depends on other material objects, so does your life depend on it. However, there is no such thing as immortality through wealth."

sloka: yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ jighrati taditara itaraṃ paśyati taditara itara śṛṇoti taditara itaramabhivadati taditara itaraṃ manute taditara itaraṃ vijānāti | yatra vā asya sarvamātmaivābhūt tatkena kaṃ jighret tatkena kaṃ paśyet tatkena ka śṛṇuyāt tatkena kamabhivadet tatkena kaṃ manvīta tatkena kaṃ vijānīyāt | yeneda sarvaṃ vijānāti taṃ kena vijānīyād vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāditi || ||
translation: Where duality arises, one person smells another, sees another, listens to another, speaks to another, thinks of another, and recognizes another. But where all aspects become one's own self, then what should one smell, see, hear, speak to, think of, or recognize? The one who knows everything, how is he to be known? Who can know the knower itself?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ śraddhāṃ juhoti taseyā āhuteḥ somo rājā saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer their faith; from that offering of faith, Soma, the king, comes into being.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ somā~ rājānaṃ juhoti tasyā āhutervarṣa saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer oblations to the king of soma; from that offering, a rain shower arises.

sloka: dhūmaḥ jyotiḥsalilamarutāṃ sannipātaḥ kva meghaḥ
translation: Where in the gathering of clouds, smoke and lightning meet with rain-bearing winds?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ varṣaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteranna~ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer a rain sacrifice; from that oblation, fire is not born.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ annaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteretaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer oblations; from that offering, heat is generated.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ reto juhoti tasyā āhutergarbhaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods sacrifice semen; from its offering, a embryo is generated.

sloka: sūrasuryāryamādityadvādaśātmadivākarāḥ | bhāskarāhaskarabradhnaprabhākaradivākarāḥ bhāsvadvisvatsaptāśvaharidaśvoṣṇaraśmayaḥ | vikartanārkamārtaṇḍamihirāruṇapūṣaṇaḥ dyumaṇistaraṇirmitrascitrabhānurvirocanaḥ | vibhāvasurgrahapatistviṣāṃpatiraharpatiḥ bhānurhaṃsaḥ sahasrāṃśustapanaḥ savitā raviḥ | māṭharaḥ piṅlo daṇḍaścaṇḍāṃśoḥ pāripārśvikāḥ
translation: The twelve radiant sun-gods, including Surya and Aditya, who possess the splendor of

sloka: svīryateḥ vā | suvateḥ vā | sūryaḥ sarteḥ vā |
translation: Either the powerful one (Surya) or the auspicious one, which one is separate from her?

sloka: sūryasya patnī saṃjñābhūttanayā viśvakarmaṇaḥ | manuryamo yamī caiva tadūpatyāni vai mune || || saṃjñayamityathārkaśva chāyāyāmātmajatrayama | śanaiśvaraṃ manuñcanyaṃ tapatīñcapyajījanat || || tato vivasvānākhyāte tayaivāraṇyasaṃsthitām | samādhidṛṣṭayā dadṛśe tāmaśvāṃ tapasi svitāma || || vājirūpadharaḥ so'tha tasyāṃ devāvathāśvinau | janayāmāsa revantaṃ retaso'nte ca bhāskaraḥ || ||
translation: The wife of Surya, known as Sanjna, gave birth to three offspring sired by Vishvakarma: Manu, Yama, and Yamī. She then assumed the forms of Uttānayā, the sun's heat, and Chāyā. Lord Vivasvān, stationed in the forest, beheld with his spiritual vision Sanjna engaged in severe austerity as Tapasvi Svitāma. In her, the two Asvinī devatās begot Revanta and Bhāskara was born from the remainder of semen.

sloka: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tanmahitvaṃ madhyā kartorvitataṃ saṃ jabhāra yadedayukta haritaḥ sadhasthādādrātrī vāsastanute simasmai
translation: That is the divinity of the sun, the power that resides in the mid-region, joined with the dawn, making the earth verdant and nourishing for all beings.

sloka: tatsaviturvareṇyaṃ bhargo devasya dhīmahi | dhiyo yo naḥ pracodayāt ||
translation: We meditate on the splendor of that divine Savitar; May he inspire our intellect.

sloka: oṃ bhūrbhuvaḥ svaḥ | tatsa̭vi॒turvareṇya॒ṃ bhargo̭ de॒vasya̭dhīmahi | dhiyo॒ yo na̭ḥ praco॒dayā̭t ||
translation: Om. Let us meditate on the brilliance of the divine creator, who is superior to all, and whose existence is praised in the three realms (earth, atmosphere, and heaven). May he inspire our intellect.

sloka: ṛgbhiḥ pūrvāhṇe divi deva īyate | yajurvede tiṣṭhati | madhye ahnaḥ | sāmavedenāstamaye mahīyate | vedairaśūnyastribhireti sūryaḥ |
translation: In the early morning, the god rises in the sky with rays; at midday, it rests in the Yajurveda; at dusk, it sets in the Sama Veda; and when devoid of the three Vedas, it is known as the sun.

sloka: suṣumno harikeśaśca viśvakarmā tathaiva ca | viśvaśravāḥ punaścānyaḥ saṃyadvasurataḥ paraḥ || arvāvasuriti khyātaḥ svarakaḥ sapta kīrtitāḥ | suṣumnaḥ sūryaraśmistu puṣṇāti śiśiradyutim ||
translation: Susumna and Harikesha, along with Visvakarma, are known to have excellent character and are celebrated by the name Samyatvasurata. They are also called Arvavasu, Svaraka, and Saptakirtita. Their sun-like radiance nourishes the cool splendor of the winter months, just as the rays of the sun nourish the lotus.

sloka: saṃsthitenaikacakreṇa paṃcāreṇa trinābhinā || hiraṇmayena bhagavāṃstathaiva haridarvaṇā || ||
translation: Established in a single wheel with five spokes and three navels, golden and shining like the sun's rays.

sloka: ete tapanti varṣanti bhānti vānti sṛjanti ca | bhūtānāmaśubhaṃ karma vyapohantīha kīrttitāḥ || ete sahaiva sūryeṇa bhramanti divi bhānugāḥ | vimāne ca sthito nityaṃ kāmage vātaraṃhasi ||
translation: These [sun and others] heat up, rain, shine, and create; they are known to rid living beings of evil deeds here. Together with the sun, they constantly move in the sky, residing in the wind on desire-filled clouds.

sloka: saratho'dhiṣṭhito devairādityairmunibhistathā || gaṃdharvairapsarobhiśca grāmaṇīsarparākṣasaiḥ || ||
translation: Seated on the chariot, being established by the gods, Ādityas, and sages, as well as by Gandharvas, Apsaras, ordinary people, serpents, and Rākṣasas.

sloka: sūryeṇa viṣuvaṃ vidyā tkālaṃ somena lakṣayet || samā rātrirahaścaiva yadā tadviṣuvaṃ bhavet || ||
translation: The length of daytime can be determined using the sun, and that of nighttime using the moon, at that point in time when they are equal.

sloka: devaliṅ‌gapraticchannaḥ svarbhānurdevasaṃsadi | praviṣṭaḥ somamapibat candrārkābhyāṃ ca sūcitaḥ || ||
translation: Having disguised himself in the assembly of the gods, the sun god entered, making himself known by drinking the soma offered during the ritual along with the moon.

sloka: pramāṇaprameyasaṃśayaprayojanadṛṣṭāntasiddhāntāvayavatarkanirṇayavādajalpavitaṇḍāhetvābhāsacchalajātinigrahasthānānāṃ tatvajñānānniḥśreyasādhigamaḥ || {padārthoddeśasūtram}
translation: Gaining ultimate benefit comes from knowing the truth through understanding the components of means of right knowledge , knowable , doubt , purpose , example , conclusion , arguments , analysis , debate , pointless contention , fallacy , irrelevant argument , deception , false reasoning , suppression of and establishing their counterparts.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, comparison, and verbal testimony are the means of correct knowledge. (pramāṇas are the means to acquire right knowledge; here they are explained as pratyakṣa or direct perception, anumāna or inference, upamāna or comparison, and śabda or verbal testimony)

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects of the senses, intellect, and mind, along with their activities, faults, results after death, suffering, and liberation – all these constitute the worthy object of knowledge.

sloka: samānānekadharmopapatteḥ vipratipatteḥ upalabdhyanupalabdhyavyavasthātaḥ ca viśeṣāpekṣaḥ vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ || {saṃśayalakṣaṇam}
translation: Inquiry accompanied by consideration of the equal and numerous attributes, their presence or absence, and the uncertainty arising from dependence on distinct aspects constitutes skepticism, as defined.

sloka: yaṃ arthaṃ adhikṛtya pravartate tatprayojanam ||{prayojanalakṣaṇam}
translation: Determining the purpose consists in activating (pravartate) that means (yam) for which objective (artham) has been assigned (adhikṛtya).

sloka: laukikaparīkṣakāṇāṃ yasminarthe buddhisāmyaṃ saḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ || {dṛṣṭāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: For scholars who examine mundane matters, in what matter does their consensus emerge? That is the illustrative example.

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established conclusion is the acceptance of jurisdiction in relation to a tantra.

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ || {avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The components of a theme are the promise, reason, example, introduction, conclusion, and parts. (Avayavauddesasutra)

sloka: avijñātatatve arthe kāraṇopapattitaḥ tattvajñānārthaṃ uhaḥ tarkaḥ||
translation: For establishing the knowledge of the true nature of that which is not yet known , reasoning is employed as a means .

sloka: vimṛśya pakṣapratipakṣābhyāṃ arthāvadhāraṇaṃ nirṇayaḥ||
translation: After careful consideration of both sides and the meaning, reaching a resolution or decision.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||
translation: Debate that is based on proofs, reasoning, means of valid knowledge, and examples; that is in accordance with established tenets, has five limbs, involves consideration of both sides – this is called debate.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ ||
translation: As has been mentioned, a debate that is unstable, based on caste, takes place using makeshift means to establish its position.

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||
translation: He who has not established counter-measures and does not refrain from harshness.

sloka: savyabhicāraviruddhaprakaraṇasamasādhyasamakālātītāḥ hetvābhāsāḥ ||
translation: Illusions of causes that are incompatible with the proper context , have objectives that are contrary to the intended meaning, occur at the same time , are not yet accomplished, and are related to the left-side or deviating from the correct path.

sloka: vacanavighātaḥ arthavikalpopapattyā chalam ||
translation: Deflection from the intended meaning of speech arises due to ambiguity and false assumptions.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyābhyāṃ pratyavasthānaṃ jātiḥ||
translation: The classification is based on similarities and differences that becomes apparent through comparison and establishes a stable state .

sloka: vipratipattiḥ apratipattiḥ ca nigrahasthānam || tadvikalpātjātinigrahasthānabahutvam ||
translation: The occurrence or non-occurrence of proper preparation results in a single outcome: the state of subjugation; arising from the choice between the two is the multitude of states of subjugation.

sloka: duḥkhajanmapravṛttidoṣamithyājñānānāṃ uttarottarāpāye tadanantarāpāyātapavargaḥ||
translation: Relief from the accumulated and continually arising suffering caused by repeatedly emerging false knowledge.

sloka: śvetā raktā ca pītā ca kṛṣṇā kāpotasannibhā | tiktā ca kaṭukā caiva kaṣāyalavaṇāmlakā || madhurā ṣaḍrasopetā sarvasampatkarī dharā |
translation: White, red, and yellow, as well as blue-black like a crow, also pungent and astringent, as well as ashy and salty; sweet-tasting and endowed with all six flavors, it is the sustainer of all forms of wealth.

sloka: vakṣye'haṃ grāmavinyāsaṃ śāstre saṃkṣepataḥ kramāt | daṇḍakaṃ sarvatobhadraṃ nandyāvartaṃ tu padmakam || svastikaṃ prastaraṃ caiva kārmukaṃ ca caturmukham | evaṃ cāṣṭavidhaṃ grāmaṃ tattadrūpeṇa saṃjñitam ||
translation: I will describe the arrangement of a village according to scriptural summary in a step-by-step manner. The well-arranged daṇḍaka is rectangular; nandī āvarta is round like a lotus. Additionally, there is svastika, prastara, and kārmukam, which are shaped like a four-faced arrow. A village is thus classified into eight categories according to these forms.

sloka: alpākṣaramasandigdhaṃ sāravadviśvato mukham| astobhamanavadhyañca sūtraṃ sūtravido viduḥ||
translation: Scholars of the disciplines recognize the subtle, concise, unambiguous, and continuously-emanating sutra, with an all-encompassing, clear opening.

sloka: tac cakṣur devahitaṃ purastāc chukram uc carat | paśyema śaradaḥ śataṃ jīvema śaradaḥ śatam
translation: That divine sight, preceded by brilliance, moves forward. May we see for a hundred autumns, may we live for a hundred autumns.

sloka: tasmādyajñātsarvahuta ṛca: sāmāni jajñire | chandāṃsi jajñire tasmādyajustasmādajāyata ||
translation: From that sacrifice , all hymns and songs were born . Chants and formulas were also generated from it ; that is how they originated .

sloka: yad vai yajñasya sāmnā yajuṣā kriyate śithilaṃ tat | yad ṛcā tad dṛḍham |
translation: That which is made fluid (easy) in a ritual by sāman (a type of hymn), it becomes soft; that which is done with ṛcā (another type of hymn), it becomes firm.

sloka: ekaṃ sadviprā bahudhā vadantyagniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānamāhuḥ ||
translation: Though called by different names - Agni, Yama, Mātariśvan - the wise all recognize there is only one, indivisible Truth.

sloka: saṃgaṭhana sūktam saṃvanana āṅgirasaḥ| agniḥ saṃjñānam| anuṣṭup triṣṭup| saṃsa॒midyṷvase vṛṣa॒nnagne॒ viśvā̭nya॒rya ā | i॒l̤aspa॒de sami̭dhyase॒ sa no॒ vasū॒nyā bha̭ra || saṃ ga̭cchadhva॒ṃ saṃ va̭dadhva॒ṃ saṃ vo॒ manā̭ṃsi jānatām | de॒vā bhā॒gaṃ yathā॒ pūrvḙ saṃjānā॒nā u॒pāsa̭te || sa॒mā॒no mantra॒: sami̭tiḥ samā॒nī sa̭mā॒naṃ mana̭: sa॒ha ci॒ttamḙṣām | sa॒mā॒naṃ mantra̭ma॒bhi ma̭ntraye vaḥ samā॒nena̭ vo ha॒viṣā̭ juhomi || sa॒mā॒nī va॒ ākṷ̄tiḥ samā॒nā hṛda̭yāni vaḥ | sa॒mā॒nama̭stu vo॒ mano॒ yathā̭ va॒: susa॒hāsa̭ti ||
translation:
Assembling Sukta of Angirasa, Agni is the name,
In anushtup and trishtup meters,
Abiding in the sacred grass, nourishing the two fires,
You are invoked, oh divine ones, for our protection.

Come together, recite together, let your minds be one,
May the gods assemble here as they did in ancient times.

The Samana mantra: it unites, it is the same, the mind is united,
We offer our oblations with the Samana mantra.

The Samana is the sound, the same within your hearts,
May this unity be with you, as it was in the beginning, full of joy.

sloka: sāmāni yo vetti sa veda tattvam |
translation: The one who recognizes the universal qualities, indeed knows the truth.

sloka: sāmna udgītho rasaḥ |
translation: The extract from the Samaveda, "udgitha," is the essence (rasa).

sloka: jagrāha pāṭhyaṃ ṛgvedāt‌ sāmabhyo gītameva ca yajurvedādabhinayān rasamātharvaṇādapi||
translation: He took up the recitation of the Rigveda, carefully studied the Sama Veda, and thoroughly mastered the Yajurveda, as well as savored the sweetness of the Atharvana Veda.

sloka: tata utkocakaṃ tīrthaṃ gatvā dhaumyāśramaṃ tu te| taṃ vavruḥ pāṇḍavā dhaumyaṃ paurohityāya bhārata||
translation: Having reached the renowned sacred site named Dhaumya's hermitage after that, O Bhārata, the Pāṇḍavas approached him with the intention of appointing him as their priest.

sloka: abhyaṣiñcattato dhaumyo vyāsaśca sumahātapāḥ| nāradaṃ ca puraskṛtya devalaṃ cāsitaṃ munim||
translation: Having initiated the sacred thread ceremony, Dhaumya and the great ascetic Vyasa, along with Narada, approached and welcomed Devala, the sage.

sloka: vyāghrapāda iti khyāto vedavedāṅgapāragaḥ| tasyāhamabhavaṃ putro dhaumyaścāpi mamānujaḥ||
translation: Referred to as "vyaghrapada," he is the knower of the limbs of the Vedas; I am his son, and Dhaumya is my younger brother.

sloka: kṣīrodanasamāyuktaṃ bhojanaṃ hi prayaccha me||
translation: Please serve up a meal joined with condensed milk for me.

sloka: śakrarūpaṃ sa kṛtvā tu sarvairdevagaṇairvṛtaḥ| sahasrākṣastadā bhūtvā vajrapāṇirmahāyaśāḥ||
translation: Becoming identical to Indra in form, and wielding the thunderbolt, he becomes praised as "Mahayasha" by all the groups of gods after being surrounded by them.

sloka: etasminnantare kaścidṛṣirdhaumyo nāmāyodastasya śiṣyāstrayo babhūvurupamanyurāruṇirvedaśceti||
translation: In this context, a certain sage named Dhaumya, and three other scholars named Upamanyu, Aruṇi, and Veda emerged as his students.

sloka: sa ekaṃ śiṣyamāruṇiṃ pāñcālaṃ preṣayāmāsa gaccha kedārakhaṇḍaṃ badhāneti|| ta tatra saṃviveśa kedārakhaṇḍe śayāne ca tathā tasmiṃstadudakaṃ tasthau||
translation: He ordered a single Pancala student named Aruni to go to the Kedara division and secure it. He then entered that very division of Kedara, rested there, and stood near the water.

sloka: sa evamukta upādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca yasmādbhavānkedārakhaṇḍaṃ vidāryotthitastasmātuddālaka eva nāmnā bhavānbhaviṣyatītyupādhyāyenānugṛhītaḥ||
translation: So spoke the student to his teacher. "Since you have arisen from Kedara khanda, you will henceforth be named Uddalaka." The teacher accepted him.

sloka: sa upādhyāyaṃ pratyuvāca bho bhaikṣyeṇa vṛttiṃ kalpayāmīti||
translation: He said to the teacher, "I will adopt a life of begging as my means of livelihood."

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca mayyanivedya bhaikṣyaṃ nopayoktavyamiti|| sa tathetyuktvā bhaikṣyaṃ caritvopādhyāyāya nyavedayat||
translation: The teacher then responded to him, "You should not ask for alms from me." After saying this, he [Rishyasringa] carried out the alms-gathering and reported it to the teacher.

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca naiṣā nyāyyā guruvṛttiranyeṣāmapi bhaikṣyopajīvināṃ vṛttyuparodhaṃ karoṣi ityevaṃ vartamāno lubdho'sīti ||
translation: The teacher replied to him, "This is not proper conduct for a guru, that you, who live on alms, obstruct the livelihood of others. Such greediness becomes you."

sloka: sa tairarkapatrairbhakṣitaiḥ kṣāratiktakaṭurūkṣaistīkṣṇavipākaiścakṣuṣyupahato'ndho babhūva|| tataḥ so'ndho'pi caṅkramyamāṇaḥ kūpe papāta||
translation: With those solar rays consumed, becoming bitter, pungent, and astringent, his eyes burnt, he became blind. Then, even while moving around the well, he fell in.

sloka: tamaśvināvāhatuḥ prītau svastavānayā gurubhaktyā upādhyāyasya te kārṣṇāyasā dantā bhavato'pi hiraṇmayā bhaviṣyanti cakṣuṣmāṃśca bhaviṣyasīti śreyaścāvāpsyasīti||
translation: Through your devotion to the spiritual preceptor, his gold-capped teeth (of wisdom) will be revealed to you, along with sharpened intellect and ultimate benefit, in this very life.

sloka: tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bheryaśca paṇavānakagomukhāḥ | sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdastumulo'bhavat || tataḥ śvetairhayairyukte mahati syandane sthitau | mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaścaiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ || pāñcajanyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṃ dhanañjayaḥ | pauṇḍraṃ dadhmau mahāśaṅkhaṃ bhīmakarmā vṛkodaraḥ ||
translation: Then, conches, drums, horns and trumpets were sounded all at once, creating a tumultuous sound. On a grand chariot harnessed with white horses, Madhava and Pandava blew their divine conches. Hrishikesha played "Panchajanya", Dhananjaya produced "Devadatta", Bhima-Karma, the gluttonous bear, sounded "Paundra" with a great conch.

sloka: asthānasnehakārpaṇyadharmādharmadhiyā''kulam | pārthaṃ prapannamuddiśya śāstrāvataraṇaṃ kṛtam || ||
translation: Designating the scripture as a refuge, with the intention of protecting Partha, a treatise has been composed that examines the duties and wrongdoings arising from compassion or lack thereof in one's family.

sloka: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ | māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata saṃjaya ||
translation: Dhrtarastra asked Sanjaya, "What are the Kauravas and Pandavas doing, who have assembled on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, which is a field of dharma, and are eager to fight?"

sloka: dharmakṣayāt trāyate iti dharmakṣetram |
translation: "Dharmaksetra" is the refuge that protects from the destruction of "dharma".

sloka: sañjaya uvāca dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṃ vyūḍhaṃ duryodhanastadā | ācāryamupasaṃgamya rājā vacanamabravīt || paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍuputrāṇāmācārya mahatīṃ camūm | vyūḍhāṃ drupadaputreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā ||
translation: Sanjaya spoke: "Seeing the Pandava army arranged, King Duryodhana approached his teacher. After meeting with him, the king spoke these words: 'Behold, O wise teacher, this great army of the sons of Pandu, so skillfully arranged by your intelligent student, the son of Drupada.'"

sloka: aparyāptaṃ tadasmākaṃ balaṃ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam | paryāptaṃ tvidameteṣāṃ balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam || ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ | bhīṣmamevābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi ||
translation: Our strength is not yet sufficient, protected as it is by Bhishma. But theirs (Pandava's) strength, protected by Bhima, is enough in all situations. Therefore, all of you should protect Bhishma alone in this battle.

sloka: mahīpate | senayorubhayormadhye rathaṃ sthāpaya me'cyuta || yāvadetānnirikṣe'haṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān | kairmayā saha yoddhavyamasmin raṇasamudyame || yotsyamānānavekṣe'haṃ ya ete'tra samāgatāḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddheryuddhe priyacikīrṣavaḥ ||
translation: O king, place my chariot in the middle of both armies, so that I may observe those who are eager for battle and arrayed here. With whom should I fight alongside in this battle conflagration? I will observe those who have assembled here for the wicked-minded Dhartarashtra's sake, wishing to bring him pleasure in this war.

sloka: pārtha paśyaitānsamavetānkurūniti ||
translation: O Partha, behold these Kurus assembled here.

sloka: dṛṣṭvemaṃ svajanaṃ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṃ samupasthitam || sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṃ ca pariśuṣyati vepathuśca śarīre me romaharṣaśca jāyate || gāṇḍīvaṃ sraṃsate hastāttvakcaiva paridahyate na ca śaknomyavasthātuṃ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ || nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni keśava na ca śreyo'nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanamāhave || na kāṅkṣe vijayaṃ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṃ sukhāni ca kiṃ no rājyena govinda kiṃ bhogairjīvitena vā ||
translation: Having seen my own kin, Kṛṣṇa, standing arrayed for battle and eager to fight, my limbs are trembling, my mouth is drying up, and my body is breaking out in goosebumps; my bow, the Gāṇḍīva, is slipping from my hands, my skin is burning; I am unable to stand steady; my mind is whirling; I see adverse omens; O Keshava, I do not see any good in killing my own people in this battle; of what use to us is victory, kingdom, or pleasure? O Govinda, even life does not seem desirable without them.

sloka: aho bata mahatpāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam | yadrājyasukhalobhena hantuṃ svajanamudyatāḥ || yadi māmapratīkāramaśastraṃ śastrapāṇayaḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyustanme kṣemataraṃ bhavet ||
translation: Alas, we are determined to commit a great sin, prepared to kill our own kin due to the desire for the comfort of kingship. If

sloka: kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ | dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnamadharmo'bhibhavatyuta || utsannakuladharmāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana | narake'niyataṃ vāso bhavatītyanuśuśruma ||
translation: In the destruction of a lineage, its eternal traditions disappear; when righteousness is lost, unrighteousness overtakes the entire family, Janardana. I have heard that when the family traditions are destroyed, the people of such families become permanently settled in hell.

sloka: yadyapyete na paśyanti lobhopahatacetasaḥ | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ mitradrohe ca pātakam || kathaṃ na jñeyamasmābhiḥ pāpādasmānnivartitum | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ prapaśyadbhirjanārdana ||
translation: Although these, their minds tainted by greed, may not see the transgression caused by the destruction of the family lineage and the sin in betraying friends, how are we not to recognize and turn away from this wrongdoing that brings about the downfall of the family and is seen by those who perceive righteousness?

sloka: nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrānnaḥ kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana | pāpamevāśrayedasmānhatvaitānātatāyinaḥ || tasmānnārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ dhārtarāṣṭrānsvabāndhavān | svajanaṃ hi kathaṃ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava ||
translation: Having killed the Dhartarastras, what joy can there be for Janardana? It would be proper to take up only evil by destroying these wicked ones. Therefore, we ought not to kill our relatives, the Dhartarastras. For how could we be happy, O Madhava, after killing our own people?

sloka: ū॒rdhva ū॒ ṣu ṇo̭ adhvarasya hota॒ragne॒ tiṣṭha̭ de॒vatā̭tā॒ yajī̭yān |
translation: Rise up and stand, the hota of the adhvara, among the devatas, for the yajnya.

sloka: agnirekākṣareṇa vāca mudajayat
translation: By the single syllable 'agni' (fire), joy is produced.

sloka: vākyaṃ syādyogyatākāṅkṣāsattiyuktaḥ padoccayaḥ |
translation: A statement becomes fitting to be uttered when longing for worthiness is present along with proper attention and the recitation of words.

sloka: śabdaḥ anumānaṃ arthasya anupalabdheḥ anumeyatvāt ||
translation: Sound is the means of inferring something unperceived, due to its being a basis for inference.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ|
translation: The word of authoritative instruction.

sloka: āptaḥ khalu sākṣātkṛtadharmā |
translation: The revealed duty has indeed been directly experienced by the worthy.

sloka: āptopadeśasāmarthyātśabdātarthasampratyayaḥ || pūraṇapradāhapāṭanānupalabdheḥ ca sambandhābhāvaḥ ||
translation: Understanding of the intended meaning from words arises from competence in receiving appropriate teachings; the connection is lost when fullness, giving, falling, and not finding are absent.

sloka: yenoccāritena sāsnālāṅgūlakakudakhuraviṣāṇināṃ saṃpratyayo bhavati sa śabdaḥ |
translation: By which exaggerated pronunciation of the breath sounds of snake-hood, frog, and elephant's trunk, recognition occurs, that is the word.

sloka: svapnādipratyaye bāhyaṃ sarvathā na hi neṣyate || ||sarvatrālambanaṃ bāhyaṃ deśakālānyathātmakam | janmanyekatra bhinne vā tathā kālāntare'pi vā || ||taddeśo vānyadeśo vā svapnajñānasya gocaraḥ | alātacakre'lātaṃ syācchīghrabhramaṇasaṃskṛtam || ||gandharvanagare'bhrāṇi pūrvadṛṣṭaṃ gṛhādi ca | pūrvānubhūtatoyaṃ ca raśmitaptoṣaraṃ tathā || ||mṛgatoyasya vijñāne kāraṇatvena kalpyate | dravyāntare viṣāṇaṃ ca śaśasyatmā ca kāraṇam || ||śaśaśṛṅgadhiyo mauṇḍyaṃ niṣedhe śiraso'sya ca | vastvantarairasaṃsṛṣṭaḥ padārthaḥ śūnyatādhiyaḥ || ||kāraṇatvaṃ padārthānāmasadvākyārthakalpane | atyantānanubhūto'pi buddhyā yo'rthaḥ prakalpyate ||
translation: In the waking state, external objects are not carried over from dreams and are different in terms of place, time, and characteristics. The knowledge of this difference is within the scope of experience. The mind may become agitated by rapid movements, leading to the perception of things like flying in the city of gandharvas or entering one's own home. In the understanding of the nature of a deer's body, it is considered as the cause of thirst, just as poison is considered the cause of illness. The concept of "shashashringa-maundya" refers to the prohibition of shaving the head in certain circumstances. An object devoid of substance and created by other objects is called "shunyata." Knowledge arises from the connection between words and their meanings, even if it is not directly experienced. The meaning that is constructed through this process is called "vakyartha." It is possible for one to imagine an object that has never been directly experienced. This is known as "atyantanubhuta."

sloka: atyantāsatyapi jñānamarthe śabdaḥ karoti hi|
translation: Speech, indeed, creates knowledge that is utterly false for a purpose.

sloka: tasya retaḥ pracaskanda dṛṣṭvāpsarasamurvaśīm| apsūpaspṛśato rājanmṛgī taccāpibattadā|| tasyarṣeḥ śṛṅgaṃ śirasi rājannāsīnmahātmanaḥ| tenarṣyaśṛṅga ityevaṃ tadā sa prathito'bhavat||
translation: Having seen the divine urvaśī emerge from his semen floating on the water, the king named him "arśyashrnga" (meaning "one with an antelope's horn on his head"), for at that moment a horn-like projection had appeared on the sage's forehead.

sloka: purohitāpacārācca tasya rājño yadṛcchayā| na vavarṣa sahasrākṣastato'pīḍyanta vai prajāḥ||
translation: Despite the chief priest's improper behavior, by the king's will, Indra did not rain, and as a result, the subjects were afflicted.

sloka: ihāgato jaṭilo brahmacārī na vai hrasvo nātidīrgho manasvī| suvarṇavarṇaḥ kamalāyatākṣaḥ svataḥ surāṇāmiva śobhamānaḥ||
translation: Here has come the brahmachari Jaṭila, not excessively short or too tall, of golden color, with lotus-like eyes, and shining naturally like the suras.

sloka: sa lomapādaḥ paripūrṇakāmaḥ sutāṃ dadāvṛṣyaśṛṅgāya śāntām| krodhapratīkārakaraṃ ca cakre gāścaiva mārgeṣu ca karṣaṇāni||
translation: He, Lomapada, fulfilled in desires, gave to Risyashringa a peaceful cow and also created a means of defense against anger. Additionally, he made cows move on the paths (for purposes like plowing).

sloka: ṛṣyaśṛṅgastu jāmātā putrāṃstava vidhāsyati sanatkumārakathitametāvadvyāhṛtaṃ mayā
translation: Rishyashringa, your father, will instruct your sons following the teachings of Sanatkumara that I have recited so far.

sloka: brahmacārī gṛhasthaśca vānaprastho yatistathā | ete gṛhasthaprabhavāścatvāraḥ pṛthagāśramāḥ | yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yathā nadīnadāḥ sarve sāgare yānti saṃsthitim | tathaivāśramiṇaḥ sarve gṛhasthe yānti saṃsthitim |
translation: Like all creatures seeking sustenance in the wind, so do they in the householder, who is born from observing brahmacharya. Just as rivers flow to the sea for their settled state, all ashramites too go to the householder for their established order.

sloka: gṛhasthaḥ pravarasteṣāṃ gārhasthyaṃ dharmamāśritaḥ|
translation: The best among householders, anchored in the righteousness of maintaining a household.

sloka: samyaktapaścarantīha śraddadhānā vanāśrame | gṛhāśramasya te devi kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm ||
translation: Practicing austerities with proper reverence in the forest hermitage, they are not able to dedicate even a fraction of the value of domestic hermitage to you, O goddess.

sloka: yathā mātaramāśritya sarve jīvanti jantavaḥ | tathā gṛhāśramaṃ prāpya sarve jīvanti cāśramāḥ||
translation: Just as all living beings subsist relying on their mothers, so do all residents thrive in the domestic ashrama.

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset |
translation: Having properly studied the Vedas or at least one of them in order, a continuously celibate student should take up the householder ashrama.

sloka: adhītya vedānkṛtasarvakṛtyaḥ saṃtānamutpādya sukhāni bhuktvā| samāhitaḥ pracaredduścaraṃ taṃ gārhasthyadharmaṃ munidharmajuṣṭam||
translation: Having studied the Vedas and fulfilled all duties, having cultivated contentment and enjoyed pleasures, a self-collected person should diligently practice that domestic dharma approved by sages.

sloka: sarveṣāṃ api caiteṣāṃ vedasmṛtividhānataḥ | gṛhastha ucyate śreṣṭhaḥ sa trīnetānbibharti hi |
translation: Among all of these, the one who has memorized and mastered the Vedas is considered the best grahastha (householder). Such a person indeed sustains the threefold obligations.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca ||
translation: A virtuous, self-restrained, and accomplished man with faith, as long as he engages in activities among women who have control over their senses and also among those who have been defeated by them, ...

sloka: pañcayajñaviśuddhātmā ṛtunityo'nasūyakaḥ| dānto brāhmaṇasatkartā susaṃmṛṣṭaniveśanaḥ|| cakṣuḥśrotramanojihvāsnigdhavarṇapradaḥ sadā| atithyabhyāgatarataḥ śeṣānnakṛtabhojanaḥ|| pādyamarghyaṃ yathānyāyamāsanaṃ śayanaṃ tathā| dīpaṃ pratiśrayaṃ caiva yo dadāti sa dhārmikaḥ||
translation: One who is pure at heart, constantly performs the five sacred duties, free from envy and anger, self-controlled, engaged in the service of brahmins, with a clean residence, having clear senses of sight, hearing, mind, and tongue, always ready to receive guests, offering food and other things to them as per custom, providing water, welcome offerings, seat, bed, light, and shelter to guests, is truly a righteous person.

sloka: mṛgoṣṭrakharamarkākhu sarīsṛpkhagamakṣikāḥ | ātmanaḥ putravatpaśyet taireṣāmantaraṃ kiyat ||
translation: Just as a person regards a deer, camel, ass, sparrow, snake, and insect to be like his own children, he should perceive the distinction between them to be minimal.

sloka: svadāratuṣṭastvṛtukālagāmī niyogasevī na śaṭho na jihnaḥ| mitāśano devarataḥ kṛtajñaḥ satyo mṛduścānṛśaṃsaḥ kṣamāvān||
translation: A faithful husband, satisfied with his wife, following the appointed time, serving the traditional rite, not deceitful or greedy, eating moderately, committed to his vow, grateful, truthful, gentle, and forgiving – such is a man.

sloka: śarīramekaṃ daṃpatyorvidhātrā pūrvanirmitam| tasmātsvadāranirato brahmacārī vidhīyate||
translation: Created in the past by the one manufacturer, the body is a single entity shared by the couple. Therefore, a devoted student of Brahman should remain celibate.

sloka: ekenāṃśena dharmārthaḥ kartavyo hitamicchatā| ekenāṃśena kāmārthamekamaṃśaṃ vivardhayet||
translation: With a fraction of one's efforts, one should pursue dharma and artha while being motivated by the welfare of others. Another fraction should be devoted to the pursuit of kama or desires, with the aim of nurturing and growing it gradually.

sloka: yāvad arthamupāsīno dehe gehe ca paṇḍitaḥ | virakto raktavat tatra nṛloke naratāṃ nyaset || divyaṃ bhaumaṃ cāntarīkṣaṃ vittaṃ acyutanirmitam | tatsarvaṃ upayuñjāna etatkuryāt svato budhaḥ ||
translation: As long as a wise worshipper is established in the body and at home, being indifferent and unattached to worldly pleasures, they should make use of all divine, earthly, and heavenly possessions, which are infallibly created, for their own benefit.

sloka: yāvad bhriyeta jaṭharaṃ tāvat svatvaṃ hi dehinām | adhikaṃ yo'bhimanyeta sa steno daṇḍamarhati ||
translation: As long as the body is maintained, so long do beings have their individuality. Whoever claims excessively belongs to him, he is a thief deserving of punishment.

sloka: dānto vidheyo havyakavyāpramatto hyannasya dātā satataṃ dvijebhyaḥ| amatsarī sarvaliṅgapradātā vaitānanityaśca gṛhāśramī syāt||
translation: The self-controlled householder, always the giver of food to the deserving twice-born, unattached to sacrificial offerings and literary works, impartial in distributing all kinds of objects, should be eternal in this world.

sloka: atithipriyatā dharmo dharmastretāgnidhāraṇam| iṣṭirvā paśubandhāśca vidhipūrvaṃ paraṃtapa||
translation: Hospitality towards guests is the religion of the age of Treta yuga, as is the proper maintenance of sacred fires; worship and animal sacrifices are preceding duties, O scorcher of foes.

sloka: vaivāhike'gnau kurvīta gṛhyaṃ karma yathāvidhi | pañcayajñavidhānaṃ ca paktiṃ cānvāhikīṃ gṛhī |
translation: In the marriage ceremony, one should perform the domestic ritual according to the rules. Also, one should properly observe the five daily sacrifices and the additional offerings for the ancestors.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan | tāsāṃ krameṇa sarvāsāṃ niṣkṛtyarthaṃ maharṣibhiḥ | pañca klptā mahāyajñāḥ pratyahaṃ gṛhamedhinām |
translation: Five are the duties of a householder: sweeping, cleaning, making beds, cooking, and looking after cattle. The scriptures have designated five great sacrifices to be performed daily by the householders: for the ancestors, gods, sages, man, and animals.

sloka: svādhyāyenārcayeta rṣīnhomairdevānyathāvidhi | pitṝñ śrāddhaiśca nṝnannairbhūtāni balikarmaṇā |
translation: With daily self-study (svādhyāya), one should properly worship the seers (rṣis) and gods through Vedic rituals, performed in the prescribed manner. Also, offer food and water to ancestors and other beings through rituals like śrāddha.

sloka: pañcaitānyo mahāayajñānna hāpayati śaktitaḥ | sa gṛhe'pi vasannityaṃ sūnādoṣairna lipyate | devatātithibhṛtyānāṃ pitṝṇāṃ ātmanaśca yaḥ | na nirvapati pañcānāṃ ucchvasanna sa jīvati | svādhyāye nityayuktaḥ syāddaive caiveha karmaṇi | daivakarmaṇi yukto hi bibhartīdaṃ carācaram |
translation: Performing these five great sacrifices, one endowed with strength does not become tainted by the sins of sonhood even while living at home. The one who serves gods, guests, servants, ancestors, and self does not depart after death if he doesn't neglect the five fires (functions of life). Constantly engaged in self-study and daily duties, such a person sustains both moving and non-moving beings through his performance of divine duties.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī |
translation: Having performed the sacrificial offering to the deity in this way, one should first welcome the guest. And according to the proper procedure, give alms to the mendicant who has arrived. Just as one attains pious merit by giving land to a guru according to the prescribed rites, similarly, a twice-born individual (dvija) acquires that same pious merit by giving alms to the mendicant.

sloka: saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam |
translation: Upon your arrival as a guest, one should offer a seat and water, as well as food according to one's ability, with due respect and following proper procedure.

sloka: bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | devānṛṣīnmanuṣyāṃśca pitṝngṛhyāśca devatāḥ | pūjayitvā tataḥ paścādgṛhasthaḥ śeṣabhugbhavet |
translation: After the brahmins and his own servants have their fill, then let the householder enjoy the leftovers. Only after performing the worship of gods, sages, humans, ancestors, and home deities should the grihastha (householder) partake of the remaining food.

sloka: śuśrūṣante ye pitaraṃ mātaraṃ ca gṛhāśrame| bhartāraṃ caiva yā nārī agnihotraṃ ca ye dvijāḥ|| teṣuteṣu ca prīṇanti devā indrapurogamāḥ| pitaraḥ pitṛlokasthāḥ svadharmeṇa sa rajyate||
translation: Devas, led by Indra, are pleased in those households where women serve their husbands and parents, and where twice-born ones perform the agnihotra ritual. In such homes, fathers who have gone to the world of the ancestors reside happily, fulfilling their own duties.

sloka: maharṣipitṛdevānāṃ gatvānṛṇyaṃ yathāvidhi | putre sarvaṃ samāsajya vasenmādhyasthyaṃ āśritaḥ |
translation: After properly visiting the great sages and ancestors of the gods, having entrusted all to his son, he should take up residence in a neutral position.

sloka: ekākī cintayennityaṃ vivikte hitaṃ ātmanaḥ | ekākī cintayāno hi paraṃ śreyo'dhigacchati |
translation: Reflecting alone, always in seclusion, on what is beneficial for oneself, one who reflects indeed attains the highest good.

sloka: satsaṅgācchanakaiḥ saṅgaṃ ātmajāyātmajādiṣu | vimuñcen mucyamāneṣu svayaṃ svapnavadutthitaḥ ||
translation: Freed from attachment to sons and so on, one should abandon attachment through the company of good people. When one is undergoing liberation, they themselves will arise as if from a dream.

sloka: siddhairyajñāvaśiṣṭārthaiḥ kalpayed vṛttimātmanaḥ | śeṣe svatvaṃ tyajan prājñaḥ padavīṃ mahatāmiyāt ||
translation: With the remnants of sacrifices accomplished by perfection, the wise one should establish a mode of living for himself; abandoning personal ownership in what remains, he should attain to the supreme station.

sloka: eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram ||
translation: In these (eṣu), bathing, recitation of mantras, fire rituals, and vows are offerings; to gods, twice-born ones, ancestors, humans, and beings, what is given (dattam) becomes permanently dedicated (taddhyanaśvaram).

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ || ||
translation: One who desires the highest good should regularly inhabit these places. For, righteousness is the cause of the dawning of thousands of fruits for humans.

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ ||
translation: One who is devoted to these places and desires the highest good , should practice this duty , which is prescribed for men and bears the fruit of thousands .

sloka: ye śāstravidhimutsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ | teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvamāho rajastamaḥ ||
translation: Those who, abandoning the rule of scripture, worship with faith, what is their conviction, Krishna? Is it sattva, rajas, or tamas?

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā | sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: The faith of embodied beings is of three kinds and naturally so: pure, passionate, and deluded. Listen about them.

sloka: sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata | śraddhāmayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yacchraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
translation: The faith of everyone becomes conforming to their predominant sattva, O Bhārata. This person is truly what his faith is.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: Purity prevails in happiness, passion in action, O Bhārata; knowledge , when covered by ignorance , becomes the cause of delusion.

sloka: yaḥ śāstravidhimutsṛjya vartate kāmakārataḥ | na sa siddhimavāpnoti na sukhaṃ na parāṃ gatim || tasmācchāstraṃ pramāṇaṃ te kāryākāryavyavasthitau | jñātvā śāstravidhānoktaṃ karma kartumihārhasi ||
translation: One who abandons the code of conduct laid down in the scriptures and acts according to his own desires will not attain success, happiness, or the highest goal. Therefore, scripture is your standard for discerning between right and wrong actions. Having understood the scripturally ordained duties, you should be eager to perform them.

sloka: aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṃkārasaṃyuktāḥ kāmarāgabalānvitāḥ || karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ | māṃ caivāntaḥśarīrasthaṃ tānviddhyāsuraniścayān ||
translation: Those who practice austerities not prescribed by scripture, driven by arrogance and desire, tormenting their own bodies and the group of elements within, as well as me who dwells within the body – know them to be of demonic resolve.

sloka: āhārastvapi sarvasya trividho bhavati priyaḥ | yajñastapastathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedamimaṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: Food, too, is of three kinds, pleasing to everyone. Likewise, there are three forms of sacrifice, austerity, and charity; hear about their differences.

sloka: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇāstena vedāśca yajñāśca vihitāḥ purā ||
translation: The description "om tatsat" is remembered as threefold for Brahman; through it, Brahmins of the past established Vedas and rituals.

sloka: tasmādomityudāhṛtya yajñadānatapaḥkriyāḥ | pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṃ brahmavādinām || tadityanabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajñatapaḥkriyāḥ | dānakriyāśca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣakāṅkṣibhiḥ || sadbhāve sādhubhāve ca sadityetatprayujyate | praśaste karmaṇi tathā sacchabdaḥ pārtha yujyate || yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ saditi cocyate | karma caiva tadarthīyaṃ sadityevābhidhīyate ||
translation: Having resolved this very thing, the ritual actions of sacrifice, charity, and austerity are regularly performed by followers of Brahma. By not doubting, seekers of liberation perform various kinds of gift-giving. The word "sat" is used in reference to the existence of goodness, its presence in pious acts, and as an auspicious word in proper conduct. In sacrifices, austerities, and charity, stability is said to exist, and action is also considered to be for that very purpose.

sloka: aśraddhayā hutaṃ dattaṃ tapastaptaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat | asadityucyate pārtha na ca tatpretya no iha ||
translation: Offered without faith, given without sincerity, performed ritualistically - all such actions and austerities, O Partha, are declared to be meaningless; they do not bear fruit in this life or in the next.

sloka: sa hovāca pitaraṃ tata kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti
translation: He asked (his) father to whom I should serve/devote myself.

sloka: tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: By your name indeed shall this fire become (mine); take up this form of mine, manifold.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū |
translation: Overcoming the bondage of birth and death, Triṇāciketa transcends through the combination of three actions and efforts.

sloka: yaddurangatha bhavathi yachasyam bhutani gachati
translation: That which moves on its own and that which creatures depart to (at death).

sloka: pasunamehabhavati yathasma deva
translation: Like how the Lord (Deva) is present in living beings (Pasuna), so too does he exist within us.

sloka: gavamsuryaha paro guruhu
translation: The supreme teacher of both cows and the sun.

sloka: atrā guru śabdha karanamaci
translation: The origin of the word "guru" is here.

sloka: nanavarnakrtini ca
translation: Including those of various colors and forms.

sloka: lokāḥ samastāḥ sukhino bhavantu |
translation: May all the world's beings be happy and at peace.

sloka: tadyaddūrvā bhavatyoṣadhīnāmevāsmiṃstatkṣatraṃ dadhātyatho pratiṣṭhāmetāni ha vai
translation: I am the dūrvā grass in plants, just as a ruler establishes his authority over them.

sloka: ṛgbhyo jātaṃ vaiśyaṃ varṇamāhuḥ | yajurvedaṃ kṣatriyasyāhuryonim | sāmavedo brāhmaṇānāṃ prasūtiḥ |
translation: The caste of vaishya is born from the ṛgveda, the kṣatriya's practice of ritual fire sacrifice comes from the yajurveda, and the sāmaveda gives birth to the brahmins' hymns.

sloka: brahma vā idamagra āsīt| ekameva tadekaṃ sanna vyabhavattacchreyo rūpamatyasṛjata kṣatraṃ yānyetāni devatrā kṣatrāṇīndro varuṇaḥ somo rudraḥ parjanyo yamo mṛtyurīśāna iti |
translation: In the beginning, only Brahman existed. From that singular reality, excellence in the form of various deities such as Indra, Varuna, Soma, Rudra, Parjanya, Yama, and Mrtyu was subsequently created.

sloka: sa śaudraṃ varṇamasṛjata pūṣaṇamiyaṃ vai pūṣeyaṃ hīdaṃ sarvaṃ puṣyati yadidaṃ kiṃ ca|
translation: This created the low-born class, Pushan , surely this Pusha makes all prosper that which exists .

sloka: udāttaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vidyānnīcaṃ kṣatriyameva ca| vaiśyaṃ tu svaritaṃ vidyād bhāradvājamudāttakam | nīcaṃ gautamamityāhurgārgyaṃ ca svaritaṃ viduḥ |
translation: The Brahmana should be pronounced with a high pitch, while the Kshatriya and Vaisya with a rising tone; Bhardvaja should have an upward inflection, and so should Gautama and Gargya. The low-born should be pronounced in a low pitch, as it is understood.

sloka: svarāstu brāhmaṇā jñeyā vargāṇāṃ prathamāśca ye dvitīyāśca tṛtīyāśca caturthāścāpi bhūmipāḥ
translation: The first among the categories are indeed to be known as the brāhmaṇas who possess svara (the quality of having a clear and resonant voice). These include the second, third, and fourth bhūmipās (those who have fully realized their role and responsibility in society) as well.

sloka: vargāṇāṃ pañcamā vaiśyā antasthāśca tathaiva ca ūṣmāṇaśca hakāraśca śūdrā eva prakīrtitāḥ
translation: The fifth of the social classes, namely the merchants, as well as those who dwell in the middle, and those characterized by heat, along with those known as Hakāras, are proclaimed to be shūdrās.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ| tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam||
translation: I created the four-varna system based on qualities and actions; know me to be its imperishable creator.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The Brahmana was born as the mouth, the Kshatriya from his arms, the Vaishya from his thighs, and the Shudra from his feet.

sloka: brahma vai svaṃ mahimānaṃ brāhmaṇeṣvadadhād adhyayanaadhyāpanayajanayājanadānapratigrahasaṃyuktaṃ vedānāṃ guptyai ||
translation: Brahman, indeed, protects its own greatness among Brahmins through study, teaching, procreation, nurturing, performing sacrifices, giving charity, accepting gifts, and being associated with Vedic rituals.

sloka: kṣatre balam adhyayanayajanadānaśastrakośabhūtarakṣaṇasaṃyuktaṃ kṣatrasya vṛddhyai ||
translation: To promote the growth of the Kshatriya, the strength lies in learning, performing rituals, giving charity, acquiring weaponry and protecting subjects.

sloka: viṭsv adhyayanayajanadānakṛṣivāṇijyapaśupālanasaṃyuktaṃ karmaṇāṃ vṛddhyai ||
translation: By engaging in an agriculture-based lifestyle, including trade and animal husbandry, along with study, worship, and charity, one's activities can flourish.

sloka: śūdreṣu pūrveṣāṃ paricaryām ||
translation: Serving of the previous sudra is done.

sloka: sarvasyāsya tu sargasya guptyarthaṃ sa mahādyutiḥ | mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ pṛthakkarmāṇyakalpayat |
translation: For the protection of everything in this creation, the illustrious one with great radiance assigned separate tasks to those with faces, arms, and thighs.

sloka: brāhmaṇānāṃ sito varṇaḥ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu lohitaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ pītako varṇaḥ śūdrāṇāmasitastathā ||
translation: The color of Brahmins is white, that of Kshatriyas is red, yellow is that of Vaishyas, and for Shudras, it is black.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ
translation: I created the four-fold varna system based on qualities and actions.

sloka: brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśāṃ śūdrāṇāṃ ca parantapa | karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāvaprabhavairguṇaiḥ ||
translation: The duties of the brāhmaṇa, kṣatriya, and śūdra castes, as well as others, are divided according to their inherent qualities and natural tendencies, O subduer of foes.

sloka: viprakṣatriyaviṭśūdrā mukhabāhūrupādajāḥ | vairājāt puruṣāt jātā ya ātmācāralakṣaṇāḥ ||
translation: Born from the mouth, arms, and thighs of the supreme Purusha are those souls that are characterized by constant mobility and are known as Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras.

sloka: na yonirnāpi saṃskāro na śrutaṃ na ca saṃtatiḥ | kāraṇāni dvijatvasya vṛttameva tu kāraṇam ||
translation: Not birth, nor religious grooming, nor hearing of the Vedas, nor lineage; only conduct is the cause of dvijatva (twice-born or brahmin status).

sloka: brāhmaḥ svabhāvaḥ suśroṇiḥ samaḥ sarvatra me matiḥ | nirguṇaṃ nirmalaṃ brahma yatra tiṣṭhati sa dvijaḥ ||
translation: A Brāhmin is one whose inherent nature is pure and equanimous in all circumstances. A dvija is established in the impersonal, stainless Brahman, where my consciousness consistently dwells.

sloka: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svadharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ ||
translation: It is better to follow one's own duty, even if imperfectly, than to do another's perfectly. Following the wrong duties can lead to danger.

sloka: etaiḥ karmaphalairdevi nyūnajātikulodbhavaḥ| śūdro'pyāgamasampanno dvijo bhavati saṃskṛtaḥ ||
translation: Even a person of low birth, if endowed with the fruit of actions prescribed in sacred texts, becomes a cultured Brahmin, just like a born Brahmin.

sloka: nityakarmānuṣṭhānāddharmotpattirdharmotpatteḥ pāpahānistataścittaśuddhiḥ |
translation: From the regular performance of duties arises righteousness, and from that arises the destruction of sin and ultimately the purification of the mind.

sloka: brāhmaṇyaṃ devi duṣprāpaṃ nisargāt brāhmaṇaḥ śubhe | kṣatriyo vaiśyaśūdrau vā nisargāditi me matiḥ ||
translation: Becoming a true brahmin is rarely achieved by nature, in my opinion; it is so for a kshatriya, vaishya, or shudra as well.

sloka: ete yoniphalā devi sthānabhāganidarśakāḥ | svayaṃ ca varadenoktā brahmaṇā sṛjatā prajāḥ ||
translation: These, as divine proclamations, are the results of origins and allotments of places; they were created by Brahman himself and have been spoken of as self-bestowed.

sloka: karmabhiḥ śucibhirdevi śuddhātmā vijitendriyaḥ | śūdro'pi dvijavat sevya iti brahmābravīt svayam ||
translation: Even a pure-self and self-controlled person, who is devoted to good deeds and cleanliness, should be served by the Brahmin himself, as proclaimed by Brahma.

sloka: svabhāvaḥ karma ca śubhaṃ yatra śūdro'pi tiṣṭhati | viśiṣṭaḥ sa dvijātervai vijñeya iti me matiḥ ||
translation: In my view, one who possesses good character and actions, even if they are of low birth, should be considered superior to those of noble birth.

sloka: yasya yallakṣaṇaṃ proktaṃ puṃso varṇābhivyañjakam | yadanyatrāpi dṛśyeta tattenaiva vinirdiśet || ||
translation: For the man whose distinguishing signs have been described, if any other [qualities] are seen, they should be attributed to him alone.

sloka: yasya yallakṣaṇaṃ proktaṃ puṃso varṇābhivyañjakam | yadanyatrāpi dṛśyeta tattenaiva vinirdiśet ||
translation: Whose characteristic sign(s) is/are declared for a man, if seen elsewhere, it should be identified as the same one.

sloka: athavā brāhmaṇasvabhāvasya sattvaguṇaḥ prabhavaḥ kāraṇam tathā kṣatriyasvabhāvasya sattvopasarjanaṃ rajaḥ prabhavaḥ vaiśyasvabhāvasya tamaupasarjanaṃ rajaḥ prabhavaḥ śūdrasvabhāvasya rajaupasarjanaṃ tamaḥ prabhavaḥ praśāntyaiśvaryehāmūḍhatāsvabhāvadarśanāt caturṇām |
translation: Either the inherent quality of a Brāhmaṇa is the manifestation of the sattva guṇa (mode of goodness) and the cause, or for a Kṣatriya, it is the manifestation of rajo guṇa (mode of passion) that leads to the rise of aggression. Similarly, for a Vaiśya, it is tamo guṇa (mode of ignorance) that brings about attachment, and for a Śūdra, it is the manifestation of raja guṇa that results in delusion. This is understood by realizing the inherent nature of the four varnas (social orders).

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ saṃtoṣaḥ kṣāṃtirārjavam | mad‍bhaktiśca dayā satyaṃ brahmaprakṛtayastvimāḥ || || tejo balaṃ dhṛtiḥ śauryaṃ titikṣaudāryamudyamaḥ | sthairyaṃ brahmaṇyataiśvaryaṃ kṣatra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || || āstikyaṃ dānaniṣṭhā ca adaṃbho brahmasevanam | atuṣṭiḥ arthopacayaiḥ vaiśya prakṛtayastvimāḥ || || śuśrūṣaṇaṃ dvijagavāṃ devānāṃ cāpi amāyayā | tatra labdhena saṃtoṣaḥ śūdra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || ||

śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ saṃtoṣaḥ kṣāṃtirārjavam | mad‍bhaktiśca dayā satyaṃ brahmaprakṛtayastvimāḥ || tejo balaṃ dhṛtiḥ śauryaṃ titikṣaudāryamudyamaḥ | sthairyaṃ brahmaṇyataiśvaryaṃ kṣatra prakṛtayastvimāḥ || āstikyaṃ dānaniṣṭhā ca adaṃbho brahmasevanam | atuṣṭiḥ arthopacayaiḥ vaiśya prakṛtayastvimāḥ || śuśrūṣaṇaṃ dvijagavāṃ devānāṃ cāpi amāyayā | tatra labdhena saṃtoṣaḥ śūdra prakṛtayastvimāḥ ||
translation: Of the constituents of one's nature, the faithful and diligent cultivation of tranquility, self-control, austerity, purification, contentment, forbearance, courage, resolution, steadfastness, sovereignty, and glory are indicative of a Brahmin.
