Generosity, firm commitment, absence of deceit, servitude to the divine, and satisfaction through resources gained honorably are marks of a Vaisya. Attentiveness, service to teachers and gods without deceit, and finding contentment in one's occupation signify a Sudra.

sloka: brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyo vaiśyastrayo varṇā dvijātayaḥ | caturtha ekajātistu śūdro nāsti tu pañcamaḥ |
translation: The first three castes are the Brahmana, Kshatriya, and Vaishya, all of whom are twice-born. The fourth is a single caste, the Shudra, who is not considered as the fifth, the outcast.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Self-control, restraint, austerity, cleanliness, forgiveness, honesty, and certainly, knowledge, awareness, and faith in the self are the inherent duties of a brahmin. Courage, power, fortitude, not retreating in battle, generosity, and lordly behavior are the inherent duties of a kshatriya. Agriculture, tending to cattle, and trade are the inherent duties of a vaishya. Serving others is the inherent duty of a shudra.

sloka: sve sve karmaṇyabhirataḥ saṃsiddhiṃ labhate naraḥ | svakarmanirataḥ siddhiṃ yathā vindati tacchṛṇu ||
translation: A person attains success (perfection) in their own respective duties; listen about how one devoted to their own duty achieves success.

sloka: yaḥ kaścidātmānamadvitīyaṃ jātiguṇakriyāhīnaṃ ṣaḍūrmiṣaḍbhāvetyādisarvadoṣarahitaṃ satyajñānānandānantasvarūpaṃ svayaṃ nirvikalpamaśeṣakalpādhāraśeṣabhūtāntaryāmitvena vartamānamantaryahiścākāśavadanusyūtamakhaṇḍānandasvabhāvamaprameyamanubhavaikavedyamaparokṣatayā bhāsamānaṃ karatalamalakavatsākṣādaparokṣīkṛtya kṛtārthatayā kāmarāgādidoṣarahitaḥ śamadamādisampanno bhāvamātsaryatṛṣṇāśāmohādirahito dambhāhaṅkāradibhirasaṃspṛṣṭacetā vartata evamuktalakṣaṇo yaḥ sa eva brāhmaṇeti śrutismṛtītihāsapurāṇānāmabhiprāyaḥ | anyathā hi brāhmaṇatvasiddhirnāstyeva |
translation: The one who, without a second, is of unique soul, devoid of material qualities and actions, free from the six senses and six changes; who is always endowed with all auspicious attributes, ultimate truth, knowledge, infinite bliss, non-dual self; who exists within all beings and things, pervading them like ether, eternal, unchanging, and full of transcendental happiness, realized through direct experience; who is free from desires, passions, faults, pride, and ego; who possesses tranquility, self-control, detachment, forbearance, compassion, and other virtues; whose mind is untainted by envy, greed, delusion, or deceit - such a one, as described, is known as a brahmin according to the consensus of scripture, tradition, and folklore. Any other attainment of brahminhood is not valid.

sloka: adhyāpanaṃ adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānāṃ akalpayat | prajānāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānaṃ ijyādhyayanaṃ eva ca | viṣayeṣvaprasaktiśca kṣatriyasya samāsataḥ | paśūnāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānaṃ ijyādhyayanaṃ eva ca | vaṇikpathaṃ kusīdaṃ ca vaiśyasya kṛṣiṃ eva ca | ekaṃ eva tu śūdrasya prabhuḥ karma samādiśat | eteṣāṃ eva varṇānāṃ śuśrūṣāṃ anasūyayā | sarvaṃ svaṃ brāhmaṇasyedaṃ yatkiṃ cijjagatīgatam | śraiṣṭhyenābhijanenedaṃ sarvaṃ vai brāhmaṇo'rhati |
translation: Instruction for the four social classes has been laid down as follows: Teaching , studying , performing yajnas , officiating in yajnas for brahmanas; For kshatriyas, governing the subjects, protecting them , donations , learning , and engaging in material activities ; For vaishyas, looking after cattle , trade , usury , and agriculture ; And for shudras, serving a single occupation has been assigned. The brahmana, free from envy , is entitled to enjoy all the riches of this world as they are all derived from him . This superiority of the brahmana is due to his higher birth and not because of any personal effort.

sloka: paṇiḥ vaṇik bhavati |paṇiḥ paṇanāt | vaṇik paṇyaṃ nenekti |
translation: A merchant becomes a thief, taking after theft. For, the merchant trades in valuable commodities.

sloka: kadū mahīradhṛṣṭā asya taviṣīḥ kadu vṛtraghno astṛtam | indro viśvānbekanāṭā~ ahardṛśa uta kratvā paṇī~rabhi ||
translation: When indeed will the earth-disturber, proud of his strength, be destroyed by this brilliant one, the enemy of the deceitful and unrighteous? Indra, the all-seeing, is surely the protector who has defeated hardness and established firm resolve.

sloka: vadhīrhi dasyuṃ dhaninaṃ ghanena~ ekaścarannupaśākebhirindra | dhanoradhi viṣuṇakte vyāyannayajvānaḥ sanakāḥ pretimīyuḥ ||
translation: King Indra, with his thunderbolt alone and supported by a single wheeled chariot, subdues the wealthy robbers in an instant; the Sanakas, always content with little, are not excited even by the oblations offered by the Lord of the universe.

sloka: saṃ vāṃ karmaṇā samiṣā hinomīndrāviṣṇū apasaspāre asya | juṣethāṃ yajñaṃ draviṇaṃ ca dhattamariṣṭairnaḥ pathibhi: pārayantā ||
translation: Together with you, through action and contribution, we should engage in this sacrifice and gift-giving, approaching them with pure intentions, free from harm and malice.

sloka: māsebhyaḥ pitṛlokaṃ pitṛlokādākāśamākāśāccandramasameṣa somo rājā taddevānāmannaṃ taṃ devā bhakṣayanti ||
translation: "The moon, the king of plants, who is the son of pitrs (forefathers), goes from the world of pitrs to the sky after a month. This is Soma. The devas consume this as their food."

sloka: māsebhyaḥ pitṛlokaṃ pitṛlokādākāśamākāśāccandramasameṣa somo rājā taddevānāmannaṃ taṃ devā bhakṣayanti ||
translation: "The moon, king Soma, who is identical to the ether beyond the heavenly world of fathers, and to the starry sky, as nourishment for the gods, they consume it monthly from the world of fathers."

sloka: apāma somamamṛtā abhūmāganma jyotiravidāma devān | kiṃ nūnamasmānkṛṇavadarātiḥ kimu dhūrtiramṛta martyasya ||
translation: Who among the gods have become immortal by partaking of the soma offering, comparable to the elixir of life, that has now been obtained and brought forth as a radiant source of light? What cruelty or treachery could there be towards us mortals who are not immortal?

sloka: tasyāśitādyādāhārādbalaṃ varṇaśca vardhate yasyartusātmyaṃ viditaṃ ceṣṭāhāravyapāśrayam
translation: The strength and complexion of someone who is known to have a harmonious relationship with the seasons grow through their appropriate consumption of food.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: Longevity, memory, intelligence, good health, youthfulness, vigor, luster, generosity, physical and mental strength, and eloquence are all attained through a virtuous lifestyle, not by the use of rejuvenating potions. This is true for those who follow the path of righteousness.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The first of the six seasonal periods, marking the beginning of the rains, is known as ṛtu-sandhi. This should be followed as a rule in the beginning, and then abandoned later. If one clings to it throughout, diseases arising from incompatibility will arise suddenly.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The first of the six seasons, marked by its onset, is remembered as "sandhiriti." Among them, the initial one should be observed and followed, while abandoning the subsequent one brings about diseases due to an incompatible lifestyle.

sloka: yad ṛtviyād asṛjat tad ṛtūnāṃ ṛtutvam |
translation: What was created by the one who conducts the ritual is the true nature of the seasons.

sloka: ṛtusandhiṣu vyādhayaḥ jāyante ṛtusandhiṣu yajñāḥ kriyante|
translation: In the change of seasons, illnesses arise; in the change of seasons, sacrifices are performed.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation: The three types of causes for the manifestation of physical transformations are: 1. the improper connection with sense objects , 2. a mistake in understanding , and 3. a natural tendency . These are the three categories of causes for the modifications arising from the union of relevant factors .

sloka: kālārthakarmaṇāṃ yogo hīnamithyātimātrakaḥ| samyagyogośca vijñeyo rogārogyaikakāraṇam||
translation: The true meaning of yoga should be understood as that which is proper for achieving the right goal at the right time; it is not just a means of performing unnecessary or excessive actions, but rather it is the sole cause for maintaining both health and freedom from disease.

sloka: dhīdhṛtismṛtivibhraṣṭaḥ karma yatkurute aśubham| prajñāparādhaṃ taṃ vidyāt sarvadoṣaprakopaṇam||
translation: One who is neglectful of mindfulness and memory, whatever wrongful action they perform, it should be known as a transgression of wisdom, capable of inciting all vices.

sloka: daivamātmakṛtaṃ vidyāt karma yat paurvadaihikam smṛtaḥ puruṣakārastu kriyate yadihāparam
translation: A supernatural act, created by the self, is remembered as past-life karma; a human action is performed when it's otherwise.

sloka: sukhādyupalabdhisādhanamindriyaṃ manaḥ| tacca pratyātmaniyatatvādanantaṃ paramāṇurūpaṃ nityaṃ ca||
translation: The means of experiencing pleasures and the like, the senses and the mind, are inherently atomic and eternal in their nature of self-contained consciousness.

sloka: cintyaṃ vicāryamūhyaṃ ca dhyeyaṃ saṅkalpyameva ca yatkiñcinmanaso jñeyaṃ tat sarvaṃ hyarthasañjñakam indriyābhigrahaḥ karma manasaḥ svasya nigrahaḥ ūho vicāraśca
translation: That which is worthy of contemplation, to be analyzed, and also the object of meditation and resolution – indeed, everything knowable by the mind is a signifier of meaning; it is the engagement of the senses, control of one’s own actions, and investigation.

sloka: mānasāstu krodhaśokabhayaharṣaviṣāderṣyābhyasūyādainyamātsaryakāmalobhaprabhṛtaya icchādveṣabhedairbhavanti
translation: Let there not arise in the mind hatred, sorrow, fear, delight, despair, envy, arrogance, selfishness, desire for wealth, and other disturbing desires and aversions.

sloka: ātmā jñaḥ karaṇairyogāj jñānaṃ tvasya pravartate karaṇānāmavaimalyādayogādvā na vartate paśyato'pi yathā''darśe saṅkliṣṭe nāsti darśanam tattvaṃ jale vā kaluṣe cetasyupahate tathā
translation: The knowledge of the self (atma), established through connection with the senses, arises in him. But even with the aid of pure senses, if it does not arise, it is like an object not being visible in a distorted mirror or in dirty water.

sloka: dhīdhṛtismṛtivibhraṣṭaḥ karma yat kurute'śubham prajñāparādhaṃ taṃ vidyāt sarvadoṣaprakopaṇam indriyopakramoktasya sadvṛttasya ca varjanam īrṣyāmānabhayakrodhalobhamohamadabhramāḥ tajjaṃ vā karma yat kliṣṭaṃ kliṣṭaṃ yaddehakarma ca yaccānyadīdṛśaṃ karma rajomohasamutthitam prajñāparādhaṃ taṃ śiṣṭā bruvate vyādhikāraṇam
translation: The action performed by one who has fallen from righteousness, wisdom, and steadfastness, and is done with malice, envy, fear, anger, greed, delusion, pride, or confusion, is considered by the wise to be the root cause of all afflictions, whether it be a sinful action committed intentionally or unintentionally, in this life or another, arising from worldly desires and ignorance.

sloka: yaccāpriyamapathyaṃ ca niyataṃ tanna lakṣayet
translation: What is considered displeasing and yet habitual, that should not be ignored.

sloka: mṛjyate śodhyate iti |
translation: Should be washed, should be cleaned.

sloka: tatra śarīraṃ nāma cetanādhiṣṭhānabhūtaṃ pañcamahābhūtavikārasamudāyātmakaṃ samayogavāhi
translation: In that , the body is named , the basis of the conscious principle , made up of the combination of the five great elements , a vehicle for the union .

sloka: yadā hyasmiñ śarīre dhātavo vaiṣamyamāpadyante tadā kleśaṃ vināśaṃ vā prāpnoti
translation: When the imbalance arises among the constituent elements of this body, then one experiences suffering or destruction.

sloka: ojaḥ prāṇāyatanamuttamam dehaḥ sāvayavastena vyāpto bhavati dehinaḥ tadabhāvācca śīryante śarīrāṇi śarīriṇām
translation: The most excellent location of prana (life force) is ojaḥ (vigor), and the body is pervaded by it. When that vigor is absent, the bodies of embodied beings deteriorate.

sloka: sarve śarīradoṣā bhavanti grāmyāhārāt|
translation: All physical ailments arise from indulgence in common food.

sloka: manaḥpuraḥsarāṇīndriyāṇyarthagrahaṇasamarthāni bhavanti
translation: The senses, located in the mind's vicinity, become capable of grasping their respective objects.

sloka: sendriyaṃ cetanaṃ dravyaṃ nirindriyamacetanam
translation: The sentient is with senses, while the insentient is without senses.

sloka: taddhyanutiṣṭhan yugapat sampādayatyarthadvayamārogyamindriyavijayaṃ ceti
translation: Engaging in that meditation, simultaneously, one attains both material wealth and the victory of the senses, as well as good health.

sloka: āyurasmin vidyate anena vā āyurvindanti iti āyurvedaḥ |
translation: The knowledge called Ayurveda is so named because it is through this means that one either finds or does not find (vindanti iti) longevity (ayuh), by making use of this (anena) in the present life (asmin).

sloka: śarīrendriyasattvātmasaṃyogo dhāri jīvitam | nityagaścānubandhaśca paryāyairayurucyate ||
translation: The connection of body, senses, mind, and self is life. It is also called daily sustenance, constant bond, and the means of length of life through various expressions.

sloka: hitāhitaṃ sukhaṃ duḥkham āyus tasya hitāhitam | mānaṃ ca tacca yatroktam āyurvedaḥ sa ucyate ||
translation: That which describes for him the beneficial and harmful, pleasure and pain, lifespan and its enhancement or reduction, as well as reputation - such is called Ayurveda.

sloka: dharmārthakāmamokṣāṇāmārogyaṃ mūlam uttamam || rogāstasyāpahartāraḥ śreyaso jīvitasya ca | prādurbhūto manuṣyāṇāmantarāyo mahānayam ||
translation: The foremost root of righteousness, wealth, desire, and liberation is health. The cessation of disease and the greatest benefit for human beings is its manifestation within them.

sloka: satvamātmā śarīraṃ ca trayametattridaṇḍavat | lokstiṣṭhati saṃyogāttatra sarvaṃ pratiṣṭhitam | sa pumāṃścetanaṃ tacca taccādhikaraṇaṃ smrutam | vedasyāsya tadarthaṃ hi vedo ayaṃ prakāśitaḥ ||
translation: The self , the physical body , and the mode of goodness - these three rest in a balanced state, similar to a tripod. All aspects of existence are established within this balance. This conscious entity , who is remembered as the locus of control, has the purpose of the Vedas revealed in this form.

sloka: tadidaṃ śāśvataṃ puṇyaṃ svargyaṃ yaśasyamāyuṣyaṃ vṛttikaraṃ ceti ||
translation: This is eternal, auspicious, heavenly, fame- and lifespan-enhancing, and a means of sustenance.

sloka: dhātusāmyakriyā coktā tantrasyāsya prayojanam ||
translation: The equal action of the elements is what has been declared as the purpose of this treatise .

sloka: hetuliṅgauṣadhajñānaṃ svasthāturaparāyaṇam | trisūtraṃ śāśvataṃ puṇyaṃ bubudhe yaṃ pitāmahaḥ ||
translation: The ancestor who realized the eternal, sacred three-part knowledge of identifying medicinal herbs for maintaining or restoring self and others' health.

sloka: sirāsnāyurajaḥstanyatvaco gativivarjitāḥ| dhātubhyaścopajāyante tasmātta upadhātavaḥ ||
translation: Born from elements, devoid of movement, excrement, milk, skin, and going, [these] are produced from the elements; therefore, they are known as accessories.

sloka: rasāt stanyaṃ tato raktamasṛjaḥ kaṇḍarāḥ sirāḥ| māṃsādvasā tvacaḥ ṣaṭ ca medasaḥ snāyusambhavaḥ ||
translation: From fluid comes milk , then red blood , followed by marrow , veins , muscle tissue , fat , skin , and finally, sinews/ligaments are all produced.

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|
translation: Knowledge of disease specialization is threefold: as revealed through reliable instruction, direct perception, and inference.

sloka: prāgabhihitaṃ taddu:khasaṃyogāḥ vyādhayaḥ iti| tacca duḥkhaṃ trividhaṃ ādhyātmikam ādhidaivikam ādhibhautikamiti|
translation: Illnesses, as mentioned before, are of three types and constitute suffering: namely, those arising from the union with past deeds, and are divided into the physical, divine, and personal types.

sloka: jāyate buḍhheravyaktādbuddhyā ahm iti manyante| paraṃ khādīnyahaṅkārādutpadyante yathākramam||
translation: From the undeveloped [state], understanding arises in the wise; they think 'it is I'. All [other] manifestations of ego arise in succession after that.

sloka: sarvadā sarvabhāvānāṃ sāmānyaṃ vṛddhikāraṇam| hrāsaheturviśeṣaśca pravṛttirubhayasya tu||
translation: The increase or decrease is always the general cause for all beings; and the specific circumstance is the impetus for their activity.

sloka: jāṭhareṇāgnināyogāt yadudeti rasāntaram| rasānāṃ pariṇāmānte sa vipākaḥ iti smṛtaḥ||
translation: The digestion process, caused by the fire within the stomach, is known as vipāka, at the end of the transformation of tastes.

sloka: śarīrāvayavāstu paramāṇubhedenāparisaṅkhyeyā bhavanti atibahutvādatisaukṣmyādatīndriyatvācca teṣāṃ saṃyogavibhāge paramāṇūnāṃ kāraṇaṃ vāyuḥ karmasvabhāvaśca
translation: The parts of the body, being composed of indivisible atoms that are countless, extremely numerous, and beyond measure, and also due to their lack of perception by the senses, their union and disunion become the cause of movement and the inherent nature of these atoms.

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|
translation: Knowledge of disease specialization is threefold: through instruction from reliable sources, perception, and inference.

sloka: pūrvajanmakṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhirupeṇa bādhyate ||
translation: Born in previous lives, sinful actions are afflicted in the form of diseases.

sloka: yāvantāḥ loke mūrtimantaḥ bhāvaviśeṣāḥ tāvantāḥ puruṣe yāvantāḥ puruṣe tāvantāḥ loke ||
translation: To the extent that distinct forms exist in the world, to that same extent they exist in Purusha; to that same extent they exist in the world.

sloka: rasāyanatantraṃ nāma vayaḥsthāpanamāyurmedhābalakaraṃ rogāpaharaṇasamarthaṃ ca |
translation: The named treatment called "Rasayana" rejuvenates and enhances longevity, intelligence, strength, and has the power to eliminate diseases.

sloka: rasāyanaṃ ca tajñeyaṃ yajjarāvyādhināśanam |
translation: A rejuvenating elixir, indeed mysterious, that destroys aging and disease.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: One who practices austerities gains long life, memory, intelligence, good health, youthfulness, strength in the body and senses, supreme eloquence of speech, humility, and radiance. This is not attained through medicines or any other means, but only by those who follow righteousness.

sloka: kit rogāpanayane|
translation: Who can remove (apanayane) this affliction (roga)?

sloka: cikitsā ruk pratikriyā|
translation: Treatment (or) cure for pain/distress.

sloka: yābhiḥ kriyābhirjāyante śarīre dhātavaḥ samāḥ sā cikitsā vikārāṇāṃ karma tadbhiṣajāṃ smṛtam kathaṃ śarīre dhātūnāṃ vaiṣamyaṃ na bhavediti samānāṃ cānubandhaḥ syādityarthaṃ kriyate kriyā
translation: By what actions are the identical constituent elements of the body produced in the body ? This is considered the treatment for the transformations . The notion is that there should not be any difference among these constituent elements. Thus, a consistent connection is made with their meaning , and this connection is itself the action .

sloka: prayogaḥ śamayedvyādhiṃ yo'nyamanyamudīrayet nāsau viśuddhaḥ śuddhastu śamayedyo na kopayet
translation: The one who applies the remedy to a different ailment without disturbing another, is not pure; only the one who calms down and doesn't anger is pure.

sloka: naiva kurvīta lobhena cikitsāpuṇyavikrayam īśvarāṇāṃ vasumatāṃ lipsetārthaṃ tu vṛttaye cikitsitaṃ śarīraṃ yo na niṣkrīṇāti durmatiḥ sa yatkaroti sukṛtaṃ sarvaṃ tadbhiṣagaśnute na deśo manujairhīno na munaṣyā nirāmayāḥ tataḥ sarvatra vaidyānāṃ susiddhā eva vṛttayaḥ
translation: One should not practice medicine through greed for unrighteous gain, but rather for the welfare of living beings. Whoever neglects to purify their body in this way is impure; wherever such a person may go, they will never find happiness or good health. Therefore, the profession of doctors should only be practiced by those who are skilled and pure-hearted, everywhere and at all times.

sloka: caturṇāṃ bhiṣagādīnāṃ śastānāṃ dhātuvaikṛte pravṛttirdhātusāmyārthā cikitsetyabhidhīyate
translation: The harmonious practice of four types of healers (physicians, surgeons, etc.) is known as the unified purpose of the dhatus (body parts/constituents).

sloka: rūpendriyasvaracchāyāpraticchāyākriyādiṣu|| anyeṣvapi ca bhāveṣu prākṛteṣvnimittataḥ| vikṛtirvā samāsena riṣṭaṃ taditi lakṣayet ||
translation: In appearances, sensory experiences, and activities, etc., or in other unmodified states that arise due to causes, the characteristic of a modified form should be recognized.

sloka: rūpendriyasvaracchāyāpraticchāyākriyādiṣu|| anyeṣvapi ca bhāveṣu prākṛteṣvnimittataḥ| vikṛtirvā samāsena riṣṭaṃ taditi lakṣayet ||
translation: In perceptible forms, such as those of sense objects, and their unconscious impressions; and in actions, starting from basic ones, that occur naturally in various states; one should recognize 'vikriti' (modification) as what is preferable.

sloka: apyevaṃ tu bhavet puṣpaṃ phalenānanubandhi yat | phalaṃ cāpi bhavet kiñcidyasya puṣpaṃ na pūrvajam || na tvariṣṭasya jātasya nāśo'sti maraṇādṛte | maraṇaṃ cāpi tannāsti yannāriṣṭapuraḥsaram||
translation: Even if it becomes like this, a flower and fruit are linked; there is also some fruit for whoever the flower belongs to, not preceding (from before). For the one just born, there is no deterioration prior to death; death itself does not exist for that which is superior to the excellent ultimate essence.

sloka: doṣāṇāmapi bāhulyādriṣṭābhāsaḥ samudbhavet |
translation: Even from an abundance of faults, a mere appearance can arise.

sloka: mithyādṛṣṭamariṣṭābhamanariṣṭamajānatā ariṣṭaṃ vā'pyasambuddhametat prajñāparādhajam
translation: Misperceiving what is not excellent as excellent, or being unaware of what is truly auspicious, or acting nonchalantly towards it—all such transgressions of correct understanding.

sloka: brāhmaṇaistat kilāmalaiḥ rasāyanatapojapyatatparairvā nivāryate
translation: Even the purest of Brahmin's is held back by the use of impure means, rituals, chants, and extreme dedication.

sloka: mānasaḥ punaruddiṣṭo rajaśca tama eva ca
translation: The mind is directed again toward the ruler, namely, ignorance itself.

sloka: hetau liṅge praśamane rogāṇāmapunarbhave jñānaṃ caturvidhaṃ yasya sa rājārho bhiṣaktamaḥ
translation: The king who possesses fourfold knowledge that quells diseases in their origin through these two instruments (i.e., medicine and surgery) is the foremost healer.

sloka: ruk vedanāyāyām|
translation: Relating to pain that is about to arrive.

sloka: vikāro dhātuvaiṣamyaṃ sāmyaṃ prakṛtirucyate sukhasañjñakamārogyaṃ vikāro duḥkhameva ca
translation: A transformation is called a change in the basis of the disparity between elements, and it is called equal when referring to nature, bringing happiness, health, and even suffering.

sloka: tadduḥkhasaṃyogā vyādhaya ucyante
translation: That which is associated with suffering is referred to as a disease.

sloka: nidāna pūrvarūpāṇi rupāṇyupaśayastathā saṃprāptiśceti vijñānaṃ rogāṇāṃ pañcadhā smṛtam|
translation: The knowledge recognized as fivefold concerning the early signs, forms, manifestation, and approach of diseases is remembered as having the causes as its first forms.

sloka: sañcayaṃ ca prakopaṃ ca prasaraṃ sthānasaṃśrayam vyaktiṃ bhedaṃ ca yo vetti doṣāṇāṃ sa bhavedbhiṣak
translation: One who understands the accumulation and aggravation, the spreading out and sheltering, the manifestation and distinction of bodily humors becomes a physician (healer).

sloka: tatra vikāraṃ hetudoṣadūṣyaprakṛtideśakālabalaviśeṣairliṅgataśca parīkṣeta na hyantareṇa hetvādīnāṃ balaviśeṣaṃ vyādhibalaviśeṣopalabdhiḥ
translation: There, one should examine the cause of change through the distinct factors such as defects, faults, nature, time, place, strength, and their special combinations; for, there is no recognition of the superiority of one cause over another as a sign of disease.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation: The three causes of the manifestation of physical transformations are improper use of the senses, intellectual mistakes, and changes in one's nature. These are respectively referred to as unhealthy sensory connections, cognitive errors, and natural cause-and-effect sequences.

sloka: te caturvidhāḥ āgantavaḥ śārīrāḥ mānasāḥ svābhāvikāśceti
translation: These are the four types of naturally occurring entities that come and go: physical and mental.

sloka: dhāraṇāt dhātavaḥ
translation: Due to retention (of essential qualities), the elements (or bodily tissues) remain intact.

sloka: strīpuṃsayoravyāpannaśukraśoṇitagarbhāśayayoḥ śreyasīṃ prajāmicchatostadarthābhinirvṛttikaraṃ karmopadekṣyāmaḥ
translation: We shall instruct the action that leads to the attainment of the most auspicious progeny in the form of a pure embryo free from semen and blood within the bodies of men and women desiring it.

sloka: tasyāmanupaghātāya paripūrṇatvāya sukhaprasavāya ca
translation: For its preservation, completion, happiness, and easy birth.

sloka: dhruvaṃ caturṇāṃ sānnidhyādgarbhaḥ syādvidhipūrvakam ṛtukṣetrāmbubījānāṃ sāmagryādaṅkuro yathā
translation: Undoubtedly, just as the sprout arises from the union of the appropriate elements in fertile soil following proper procedure , so too will the embryo emerge in the presence of the four [seasons] .
